meanings.definition: the buying and selling of goods and services over the internet:

meanings.definition: a type of currency in electronic form that is designed especially for paying for goods and services bought on the internet:

meanings.definition: using the internet to do business or to communicate:

meanings.definition: entertainment that someone is able to see or hear using the internet:

meanings.definition: the arrangements that are necessary for businesses to sell their products or services on the internet:

meanings.definition: products that you can buy on the internet and download directly to your computer, such as electronic books or software:

meanings.definition: the use of the internet by governments to make it possible for people to use government services and be involved in making decisions:

meanings.definition: an invoice (= document asking for payment for a product or service) that is sent electronically over the internet:

meanings.definition: a journal (= specialist magazine) that is published on the internet:

meanings.definition: relating to ways of working where someone uses the internet to sell their services or work, and is not employed by one company:

meanings.definition: learning done by studying at home using computers and courses provided on the internet

meanings.definition: a website that makes books and other reading material available to users:

meanings.definition: the liquid that is used in an e-cigarette or similar device

meanings.definition: the process of advertising and selling products and services on the internet, for example, on a company website or by email:

meanings.definition: the internet, as a place where organizations and consumers exchange information and do business:

meanings.definition: help and advice provided over the internet by someone with a lot of experience in a particular activity to someone who has little experience:

meanings.definition: money that is stored electronically, for example, on a computer or plastic card, and can be used to pay for products and services, for example, on the internet:

meanings.definition: a newspaper in electronic form that is read on a computer, etc.:

meanings.definition: the production of books, magazines, newspapers, etc. that can be read using a computer, for example on the internet or on a CD:

meanings.definition: a business that uses the internet to sell its products:

meanings.definition: the activity of using the internet to sell products:

meanings.definition: a ticket, usually for someone to travel on an aircraft, that is held on a computer and is not printed on paper

near the beginning of a period of time, or before the usual, expected, or planned time:
examples: If you finish early you can go home.

near the beginning of (a period of time), or before the usual, expected, or planned time:

meanings.definition: someone who is one of the first people to start using a new product, especially a new piece of technology :
examples: Lucic was an early adopter, buying one of the first iPods in 2001.

meanings.definition: a person who buys a new type of product or service as soon as it is available:
examples: Business people were early adopters of mobile phones.

meanings.definition: a person who gets up or arrives early, or who does something before other people do :
examples: She isn't an early bird by nature, but she's been up before dawn every day for the past month.
Attracted by early season discounts and bargains, 500 early birds lined up at 7 a.m. yesterday to get into the store.
The early bird usually gets the best deal.

meanings.definition: available early in the day:
examples: This is one of my favourite places to get an early-bird breakfast.
They rose at 4 a.m. to catch an early-bird flight to San Francisco.
Many retailers offered early-bird specials to boost sales.

meanings.definition: available at the beginning of a period of time or process:
examples: Early-bird tickets available now are $165 for a three-day pass, which will rise to $195.
Registration to the convention is currently available at an early-bird rate of £135 (until September 1).

meanings.definition: used to describe someone who does something early in the day:

Early-bird voters stand in line outside the polls.
Pick a site away from the trail, so early-bird hikers don't interrupt your morning sleep.

meanings.definition: used to describe someone who does something before most other people:
examples: Emerging-growth companies can offer spectacular returns to early-bird investors who catch them before the crowds arrive.
You may have heard complaints that the game is too easy, and I have to say those early-bird critics have a point.

meanings.definition: a person who gets up or arrives early
available early in the day:
examples: They rose at 4 a.m. Tuesday to catch an early-bird flight to San Francisco.
The store's early-bird special was 50% off everything until 11 a.m.

meanings.definition: used to describe a person who does something early in the day, especially in order to get an advantage such as a cheaper price:
examples: early-bird investor/shopper

meanings.definition: the study of the education of children from about two to seven years of age
the early hours of the morning, between twelve o'clock at night and the time when the sun rises:

meanings.definition: the group of people who begin buying a new product or service after waiting to see if the people who have already bought it are satisfied with it:

meanings.definition: the group of people in a company who are the first to use a new method or system after it has been tested

meanings.definition: happening or involved in, or relating to, the first years of children's education, especially the years up to the age of 5 in the UK education system:

meanings.definition: especially in Britain in the past, the one day in the middle of the week when most shops closed very early in the afternoon
used for describing something that has only recently started to happen or develop:

meanings.definition: used to describe something such as a company or product that is starting to be developed or has only recently been developed:

meanings.definition: used to describe investment in companies or products that are starting to be developed or have only recently been developed:

meanings.definition: a person who usually gets out of bed early/late in the morning:

meanings.definition: to keep or intend something for a particular purpose:

meanings.definition: to intend something for a particular purpose:

meanings.definition: in the US, a legal request that is added to a law to make sure that an amount of money from the US Congress’s budget is spent on a particular project:
examples: Members of the Party used the 111th Congress to request hundreds of earmarks that added more than $1 billion to the federal budget.

meanings.definition: an amount of money from the US Congress’s budget to be spent on a particular project:
examples: A senator obtained an earmark of $1.5 million last year to deal with a beetle that attacks trees, lawns, and crops.

meanings.definition: a characteristic or feature that is typical of a person or thing:
examples: He said the plan had all the earmarks of an economic disaster because it would increase customer costs.

meanings.definition: to keep or plan to use something for a particular purpose:
examples: The money had been earmarked for airport improvements.

a pair of warm pieces of material that cover the ears and that are connected by a curved strip that goes over the head
to receive money as payment for work that you do:
examples: I earn $80,000 a year.

meanings.definition: to get something that you deserve:
examples: It's been a tough six months and I feel I've earned a few weeks off.

meanings.definition: to receive money as payment for work that you do, or to get something that you deserve because of your abilities or actions:
examples: This month’s raise means that I’ll be earning $45,000 a year.
After all the work I’ve done, I’ve earned a vacation.

meanings.definition: to receive money as payment for work that you do:
examples: How much do you earn?
When I started earning, I decided to open a savings account.
A typical manager will earn a salary of at least $69,000.
Brokers earn commission on each sale.
She turned down an advert that would have earned her £1 million.

meanings.definition: to make a particular amount of money from a product or business activity:
examples: His last three films have earned more than $437 million worldwide.
In 1994, BBA earned pretax profit of 84.3 million pounds.
The region earns billions of dollars from tourism.

meanings.definition: to get an amount of money as profit or interest on an investment or loan:
examples: You can buy and sell these unit trusts when you choose, and you earn dividends.
Any spare cash is best put in a savings account where it will earn interest.
Local governments use the fund as a money-market account to earn interest on surplus cash.

meanings.definition: to collect a reward for doing business with a particular company or for a particular activity. You can use these rewards to buy goods or get some other advantage:
examples: Apply now to start earning loyalty points
Organizations can earn carbon credits by registering an energy saving project.

meanings.definition: to do something for which you receive praise and approval:
examples: She has sold millions of records and earned numerous awards and accolades over a 30-year career.
He earned accolades for several successful books.

meanings.definition: to earn the money that you need so that you can pay for food, clothes, and other ordinary needs:
examples: He earns his daily bread as a tourist guide.
She was a poor woman who earned her daily bread by working long hours in a textile factory.

meanings.definition: to get praise or approval for something you have done:
examples: I thought I could score some brownie points with my mother-in-law by offering to cook dinner.
By emphasizing its green credentials the company earns brownie points with consumers.

It's a marketing opportunity. It looks like they're doing something and they get brownie points for it.

meanings.definition: someone or something that earns money:

meanings.definition: a product or business activity that makes money for a person or company:

meanings.definition: serious and determined, especially too serious and unable to find your own actions funny:

meanings.definition: money that someone pays when they sign an agreement in order to show that they will do what the agreement says:

meanings.definition: in a serious and determined way, often without humour:

meanings.definition: determination and seriousness, especially when this is without humour:

a teleconference (= a meeting between people in different places, connected by video, phone, etc.) in which a public company talks about its financial situation:
examples: In an earnings call on Tuesday, the CEO told investment analysts, "The prospects are good for continued growth this year".

→

a measure of the value of a share in the best possible conditions. It is calculated by dividing the expected annual earnings of a share by the present price of a share.
the difference in pay between two jobs with different responsibilities or between employees with different qualifications or experience:
examples: There is a growing earnings differential between high-school and college graduates.

meanings.definition: the difference in pay between two people doing the same job or similar jobs:
examples: Actors are once again angered by the pay differential between the famous and less famous in their profession.

meanings.definition: a statement of the expected profits of a particular company over a particular period:
examples: Analysts issue earnings estimates, giving earnings per share that the analyst believes a particular company will report in its next quarterly statement.

meanings.definition: a measure of the increase in a company's income in a particular period:
examples: Disappointment over slower earnings growth caused the stock price to tumble.

meanings.definition: the use of methods of recording financial information about a company's income that give a false idea of the company's success, which may not be illegal but is considered dishonest:
examples: Some types of earnings management may comply with accounting rules; others cross the line into violations of the law.

meanings.definition: a company's profits over a particular period divided by the number of its shares:

meanings.definition: the amount of money that it is possible for you to make in your work:

meanings.definition: the amount of money that it is possible for a business to make:

meanings.definition: the amount of money that it is possible for a product to make for a business:

meanings.definition: the degree to which a company's accounts accurately show income for that period, for example, by only including real sales made during that period, and not including income that may not be repeated in future:
examples: The market realized that the company's earnings quality was questionable.

meanings.definition: an official statement that gives details of a company's profit or loss for a particular period:

meanings.definition: a statement about a company's profit and loss which has been changed, for example, because mistakes have been found:

meanings.definition: an official statement that gives details of a company's profit or loss for a particular period:

meanings.definition: a document that an employee receives giving details of money they have been paid:

meanings.definition: an earnings report that shows profit or loss that is much higher or lower than was expected:

meanings.definition: a way of measuring financial performance by comparing a company's earnings per share in a particular period with its share price:
examples: The earnings yield has moved more or less in step with long-term bond rates.

meanings.definition: the earnings yield shown as a percentage

meanings.definition: to make or become less severe, difficult, unpleasant, painful, etc.:
examples: To ease the problem of overcrowding, new prisons will be built.
These pills should ease the pain.
After the arrival of the United Nations soldiers, tension in the area began to ease.

meanings.definition: to move or to make something move slowly and carefully in a particular direction or into a particular position:
examples: She eased the key into the lock, anxious not to wake anyone.
I eased myself out of the chair.

meanings.definition: the quality of needing little effort or not being difficult:
examples: She won the 400 metre race with ease.
The doors are extra-wide for ease of access (= so that people can get in without difficulty).

meanings.definition: the state of being comfortable or relaxed, or free from worry or pain:
examples: They live lives of great comfort and ease.
He came into the room and sat down with his usual good-natured ease.

meanings.definition: to make or become less severe, difficult, unpleasant, or painful:
examples: These pills should ease the pain.

meanings.definition: to move something slowly and carefully in a particular direction or into a particular position:
examples: I eased through the crowd to the stage.

meanings.definition: freedom from difficulty, effort, or pain:
examples: She won the match with ease (= without difficulty).
He felt completely at ease (= relaxed and comfortable) with them.

meanings.definition: to make something less severe, difficult, etc. or to become less severe, difficult, etc.:
examples: He made proposals to ease the tax burden on lower earners.
The rise in interest rates may prompt the government to ease fiscal policy again.
the tension/pressure/crisis eases

meanings.definition: to become lower in value:
examples: Interbank interest rates in the domestic money market eased in the week to Nov. 15.

meanings.definition: to move gradually to a different level, or to make something do this:
examples: Freight rates eased upwards.

meanings.definition: the fact that something does not involve difficulty or effort:
examples: We rated the products for ease of use, quality, and price.

meanings.definition: to make someone leave a job or powerful position:

meanings.definition: to stop someone from worrying:
examples: If it will ease your mind, I'll have a word with Charlotte for you.

meanings.definition: to gradually stop or become less:
examples: At last the rain began to ease up.

meanings.definition: to treat someone less severely:
examples: If his father doesn’t ease up on him, he’s going to leave home.

meanings.definition: to gradually stop or become less:
examples: At last the rain began to ease off.

meanings.definition: to start to work less or do things with less energy:
examples: As he got older, he started to ease up a little.

meanings.definition: to start to treat someone less severely:
examples: I wish his supervisor would ease up on him a bit.

meanings.definition: in a way that needs little effort, or that makes something seem easy:

meanings.definition: said when something seems like a good idea but would be difficult to do:

meanings.definition: easy to suggest, but much more difficult to make happen:

meanings.definition: the quality of needing little effort:

meanings.definition: the direction where the sun rises in the morning that is opposite west, or the part of an area or country that is in this direction:

examples: The sound of footsteps echoed around the hall.
Suddenly, the building echoed with the sound of gunfire.

meanings.definition: to repeat details that are similar to, and make you think of, something else:
examples: The design of the church echoes that of St. Paul's Cathedral.
I've heard the prime minister's view echoed throughout the party.

meanings.definition:
plural of 
        
         echo
able to send back an echo (= a sound that reflects off a surface), and therefore showing as a light area in an ultrasound scan (= a medical examination that produces an image using sound waves):
examples: Ultrasonography revealed large, echogenic kidneys.
4 patients had an abnormal anechoic mass and 1 had an abnormal echogenic mass.

meanings.definition: the quality of being able to send back an echo (= a sound that reflects off a surface), and therefore showing as a light area in an ultrasound scan (= a medical examination that produces an image using sound waves):
examples: A liver ultrasound showed areas of increased echogenicity.

meanings.definition: like or related to an echo (= a sound that is heard after it has been reflected off a surface such as a wall or a cliff):
examples: I listened to the strange echoic noises of the empty night-time station.
The album is full of echoic hymn-like melodies.

meanings.definition: (of a word) sounding similar to the noise the word refers to:
examples: Echoic words like "pop" and "bang" imitate the sound of what they are describing.
The nightingale's name is not imitative of its cry, although the ending "-gale" is related to "yell", which is certainly echoic.

meanings.definition: a medical condition in which someone repeats the words that someone else has just said, in a way that they cannot control:
examples: The automatic repetition of words known as echolalia is common in autism.

meanings.definition: (of animals) to find the way using echolocation (= sound waves):

meanings.definition: a process in which animals, for example bats (= small animals with wings that fly at night), find their way in the dark by producing sound waves that echo (= are heard again) when they are reflected off an object:
examples: Dolphins locate underwater creatures using echolocation.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean: an organization of the United Nations that supports trade and economic growth in Latin America and the Caribbean:

meanings.definition: a small thin cake made of pastry, with cream inside and usually chocolate on top
a medical condition in which a pregnant woman has high blood pressure and experiences convulsions (= sudden uncontrolled movements of the muscles), which is dangerous for the mother and baby:

Eclampsia is a serious condition which requires urgent medical treatment.

meanings.definition: a strong and stylish effect:
examples: She broke onto the music scene with great éclat.

meanings.definition: Methods, beliefs, ideas, etc. that are eclectic combine whatever seem the best or most useful things from many different areas or systems, rather than following a single system:
examples: an eclectic style/approach
an eclectic taste in literature

meanings.definition: consisting of different types, methods, styles, etc.:
examples: It was an eclectic mix of our ethnic foods and traditional Thanksgiving food.

meanings.definition: including many different styles or methods:

meanings.definition: in an eclectic way (= combining things from different systems or areas):
examples: This fun, chic, eclectically designed boutique hotel is located in the fishing village of Treasure Beach.

meanings.definition: the fact of combining things from many different areas or systems:
examples: Another obvious quality of Taiga's work is its stylistic eclecticism.
His music reflects his eclecticism and his songs are a unique mix of soul, reggae, and hip-hop.

meanings.definition: an occasion when the sun disappears from view, either completely or partly, while the moon is moving between it and the earth, or when the moon becomes darker while the shadow of the earth moves over it:
examples: Some people believe that a solar/lunar eclipse affects their relationships, energy levels, and mood.
On Wednesday there will be a total/partial eclipse of the sun.

meanings.definition: a situation in which something becomes less important:
examples: The eclipse of the ruling political party was inevitable.
His remarkable contribution to literature has been too long in eclipse.

meanings.definition: to make an eclipse of the moon or sun:
examples: The moon will be totally eclipsed at 12.10 p.m.

meanings.definition: to make another person or thing seem much less important, good, or famous:
examples: The economy has eclipsed all other issues during this election campaign.

meanings.definition: a period of time when the light from an object in the sky cannot be seen because another object has come between you and it
to become much more important and noticeable than something:
examples: The state of the economy has eclipsed all other issues during the election campaign.

meanings.definition: to become greater in amount or level than something else:
examples: The increased consumer spending from new businesses has already helped shopping, dining, and real estate eclipse oil revenues.
Their stock is up 50% so far this year, as their profit growth is expected to eclipse that of larger companies.

meanings.definition: to become more successful or important than something else:
examples: We have developed a winning formula to eclipse our rivals.
These problems should not be allowed to eclipse the organization's achievements.

meanings.definition: (of an insect) to emerge (= come out of) an egg, or out of a pupal case (= the hard covering in which an adult insect develops):

Eggs that were ready to eclose were placed in glass tubes.

meanings.definition: (of an insect) the act of coming out of an egg, or out of a pupal case (= the hard covering in which an adult insect develops):
examples: After adult eclosion, the sex of each insect was recorded.
Immediately after egg eclosion, the newly hatched larvae start feeding.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation: a medical treatment in which blood is pumped out of the body into a machine that temporarily does the work of the heart and lungs by removing carbon dioxide from the blood and adding oxygen before it is pumped back into the body:
examples: ECMO was maintained for two days in order to reduce the workload of the heart.
Heart failure patients awaiting transplants can be kept alive on an ECMO machine.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Electronic Communications Network: a computer system for buying and selling shares, that provides information about orders to buy or sell, and allows them to be carried out:
examples: Trading with an ECN offers many benefits, such as the ability to trade after-hours and anonymously.

meanings.definition: a product that is designed to protect the environment:
examples: eco products such as wind turbines and solar panels

meanings.definition: a town consisting of houses that are built in a way that is designed to cause less damage than usual to the environment, for example, by using power from sun or wind, not using much electricity, and not producing much carbon dioxide
connected with the environment
abbreviation for Economic Cooperation Organization: an organization with members from Asian and Eurasian countries which aims to encourage trade and investment:
examples: The ECO's main objective is to establish a single market for goods and services, much like the European Union.

meanings.definition: advertising that uses natural materials, electronic methods, or other methods that avoid using a lot of resources that harm the environment:
examples: They use eco-advertising to provide clients with outstanding natural marketing.

meanings.definition: advertising for companies whose business or message relates to protecting the environment:
examples: Here is another company hoping that eco advertising can significantly change perceptions.

meanings.definition: an examination of how the behaviour of a business or group of people affects the environment:
examples: After our eco-audit, we switched to low-energy light bulbs.

meanings.definition: someone whose job is to examine how the behaviour of a business or group of people affects the environment:
examples: The calculations of a home's carbon footprint may seem easy to an eco-auditor.
He works as a home and business eco-auditor.

meanings.definition: a brand name for a bag for carrying things you have bought that can be used many times and does not harm the environment, for example because it is made from natural materials:
examples: Feeling guilty for using a plastic bag while out shopping, I eventually got round to buying an Eco-bag.

meanings.definition: a building that has been made in a way that does not harm the environment, for example because it is made with sustainable materials (= ones that will continue to be available and not all be used up) and uses natural energy for heat, etc.:
examples: Eco-buildings come in many different forms.

meanings.definition: the activity of making buildings that do not harm the environment:
examples: Most of the structures will be built by volunteers who want to learn the art of eco-building.

meanings.definition: a meeting to discuss a company's or organization's plans to protect the environment:
examples: Staff from all regions discussed how to make the business more environmentally friendly at an eco-conference yesterday.

meanings.definition: a conference (= large formal meeting) that is organized in a way that has little or no damaging effect on the environment:
examples: The company is planning to plant a tree for every delegate who attends the eco-conference to help offset its environmental impact.

meanings.definition: renewable energy  :
examples: The British government says it is committed to eco-energy and has signed up to the latest EU generation target for 2020.

meanings.definition:
an 
        
         ecological footprint
not harmful to the environment, or trying to help the environment:
examples: The building has many features that make it more eco-friendly as well as reducing heating costs.

eco-friendly detergent

meanings.definition: designed to have little or no damaging effect on the environment:
examples: an eco-friendly product/company/organization

meanings.definition: an official symbol that shows that a product has been designed to do less harm to the environment than similar products
the act or system of adding an eco-label to a product (= a symbol showing whether a product causes harm to the environment):

meanings.definition: the act or system of adding an eco-label to a product (= a symbol showing whether a product causes harm to the environment):
examples: Another problem with eco-labelling is that certification is voluntary.

meanings.definition: marketing for a product that emphasizes the fact that it does not harm the environment:
examples: Eco-marketing is not just about adding a green recycle image to your website.

meanings.definition: a person who argues against and tries to stop activities that damage the environment
destruction of the natural environment of an area, or very great damage to it:

meanings.definition: a place for people to stay on holiday that is designed not to harm the natural environment where it has been built:
examples: On the eight-day trip you'll stay in an ecolodge in the rainforest.

meanings.definition: relating to ecology or the environment:
examples: The destruction of the rain forests is an ecological disaster.

meanings.definition: relating to ecology (= the relationship between living things and their environment) or the environment:
examples: The industry has created thousands of jobs in rural communities but environmentalists believe this has been an ecological disaster.

meanings.definition: the amount of the earth's energy that someone or something uses:
examples: I'm trying to reduce my ecological footprint by cycling more and driving less.

meanings.definition: a person who studies the natural relationships between the air, land, water, animals, plants, etc.
a person who studies the relationship between living things and their environment
the relationships between the air, land, water, animals, plants, etc., usually of a particular area, or the scientific study of this:
examples: The oil spill caused terrible damage to the fragile ecology of the coast.
She hopes to study ecology at college.

meanings.definition: the relationship of living things to their environment and to each other, or the scientific study of this:

meanings.definition: the relationship between living things and their environment:

meanings.definition: the relationship between the people working within a company or the relationship between different companies working together:

econometric studies of the relationship between unemployment and inflation

meanings.definition: of or relating to econometrics:
examples: Most econometric models suggest that the immediate impact of higher oil prices tends to be relatively small.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to the testing of the performance of economies and economic theories using mathematical methods:

We need to show econometrically which factors have a statistically significant impact on savings.

meanings.definition: someone who works with or studies econometrics:

meanings.definition: the testing of the performance of economies and economic theories using mathematical methods
the part of economics that uses mathematics and statistics (= the study of the number of times something happens or is present) to understand financial and economic information:
examples: Bank research is still too often based on complex econometrics, rather than talking to poor people in poor countries.

meanings.definition: relating to trade, industry, or money:
examples: The country has been in a very poor economic state ever since the decline of its two major industries.

meanings.definition: making a profit, or likely to make a profit:

meanings.definition: relating to trade, industry, and money:

meanings.definition: relating to trade, industry, and money:

meanings.definition: making a profit, or likely to make a profit:
examples: We had to close our London office - with the rent so high it just wasn't economic.

meanings.definition: not using a lot of money, fuel, etc.:
examples: It's often more economic to buy office supplies in bulk.

meanings.definition: a situation in which someone harms another person in a close relationship using money or property, for example by controlling how they are able to get or spend money, or preventing them being able to buy things that they need:
examples: With economic abuse, money becomes a way to control the victim.

meanings.definition: the actions and processes involved in producing, buying, and selling products and services:

meanings.definition: a study of the finances of a business, done especially in order to save money and reduce waste:
examples: Direct and indirect costs are traditionally included in an economic analysis.

meanings.definition:
→

the cost in money, time, and other resources needed in order to do something or make something:

meanings.definition: a repeated series of periods of growth in business activity followed by periods of recession (= times when there is less economic success and business is bad):
examples: Economic orthodoxy is that monetary policy is the best tool for managing the economic cycle.
We will probably need to see a full economic cycle to be certain these funds can successfully weather all market conditions.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         business cycle
the process of removing government controls or rules from a country's economy or from a particular industry:
examples: He hoped to transform the country into a global showcase for the benefits of economic deregulation.

meanings.definition: the process in which an economy grows or changes and becomes more advanced, especially when both economic and social conditions are improved:
examples: They're trying to promote economic development in the border areas.

an economic development/initiative/strategy.
Energy plays a key role in Colorado's economic development strategy.

meanings.definition: the condition of a country's economy and the way that it influences how effectively businesses can work, how much profit they can make, etc.:
examples: The ability to meet obligations requires an advantageous economic environment.

meanings.definition: the degree to which the economic advantages of something to be made, done, or achieved are greater than the economic costs:
examples: The state commissioned a report on the economic feasibility of a single-payer health system.
an economic feasibility study

meanings.definition: a statement of what is judged likely to happen in the future of a particular economy:
examples: The Chancellor has stuck to optimistic economic forecasts.
Revenue estimates in the proposed budget were developed using a national economic forecast with a projected real gross domestic product growth annual rate below 2%.

meanings.definition: a person or organization that makes economic forecasts:
examples: In a survey of top economic forecasters, 91% said they expected the economy to grow at an annual rate of between 2% to 5% in the second half of this year.

meanings.definition: the activity of making economic forecasts:
examples: As with all economic forecasting, there is no magic formula that automatically calculates the impact of changes in oil prices.
an economic forecasting firm

meanings.definition: the way in which economic activity and the money created by it are distributed in a particular country or in the world:
examples: Air transport transformed the economic geography of the world.

meanings.definition: the study of where economic activity occurs and why:
examples: The two main branches of economic geography raise questions that are entirely familiar to geographers.

meanings.definition: a product or service that a person or organization is willing to pay for:
examples: Economic goods are typically exchanged through a market.

meanings.definition: an increase in the economy of a country or an area, especially of the value of goods and services the country or area produces:
examples: We need to maintain low inflation and at the same time create an environment that is conducive to economic growth.
The administration wants to promote economic growth and spur more savings and investment.

meanings.definition: difficulty caused by having too little money or too few resources:
examples: The government is stepping in, recognizing their economic hardship, and paying the interest on their loan for that period.
The economic hardships she observed at that time were similar to some of what she saw today.

meanings.definition: a situation in which something, such as a payment on a loan, is delayed because someone has too little money or too few resources at the present time
the history of economic development in a country or different parts of the world:
examples: European colonization deeply affected the economic history of many African nations.

meanings.definition: a financial effect that something, especially something new, has on a situation or person:
examples: Increased tourism has had a significant economic impact on the resort community.
It may be difficult to judge the economic impact of the new maximum-security prison.

meanings.definition: a situation in which one country has a lot of economic power or influence over others:
examples: Many rants on economic imperialism have come from those who distrust the capitalist system.

meanings.definition: something, often money or a prize, offered to make someone behave in a particular way:
examples: The state has an economic incentive program that provides an additional incentive to companies that already are located and employ workers here and are considering expansion.

meanings.definition: information that shows how well or badly an economy is doing:
examples: A few national economic indicators suggest the economy had begun to strengthen.
He compiles an index of local leading economic indicators that has shown a weakening economy for more than a year.

meanings.definition: a company or an organization that deals with money or with managing the distribution of money, goods, and services in an economy. Banks, government organizations, and investment funds are all economic institutions:
examples: Technical assistance will be needed to rebuild essential economic institutions after this upheaval.

meanings.definition: a process in which the economies of different countries become more connected because government rules, taxes, limits, etc. are removed from trade between those countries:
examples: Asian economic integration would create a formidable competitor, but also a huge stimulus to global growth, trade and investment.

meanings.definition: the length of time that an asset is expected to continue to be useful, or how long the asset can be used before repairing it becomes more expensive than replacing it:
examples: Technological assets become obsolete so fast that their economic life is often shortened.

meanings.definition: a person who leaves their home country to live in another country with better working or living conditions
someone who goes to live in another country because it is possible to earn more money or to have a better standard of living there than in their own country:
examples: The new law will allow some 200,000 immigrants - both highly skilled economic migrants and asylum seekers - to enter the country each year.

meanings.definition: one particular way of organizing an economy:
examples: Going forward, the American economic model should not be abandoned, as some advocate.

meanings.definition: a theory used for calculating the effect of something on an economy:
examples: Ernst & Young's ITEM Club, which uses the Treasury's economic model, says UK GDP will grow by 3.5% this year.

meanings.definition: a calculation of the degree to which spending on one product or service causes people and organizations to spend on other things as a result:
examples: There's an economic multiplier at work because all of those people who are now employed at the new factory are spending money in the community.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a country tries to protect its own economy by reducing the number of imports and investments from other countries:
examples: The US was seen as the main opponent of protectionism and economic nationalism.

meanings.definition: the amount of goods ordered by a company at one time when this has been calculated to keep costs, for example, of storing and transporting goods, as low as possible
a basic principle that describes how an economy works or should work:
examples: A new economic paradigm has emerged with the growth of e-commerce.

meanings.definition: decisions and activities by a government that are aimed at making a country's economy grow and be successful:
examples: an economic planning agency/minister

meanings.definition: the activity of deciding the best way of using money, labour, and other resources in order to make a business or industry successful:
examples: Social research is a prerequisite to economic planning in the public health sector.

meanings.definition: a country that has a lot of importance because it can produce, buy, and sell a lot of products or services:
examples: China is a very important economic power.

meanings.definition: the fact of having a lot of influence because of being able to produce, buy, or sell a lot:
examples: It is clear that economic power is the prime moving force in today's world.

meanings.definition: actions taken by a country or organization against the economy of another country, such as refusing to trade with it, in order to force it to obey a law or a set of rules:
examples: The UN announced new economic sanctions against countries abusing human rights.

call/push/press for economic sanctions
tough/strict/stiff economic sanctions

meanings.definition: actions by a government, bank, etc. that are intended to encourage activity and growth in the economy, for example, in order to avoid a recession:
examples: They are pushing for $5 billion in spending for roads and bridges, largely as an economic stimulus.
The US House of Representatives approved an economic stimulus package including tax rebates to encourage consumer spending.

meanings.definition: the way in which an economy works, for example, the way it makes money and uses goods and labour:
examples: The WTO is at the centre of the global economic system.

meanings.definition: the ideas and priniciples that aim to describe how economies work:
examples: Basic economic theory states that if wages are too high, economic growth will suffer.

meanings.definition: a particular idea or principle that aims to describe how an economy works:
examples: He disagreed with supply-side economic theories.

meanings.definition: a country whose economy has grown and become successful very quickly:
examples: Poland became one of central Europe's economic tigers, with an annual growth rate of 5 to 7%.

meanings.definition: the value of an asset calculated according to its ability to produce income in the future:
examples: Recent developments have substantially increased the economic value of the merger proposal.

meanings.definition: the amount by which the profit made by a company is bigger than the capital it has invested to make that profit. Economic value added is considered to be a way of measuring how successful a company is.
using as little of something as possible; wasting nothing or very little:
examples: People were urged to be economical with water as a drought was declared.
He was typically cautious and economical with his words (= he used few words).
What's the most economical way of heating this building?
Loft insulation keeps warmth inside the house, making it more comfortable and more economical to run.
As well as being powerful, the engine is impressively economical and clean.
There's increasing demand for cars that are more economical on fuel.

meanings.definition: making a profit, or likely to make a profit:
examples: He claims that rising gas prices make the pipeline project economical.
The price of corn needs to be low in order for biofuel production to be economical.

meanings.definition: relating to the economy, or to trade, industry, or money:
examples: New business means economical and social progress.
In the current economical climate, many businesses have shut down for good.

meanings.definition: not using a lot of money, energy, etc.:
examples: With rents so high, it wasn’t economical to continue to live in the city.

meanings.definition: not using a lot of fuel, money, space, etc.:
examples: What's the most economical way of heating this building?
Most printer software lets you fit four pictures per sheet to make the most economical use of the space available.
There's increasing demand for cars which are more economical on fuel.
It's a shame this industry could not be a bit more economical with the costs.

meanings.definition: avoiding stating the true facts about a situation, or lying about it:
examples: Anyone who tells you that this is a simple process is being economical with the truth.
He is being economical with the truth when he claims this was a joke.
Politicians who claim any different are being economical with the truth.
Journalists are often economical with the truth, but he is very honest.
Everyone can be economical with the truth sometimes if it suits them to do so.

meanings.definition: using little money, time, etc.:
examples: As a student she lived very economically, rarely going out and buying very few clothes.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to a country's trade, industry, and money:
examples: Economically, the country has been improving steadily these past ten years.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to a country's trade, industry, and money:
examples: Economically the country has been improving steadily these past ten years.
The neighborhood is one of Lexington's most economically depressed areas.
economically powerful/prosperous/developed

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to making a profit:
examples: Is the service economically viable for providers?
The project is no longer economically justified.
What can we do to dramatically reduce emissions in an economically sustainable way?

meanings.definition: in a way that does not use a lot of fuel, money, space, etc.:
examples: We need to deliver services much more economically.

meanings.definition: the way in which trade, industry, or money is organized, or the study of this:
examples: Their ideas sound fine in principle, but they haven't worked out the economics behind the policies.
She's in her third year of studying economics at York University.

meanings.definition: the scientific study of the system by which a country’s wealth is made and used
the study of the way in which economies work, for example, the way in which they make money and produce and distribute goods and services:
examples: One of the laws of economics is that today's shortage is tomorrow's glut.
He has a degree in economics.
She's economics professor/professor of economics at the University of Berkeley.

meanings.definition: business activities considered from a financial point of view, and whether or not products or services are likely to make a profit:
examples: Energy policy must be built on economics if it is to succeed.
We are trying to change the economics of the digital business to let consumers benefit.

meanings.definition: the reduction of production costs that is a result of making and selling goods in large quantities, for example, the ability to buy large amounts of materials at reduced prices:
examples: Big public companies frequently enjoy economies of scale and dominant market shares.
Selling to a global market would enable us to achieve huge economies of scale.

meanings.definition: the reduction of costs that is the result of sharing resources, processes, and skills in producing a larger range of products:
examples: Economies of scope only benefit companies who are also willing to manage the risk of added complexity.

meanings.definition: a person who studies or has a special knowledge of economics
a person who studies or has a special knowledge of economics
someone whose work is to study the way in which economies work, or who studies developments within a particular economy:
examples: Mr Toledo is a former World Bank economist.
Leading economists have warned of the dangers that could arise from 'globalized' inflation.

meanings.definition: the name of a newspaper produced every week in London, which publishes international politics and business news and opinion:

meanings.definition: to try to save money by reducing the amount that you are spending:

meanings.definition: to intentionally reduce what you are spending or using:
examples: You could economize on food by not eating in restaurants all the time.

meanings.definition: to make an effort to save money, time, resources, etc.:
examples: Shoppers are going for less expensive food in an effort to economize.

meanings.definition: an advantage over other people:

meanings.definition: an extreme or not typical example of something, that should not be considered when forming an opinion about it:

meanings.definition: to achieve something and cause it to happen:

meanings.definition: successful or achieving the results that you want:
examples: The lighting for the production made a very effective use of shadow.

meanings.definition: (used about a treatment or drug) working well when used by people in general, as opposed to only under carefully controlled scientific testing conditions:
examples: How effective a drug is depends on many factors, including how consistently the patient follows the instructions for taking it.
It's an extremely effective cure for a headache.

meanings.definition: in fact, although not officially:
examples: Although she's not officially our boss, she's in effective control of the office.

meanings.definition: If a law or rule becomes effective, it starts to be used:
examples: The new laws will become effective next month.

meanings.definition: producing the intended results, or (of a person) skilled or able to do something well:
examples: an effective policy/strategy
We’ve found that giving away samples of our product is the most effective way to promote it.
She’s an effective administrator and knows how to get things done.

meanings.definition: (of rules or laws) in official or legal use:
examples: The law becomes effective next month.

meanings.definition: successful in achieving the result that you want:
examples: You need a workable, effective strategy for developing your business.

The consumer council must have clear duties and strong powers if it is to be effective.

meanings.definition: having started to operate or be used:
examples: The new Investment Management Agreements became effective on 1st November.

meanings.definition: used to describe what is actually true, although it may not be intended or stated:
examples: The remainder of the stock is owned by a consortium of banks which are in effective control of the hotel.

meanings.definition: a calculation of the age of a building or other asset, based on its physical condition at a particular time, rather than on the actual time since it was built or made:
examples: A property that has been well maintained will generally have an effective age somewhat lower than its actual age.

meanings.definition: the actual rate of interest paid or charged over one year:
examples: The effective annual rate is the amount of interest charged on an overdraft, not including any fees or charges.

meanings.definition: the actual amount of work a system, organization, etc. can do:
examples: Computer-aided design has already helped us quadruple effective capacity for one of our product ranges.

meanings.definition: the date when an agreement starts to operate, or when something is recorded as being bought or sold:
examples: Payment of severance pay will commence as soon as practicable after the effective date.

meanings.definition: a way of measuring the value of a country's currency in relation to the currency of other countries that it trades with:
examples: The euro's effective exchange rate has remained unchanged compared with the level at the end of August.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         economic life  :
examples: A depreciating asset is an asset that has a limited effective life, and that can reasonably be expected to decline in value over the time that it is used.

meanings.definition: an actual rate after everything has been considered, rather than a rate that is planned, offered, etc.:
examples: Small businesses should benefit from a reduction in the effective rate of capital-gains tax.

meanings.definition: the percentage of people in the particular group that you are trying to reach (= the target group) who see or hear an advertisement during a particular period:
examples: High-bandwidth internet access can extend the effective reach of your product or service.

meanings.definition: the actual amount of tax paid as a percentage of taxable income or profit:
examples: The company's effective tax rate was 36.6% in the last fiscal year.

meanings.definition: the total amount earned on an investment, including money from investing the interest payments:
examples: If one allows for share buybacks, the effective yield on American equities is around 2.7%.

meanings.definition: in a way that is successful and achieves what you want:
examples: The tablets work more effectively if you take a hot drink after them.

meanings.definition: used when you describe what the real result of a situation is:
examples: His wife left him when the children were small, so he effectively brought up the family himself.

meanings.definition: in a way that is successful and produces the intended results:
examples: Though barely winning election, he governed effectively and was reelected.

meanings.definition: Effectively also means having as a certain result in reality, though not in theory:
examples: If she loses this match, she’s effectively eliminated from the tournament.

meanings.definition: in a way that successfully achieves the result that you want:
examples: Staff must be given enough training and development to be able to do their jobs effectively.

meanings.definition: used when you are describing what is actually true, although it may not be intended or stated:
examples: Whoever owns those shares, effectively controls the company.

meanings.definition: the degree to which something is effective:
examples: The study will review the effectiveness of reading and mathematics software products.

meanings.definition: how well a particular treatment or drug works when people are using it, as opposed to how well it works under carefully controlled scientific testing conditions:
examples: There are doubts about the effectiveness of the new drug in treating the disease.
Once the vaccine is widely available we will know more about its effectiveness.
An effectiveness study asks “Does the treatment approach work in the real world?”

meanings.definition: the ability to be successful and produce the intended results:
examples: The drug’s effectiveness is doubtful.

meanings.definition: the quality of being successful in achieving what is wanted:
examples: The effectiveness of ads like this lies in their simplicity.

meanings.definition: a body part or cell that reacts to a stimulus in a particular way, or a cell or substance in the body that produces an effect:

meanings.definition: cheques, etc. that have been put into an account by a customer but not yet cleared (= successfully paid) by the bank:

meanings.definition: lighting, sounds, and objects that are specially produced for the stage or a film and are intended to make something that does not exist seem real:

meanings.definition: a person's possessions, especially after their death:

meanings.definition: effective and successful:

meanings.definition: successful in producing the intended results:

meanings.definition: in an effective and successful way:

meanings.definition: to do something or make something happen:

meanings.definition: able to produce the intended result:
examples: We believe that educational or counselling schemes are a more efficacious way of dealing with this problem than harsh sanctions.

meanings.definition: (used about a treatment or drug) working well under carefully controlled scientific testing conditions:
examples: Two versions of the vaccine have been shown in trials to be between 90% and 95% efficacious.

meanings.definition: in a way that is able to produce the intended result:
examples: These politicians are interested in learning how to govern more efficaciously.

meanings.definition: (used about a treatment or a drug) in a way that works well under controlled scientific testing conditions:
examples: It might be possible to use the two drugs in combination efficaciously.

meanings.definition: the ability, especially of a medicine or a method of achieving something, to produce the intended result:
examples: The efficacity of the new regulations must now be examined.

meanings.definition: how well a particular treatment or drug works under controlled scientific testing conditions:
examples: This study evaluates the efficacity and speed of action of the drug.

meanings.definition: the ability of something to produce the intended result:
examples: The study is a serious attempt to understand the efficacy of cash incentives as a way of promoting learning.

meanings.definition: how well a particular treatment or drug works under carefully controlled scientific testing conditions:
examples: The clinical report shows results of almost 95% efficacy for the vaccine.

meanings.definition: the quality of being effective; effectiveness:
examples: The drug's efficacy has been questioned by consumer advocates.

meanings.definition: the quality of achieving the largest amount of useful work using as little energy, fuel, effort, etc. as possible:
examples: Families and business need to take steps to maximize energy efficiency.

meanings.definition: the quality of working well in an organized way, without wasting time or energy:
examples: She gets through her work with speed and efficiency.

meanings.definition: something that is done to avoid wasting time, energy, or money:

meanings.definition: the relationship between the amount of energy put into a machine or process, and the amount of useful work that it produces:

meanings.definition:
an

the condition or fact of producing the results you want without waste, or a particular way in which this is done:
examples: The use of high-speed machinery improved the efficiency of the factory.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a person, company, factory, etc. uses resources such as time, materials, or labour well, without wasting any:

business/economic/operational efficiency

improved/increased/greater efficiency
efficiency gains/improvements/savings

meanings.definition: a situation in which a person, system, or machine works well and quickly:
examples: We are looking at ways to increase the efficiency of our advertising.

meanings.definition: the difference between the amount of energy that is put into a machine in the form of fuel, effort, etc., and the amount that comes out of it:
examples: Burning wood on an open fire has efficiencies of only 15-20% compared to wood burning stoves, chip and pellet boilers with efficiencies of up to 80-90% .

meanings.definition: a small apartment intended for one person, with a combined living and sleeping space and small kitchen area:

meanings.definition: a hotel room that has a small kitchen area:

meanings.definition: working or operating quickly and effectively in an organized way:

meanings.definition: working in a way that does not waste a resource (= something valuable such as fuel, water, or money):
examples: Modern-day car engines are much more efficient.
Try to replace your lightbulbs with more efficient bulbs.

meanings.definition: working or operating in a way that gets the results you want without any waste:

meanings.definition: using resources such as time, materials, or energy well without wasting any:

meanings.definition: working well and quickly:

meanings.definition: systems, especially in the food industry, for producing exactly what customers want and making the goods available in the quickest and cheapest ways:

meanings.definition: a market where all the important information is available to everybody involved at the same time, and prices change immediately according to this information:

meanings.definition: working or operating in an organized, quick, and effective way:

meanings.definition: physical or mental activity needed to achieve something:

meanings.definition: physical or mental activity needed to achieve something, or an attempt to do something:

meanings.definition: physical or mental activity needed to achieve something, or energy used to do something:

         elicit
to get or produce something, especially information or a reaction:
examples: Have you managed to elicit a response from them yet?
The questionnaire was intended to elicit information on eating habits.
They were able to elicit the support of the public.

meanings.definition: to get a student to provide or remember a fact, response, etc. rather than telling them the answer:
examples: The teacher elicits definitions from the students.
In this teaching practice, teachers elicit and build on their students' mathematical insights.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         elicit
to get or produce something, especially information or a reaction:
examples: Have you managed to elicit a response from them yet?
The questionnaire was intended to elicit information on eating habits.
They were able to elicit the support of the public.

meanings.definition: to get a student to provide or remember a fact, response, etc. rather than telling them the answer:
examples: The teacher elicits definitions from the students.
In this teaching practice, teachers elicit and build on their students' mathematical insights.

meanings.definition: to join different things together as if they are the same; to become joined in this way:
examples: For some people, "classy" and "classic" have become elided.
One character elides into another because they all speak with the same infuriating voice.

meanings.definition: to ignore a difference between things:
examples: By eliding the distinction, you are being sloppy and weakening your argument.
He attempts to elide the boundaries between painting and sculpture.

meanings.definition: to not pronounce a particular sound in a word:
examples: The "t" of "acts" is often elided if someone is speaking quickly.
She drops g's, elides r's and, in general, sounds streetwise and tough.

meanings.definition: the fact of having the necessary qualities or satisfying the necessary conditions:
examples: I'll have to check her eligibility to take part.
The eligibility rules prevent under-18s being in the team.
our eligibility for government funding

meanings.definition: the fact of being allowed to do or receive something because you satisfy certain conditions:
examples: The poverty level is the official measure used to decide eligibility for federal health, housing, nutrition, and child care benefits.

meanings.definition: having the necessary qualities or satisfying the necessary conditions:
examples: Are you eligible for early retirement/maternity leave?
You might be eligible for a grant.
Only people over 18 are eligible to vote.

meanings.definition: An eligible person is not married and is thought to be a suitable future marriage partner, especially because they are rich and attractive:
examples: I can think of several eligible bachelors of my acquaintance.

meanings.definition: having the necessary qualities or fulfilling the necessary conditions:
examples: an eligible voter
You have to be employed six months to be eligible for medical benefits.

meanings.definition: If you refer to a man or a woman as eligible, you mean the man or woman is not married and is desirable as a marriage partner:
examples: The magazine listed 50 of the world’s most eligible bachelors.

meanings.definition: allowed to do or receive something because you satisfy certain conditions:
examples: The company will offer its 104,000 eligible employees a stock option scheme this year.
Nearly two-thirds of the company's current employees will be eligible to retire within five years.
Of 9,475 students, 1,323 were eligible for a scholarship.

meanings.definition: in the UK, a bank that is approved by the Bank of England to accept particular bills of exchange (= documents ordering payment for goods or services), which the Bank of England has agreed to buy immediately:
examples: Most of the major banks that operate in the City of London are on the list of eligible banks maintained by the Bank of England.

meanings.definition: in the UK, a bill of exchange (= document ordering payment for goods or services) that a bank approved by the Bank of England has accepted, and which the Bank of England has agreed to buy immediately:
examples: Eligible bills are virtually risk free since the Bank guarantees to buy all that are offered.

meanings.definition: a player on the offence of an American football team who is allowed to catch a ball thrown by the quarterback:
examples: The player entered the game and was announced by the official as an eligible receiver.
The offensive lineman was not an eligible receiver, so the pass that was thrown to him was not legal.

meanings.definition: in a way that satifies the necessary conditions or has the necessary qualities:
examples: Should athletes be questioned before they can eligibly compete?
Any land that was not eligibly situated for business was abandoned.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to someone who is thought to be suitable as a marriage partner:
examples: They would like to see their daughter eligibly married.

meanings.definition: to remove or take away someone or something:
examples: A move towards healthy eating could help eliminate heart disease.
We eliminated the possibility that it could have been an accident.
The police eliminated him from their enquiries.

meanings.definition: to defeat someone so that they cannot continue in a competition:
examples: He was eliminated in the third round of the competition.

meanings.definition: to murder someone:
examples: A police officer was accused of helping a drug gang eliminate rivals.

meanings.definition: to remove or take away something:
examples: You can never totally eliminate the possibility of human error.

meanings.definition: to completely remove something that is not wanted or needed:
examples: The problem we confront today is there is no one thing that can eliminate our dependency on petroleum.
The UK hopes other countries will support its proposals to eliminate debt owed by the poorest African states to international institutions.

meanings.definition: a chemical reaction in which a substance separates from a molecule
a competition in which only the winners of each stage play in the next stage, until one competitor or team is the final winner
a part of a competition in any game or sport where one person or team plays against another to decide which of them will continue to the next stage and which will be removed from the competition
the fact of not pronouncing a particular sound in a word
the richest, most powerful, best-educated, or best-trained group in a society:
examples: the country's educated elite
a member of the elite
A powerful and corrupt elite has bled this country dry.

meanings.definition: belonging to the richest, most powerful, best-educated, or best-trained group in a society:
examples: Elite troops were airlifted to the trouble zone.

meanings.definition: those people or organizations that are considered the best or most powerful compared to others of a similar type
the richest, most powerful, best educated, or best trained people in a particular group or society:
examples: the corporate/financial/media elite

meanings.definition: the belief that some things are only for a few people who have special qualities or abilities :
examples: The accusation of elitism seems unfair as the festival presents a wide range of music, with something to please everyone.
The plan, which includes banning skateboards from the park, has drawn charges of elitism.

meanings.definition: organized for the good of a few people who have special interests or abilities:
examples: Many remember sport at school as elitist, focusing only on those who were good at it.

meanings.definition: someone who believes that some things should be controlled or owned only by the richest or best educated people:
examples: They were elitists who had a contempt for popular politics.

meanings.definition: characteristic of the elite, and esp. not caring about the interests or values of ordinary people:
examples: He denounced the plan as impracticable and elitist.

meanings.definition: a substance, usually a liquid, with a magical power to cure, improve, or preserve something:
examples: It's yet another health product claiming to be the elixir of life/youth (= something to make you live longer/stay young).

meanings.definition: from or relating to the period of British history during the rule of Queen Elizabeth I (1558-1603):
examples: This beautiful Elizabethan manor house has delighted visitors for centuries.
English literature, art, architecture, and music flourished in the Elizabethan age of the late sixteenth century.

meanings.definition: from or relating to the period of British history during the rule of Queen Elizabeth II (1952-2022):
examples: Elizabeth II represented the dawn of a new Elizabethan era.
The second Elizabethan Age had come to a close.

meanings.definition: a person living during the period when Elizabeth I was queen of England (1558-1603):
examples: Sir Francis Drake was a famous Elizabethan.
Elizabethans rarely cleaned their teeth but instead gargled with sugar water to sweeten the breath.

meanings.definition: a large deer with brownish-red fur and large antlers (= horns like branches) that lives in the forests of North America

a 
        
         moose
a type of large deer with large, flat horns
the theory that stock market prices move up and down in a regular way, making it possible for investors to know which direction they will move before it happens:
examples: Prechter is a pioneer of Elliott Wave Theory, a statistical analysis tool that is used to predict, among other things, the direction of markets.

meanings.definition: a regular oval shape
a curve in the shape of an oval

plural of 
        
         ellipsis   specialized
a situation in which words are left out of a sentence but the sentence can still be understood:
examples: An example of ellipsis is "What percentage was left?" "20." (= 20 percent)

meanings.definition: three dots in a printed text that show where one or more words have been intentionally left out
having an oval shape
Elliptical language has parts missing, so that it is sometimes difficult to understand:
examples: His message was written in a deliberately elliptical style.

meanings.definition: shaped like an ellipse
a piece of exercise equipment designed to exercise all of the body's main groups of muscles, using an exercise like fast walking and climbing, using both legs and arms:
examples: She exercises on an elliptical trainer to relieve stress.
I try to work out every day on the elliptical machine at my gym.
The gym is well-equipped with treadmills, ellipticals, bikes, and weights.

meanings.definition: in a way that has the shape of an oval:
examples: The new arena will be elliptically shaped.
The planets circle around the sun elliptically and in the same direction as the sun rotates.

meanings.definition: If you speak elliptically, you use language that is not direct and is sometimes difficult to understand:
examples: They talked elliptically, and they didn't like to share their ideas too quickly.
He answered elliptically, "The evidence will show what it shows."

meanings.definition: a large tree that loses its leaves in winter, or the wood from this tree
a large tree valued for the shade it provides, or the hard wood from this tree
a small beetle (= an insect with a hard shell-like back) that moves under the bark (= hard outer covering) of elm trees, bringing a disease that often kills them :
examples: A tiny flying insect called the elm bark beetle spreads the fungus among the elms.
The elm bark beetle feeds and nests in elm wood.

meanings.definition: the art of careful public speaking, using clear pronunciation and good breathing to control the voice:
examples: classes in elocution

meanings.definition: to become or make something become longer, and often thinner:
examples: The cells elongate as they take in water.

meanings.definition: having a shape that is much longer than it is wide:
examples: Acanthoclinus are elongate fishes.

meanings.definition: longer and thinner than usual:
examples: In the photo her face was slightly elongated.

meanings.definition: longer and thinner than usual, as if stretched:
examples: Giacometti’s elongated sculptures of young women

meanings.definition: the process of becoming or making something become longer, and often thinner:
examples: Yoga postures emphasize elongation of the spine and help condition the back.

meanings.definition: to leave home secretly in order to get married without the permission of your parents:
examples: She eloped with an Army officer.

meanings.definition: the act of leaving home secretly in order to get married:

meanings.definition: the quality of delivering a clear, strong message:
examples: She was renowned for her eloquence and beauty.
His wit and eloquence made it a joy to be around him.

meanings.definition: giving a clear, strong message:
examples: She made an eloquent appeal for action.
The pictures were an eloquent reminder of the power of the volcano.

meanings.definition: using language to express ideas or opinions clearly and well, so that they have a strong effect on others:
examples: When required, he could be an eloquent speaker, but preferred talking to small groups.

meanings.definition: Eloquent also means giving a clear, strong message:
examples: The pictures of destruction served as an eloquent reminder of the hurricane’s power.

meanings.definition: in a way that gives a strong, clear message:
examples: He spoke eloquently.

meanings.definition: used after words beginning with any-, every-, no-, and some-, or after how, what, where, who, why, but not which, to mean 'other', 'another', 'different', 'extra':
examples: Everybody else has (= all the other people have) agreed except for you.
If it doesn't work, try something else (= something different).
Let's go before they ask us to visit anyone else (= another person).
It's not my bag. It must be someone else's (= it must belong to another person).
The book isn't here. Where else (= in what other place) should I look?
He came to see you. Why else (= for what other reason) would he come?
After I'd thanked them I didn't know what else (= what other things) to say.

meanings.definition: (after words beginning with any-, every-, no-, and some-, or after how, what, where, who, and why, but not which) other, another, different, additional:
examples: If it doesn’t work, try something else (= something different/another way or thing).
Let’s go before anyone else (= another/an additional person) arrives.
The book isn’t here – where else (= In what other place) should I look?

meanings.definition: at, in, from, or to another place or other places; anywhere or somewhere else:
examples: The report looks at economic growth in Europe and elsewhere.
They couldn't find what they wanted and decided to look elsewhere.

meanings.definition: (at, in, from, or to) another place or other places; anywhere or somewhere else:
examples: It’s hot and sunny on the coast but not elsewhere.

meanings.definition: the state of being difficult to describe, find, achieve, or remember:

meanings.definition: a young eel (= a long, thin, snake-like fish):
examples: Elvers were traditionally eaten by local people and have been netted in the Severn for hundreds of years.

meanings.definition:
plural of
        
         elf
pl of elf
relating to or like an elf (= an imaginary magical being in stories, often like a small person with pointed ears):
examples: A young woman of elvish origin suddenly appeared from the trees.
She is fascinated by Iceland's elvish folklore and spectacular volcanoes.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to or is like an elf (= an imaginary being in stories, often like a small person with pointed ears):
examples: He took off his hat to reveal his almost elvishly sharp features.

meanings.definition: relating to heaven:
examples: the Elysian fields of the next world

meanings.definition: a state of great happiness:
examples: Everything was perfect. She was in Elysium.

meanings.definition: short form of them:
examples: Tell 'em to go away.

meanings.definition: a long dash (= the symbol —), used especially when typing on a computer or in printing to separate parts of a sentence:

meanings.definition: a long dash (= the symbol - ), used especially when typing on a computer or in printing to separate parts of a sentence:

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Education Maintenance Allowance: until 2011, a payment that some young people in the UK between the ages of 16 and 18 received from the government to continue their education after completing the education they must have by law:
examples: Making the continuation of EMA payments contingent on a pupil having met targets has placed great pressure on headteachers.

meanings.definition: very thin and weak, usually because of illness or extreme hunger:

meanings.definition: (esp. of people and animals) very thin and weak, usually because of illness or not eating enough
the state of being very thin and weak, usually because of illness or extreme hunger:
examples: In spite of the fact that the patient eats well, the disease causes emaciation.

meanings.definition: the system for using computers to send messages over the internet:

meanings.definition: a message or document sent using this system:

meanings.definition: to send an email to someone:

meanings.definition: a message sent from one person to another by computer:

meanings.definition: to send something or write to someone using e-mail:

meanings.definition: the system of sending messages over the internet:

meanings.definition: a message or document, or a set of messages or documents, sent using this system:

meanings.definition: the action of appearing by coming out from behind something:

meanings.definition: the action of a plant appearing above the surface of the soil after it has been planted as a seed:
examples: In temperate regions, sunflowers require approximately 11 days from planting to emergence.

meanings.definition: the action of an insect coming out of an egg or cocoon (= a covering that protects the form of an insect that is developing into an adult):
examples: The timing of natural events such as the leafing of trees, the nesting of birds and the emergence of insects are being altered by rising atmospheric temperatures.
The larvae on the cabbage leaf were checked daily until the emergence of adult moths.
Millions of cicadas burst from the ground in one of the largest insect emergences on earth.

meanings.definition: the fact of someone or something coming to the end of a difficult period or experience:
