meanings.definition: the development of particular patterns, properties, or behaviours in parts of complex systems that happen only when the parts of the system interact, and that the parts do not have on their own:
examples: The concept of emergence dates back to Aristotle or even further.
Some types of emergence involve incredible complexity emerging from simple elements, as with the emergence of the universe’s structure in a few microseconds after the Big Bang.
Cases of weak emergence imply that the whole only appears to exceed the sum of its parts.
If a new entity is formed with new, emergent properties, which cannot be understood or predicted based only on an understanding of the entity's components, this is called strong emergence.

meanings.definition: the process of appearing:

meanings.definition: the process of becoming known or developing:

meanings.definition: a dangerous or serious situation, such as an accident, that happens suddenly or unexpectedly and needs immediate action:

meanings.definition: someone whose job is to be one of the first people to arrive to deal with an emergency, especially a paramedic, police officer, or firefighter:

meanings.definition: the part of a hospital where people go when they are ill or injured and need treatment quickly:

meanings.definition: (of a plant) taller than surrounding plants, especially a tree that is taller than other trees in a forest:

meanings.definition: An emergent property of a complex system is one that does not belong to any part of that system on its own, but that happens as a result of parts of the system interacting:
examples: The phenomenon of life as studied in biology is an emergent property of chemistry.

meanings.definition: ways in which employees take part in making decisions, planning, making sure work is done well, etc.:
examples: We attribute our declining injury rate to our employee involvement and ownership in our safety program.
He led a drive to promote more cooperative labor-management relations that encourage employee involvement in decision-making.

meanings.definition: an arrangement in which a company's workers are employees of another company which pays them and manages other costs and responsibilities relating to them:
examples: Employee leasing might help a small business because it shifts many HR responsibilities on to another company.

meanings.definition: a situation in which the employees of a company also own the company or part of it:
examples: One of the features that many investors look for when assessing a company is employee ownership.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         employee involvement

→ 
        
         profit-sharing
a system in which a company pays an employee if someone they know takes a job in the company because of their suggestion:
examples: About 65% of our staff were hired through our employee referral programme.

meanings.definition: the relationship between employees and managers in a company, especially whether the employees feel happy with their working conditions and involved in making decisions:
examples: Companies that have good employee relations and good environmental policies are likely to outperform the broader market over time.

meanings.definition: the department of a company that is responsible for managing employee relations:
examples: director of employee relations/employee relations director

meanings.definition: systems in a company for considering employees' ideas and wishes, especially by having someone to represent employees at managers' meetings:
examples: Employee representation is going to be the driving-force in industrial relations over the next five years.

meanings.definition: someone who speaks officially for an employee or group of employees and represents them, for example at managers' meetings:
examples: It is important that employers, employees and employee representatives know their rights and responsibilities.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         ERISA
the rights that an employee has to be treated in a fair, morally acceptable, or legal way:
examples: There has been an increase in the level of awareness of issues such as health and safety and employee rights.

meanings.definition: the happiness that workers feel when they are satisfied with their job and work conditions, used as one way of measuring a company’s success:
examples: Flexible work schedules have been shown to help with employee satisfaction, retention and performance.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         employee survey
a list showing the dates and times that each employee must work during a particular period:
examples: With this software, managers can quickly create and print weekly employee schedules.

meanings.definition: tests given to people before they are allowed to work for a company, to make certain they can be trusted, have the right personality for the job, etc.:
examples: Employee screening may include reference and credit checks, background checks, and physical/drug testing.
employee screening services/tests/questionnaires

meanings.definition: the part of an organization's website used for finding names, phone numbers, and email addresses of its employees:
examples: The Employee Search page allows you to find contact information for the employees of Dane County.

meanings.definition: a company website where employees can manage information relating to their jobs, personal details, etc.:
examples: Employee self-service (ESS) allows an employee to apply for benefit reimbursements and update personal information.

meanings.definition: a prize, reward, etc. given to employees when they have worked with the same company for a particular number of years:
examples: Employee service awards are presented annually to all full-time regular employees who reach a five-year milestone of service.

meanings.definition: a special agreement that gives an employee the right to buy company shares for a particular price by a particular date, sometimes offered as a reward or instead of pay:
examples: If employee share options are cashed in early, you may lose the income tax break that the options normally carry.

meanings.definition: a benefits plan in which employees own a percentage of their company’s shares, which are bought and managed for them by a trust (= separate organization):
examples: An employee share ownership plan distributes 5% of pre-tax profits among 29,000 eligible employees.

meanings.definition: an attempt by an employee to get extra work, customers, or other advantages from the company they work for or from other employees:
examples: Employee solicitations for charitable purposes must be confined to breaks, lunch periods and other non-working times.

meanings.definition: the position of being legally employed by a particular company:
examples: Temporary office workers who stayed with the agency for more than three months were all offered employee status.

meanings.definition: a special agreement that gives an employee the right to buy company stock for a particular price by a particular date, sometimes offered as a reward or instead of pay:
examples: More and more U.S. companies are granting employee stock options as part of an overall compensation package.

meanings.definition: a benefits plan in which employees own a percentage of their company’s shares, which are bought and managed for them by a trust (= separate organization):
examples: The company’s 12,000 employees continue to control the company through an employee stock ownership program, or ESOP.

meanings.definition: the most useful qualities and skills that an employee has:
examples: By matching employee strengths to organizational goals, managers can boost company loyalty as well as results.

meanings.definition: a set of questions that ask employees for their opinions about their jobs, company, work conditions, etc.:
examples: An employee survey revealed that employee morale was far below industry average.

meanings.definition: the process of officially ending someone’s job at a company:
examples: Employee terminations fall under the responsibility of management and human resources personnel.
Employee termination is often the last step in an unsuccessful attempt to help a worker meet work standards.

meanings.definition: an official statement from an employee which explains what they like about their job or company:
examples: Companies often display employee testimonials on recruitment websites to attract new staff.

meanings.definition: the process of having employees take medical tests, for example to discover if they are taking drugs:
examples: More and more employers are introducing employee testing programs.

meanings.definition: the process of testing employees to see if they have the necessary skills to do a job successfully:
examples: They discussed the use of graphology in employee testing.

meanings.definition: the crime of employees stealing from the company they work for:
examples: Nearly half of all retailers' inventory losses can be attributed to employee theft.

meanings.definition: the rate at which employees leave a company and are replaced by new employees:
examples: Faced with high employee turnover, many restaurants are reluctant to provide health benefits to hourly employees.

meanings.definition: an official message that tells an employee they have done something wrong and must improve their behaviour:
examples: an employee warning notice/letter/form

meanings.definition: a person or organization that employs people:
examples: We need a reference from your former employer.

meanings.definition: a person, company, or organization that pays people to work for them:
examples: The Air Force is the largest employer in this area.

meanings.definition: a person, company, or organization that employs people:
examples: The telecommunications giant currently provides over 2000 jobs and is the largest employer in the region.
Public sector employers account for the majority of jobs in health and education.
a previous/current/new employer
The purpose of a CV is to reveal your accomplishments and qualifications to a potential employer.
Statutory maternity pay is available to those who have worked for their employer for at least 26 weeks.

meanings.definition: a special number given to each business in the US that pays tax on its employees:
examples: Obtaining an employer identification number from the IRS under false pretenses is illegal.

meanings.definition: legal responsibility for any problems, accidents, or mistakes that your employees make while working for you:
examples: Employer liability could become an issue if an employee harasses a third party using the company’s computer and internet services.
employer liability insurance/policy/cover

meanings.definition: a company or organization that is legally responsible for paying employees, including dealing with employee taxes, benefits, insurance, etc.:
examples: As the employer of record, our staffing agency is responsible for issuing payroll checks and submitting local, state, and federal payroll taxes.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that is paid for by the company that you work for, or that you used to work for:
examples: Many employer-paid health benefits are less generous for newer employees than for longer-serving ones.
employer-provided educational assistance
an employer-sponsored retirement plan

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         employer-paid

→ 
        
         employer-paid
an organization that supports companies and employers and protects their rights:
examples: The Government's review on disability rights includes a survey of employers’ organisations, especially those representing small firms.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         employ
to have someone work or do a job for you and pay them for it:
examples: How many people does your company employ?
Can't we employ someone as an assistant to help with all this paperwork?
We've employed a market researcher to find out what people really want from a cable TV system.
More people are now employed in service industries than in manufacturing.

meanings.definition: to use something:
examples: Sophisticated statistical analysis was employed to obtain these results.

meanings.definition: the fact of someone being paid to work for a company or organization:
examples: Employment levels are unlikely to rise significantly before the end of next year.
How long have you been looking for employment?

meanings.definition: use:
examples: How can you justify the employment of capital punishment?

meanings.definition: the use of something for a particular purpose:
examples: She studied advertisers’ employment of images in food ads.

meanings.definition: work, esp. for someone else, for which you are paid, or a period of work:
examples: After leaving Pearson, it took Friedman months to find new employment.

meanings.definition: work that you are paid to do for a particular company or organization:
examples: If you are unemployed but you are actively seeking employment, you may qualify for benefits.
Almost half of the participants gained employment after completing the training program.
These attractions provide employment for local people and create business for local shops and cafes.
Today the terminal offers employment to around 500 people.
casual/full-time/part-time employment
seasonal/temporary employment
permanent/continuous employment
Many rural workers have moved to the cities to seek better employment opportunities and improved living conditions.
Under the terms of her employment contract she is entitled to five weeks paid vacation per year.

meanings.definition: the number of people who have jobs, or the ability to provide jobs to other people:
examples: An unemployment rate below 5% is considered full employment.
Glasgow had economic growth above the UK average and employment rising faster than anywhere outside London.
The state reported employment growth of 3.1% during the past year, with the creation of 438,000 non-farm jobs.
The dollar plunged against the euro, despite Friday's strong employment figures.
Politicians hope to boost employment by introducing a new tax credit for employers.

meanings.definition: a business that helps people to find suitable jobs or companies to find suitable employees
a business that finds jobs for people and finds people who suit particular jobs
a business that is paid to find suitable workers for other companies and organizations:
examples: A good employment agency will match your skills and aspirations to available opportunities in the marketplace.

meanings.definition: an organization, especially a government organization, that helps people who need jobs:
examples: The borough established its own employment bureau to address a shortage of teachers, social workers and IT specialists.

meanings.definition: the total amount of money that it costs a company to employ people, including pay, insurance, benefits etc.:
examples: When faced with declining business, employers often must look at ways to cut employee costs in order to make ends meet.

meanings.definition: a situation in which employees are treated unfairly because of their race, sex, age, religion, physical or health problems, etc.:
examples: According to the study, 22% of employment discrimination claims were related to age and 35.5% to race.

meanings.definition: an official disagreement between an employer and their employee, usually relating to the employee's rights:
examples: Our lawyers have experience litigating all types of employment disputes on behalf of both employers and employees.

meanings.definition: the principle of making changes in an organization so that people who are often treated unfairly because of their race, sex, gender, physical differences, etc. have fair opportunities to find jobs there:
examples: Employers shall implement employment equity by identifying and eliminating barriers to employment for members of designated groups.
Employment equity is a policy whereby staff will represent all segments of the population, including women, visible minorities, Aboriginal people and persons with mental and physical challenges.
He is a project officer for transformation and employment equity at the University of the Witwatersrand.

meanings.definition: in some countries, a government plan that pays money to employees when they are unable to work, for example, because they have become sick, have had a child, or have lost their job:
examples: Employment insurance benefits are available to those workers who have lost their job through a layoff, work shortage or other no-fault reason.

meanings.definition: a set of laws that deal with the rights of employees and the responsibilities of employers:
examples: Employment law covers a wide range of issues from pension plans and retirement, to occupational safety, to discrimination in the workplace.

meanings.definition: laws, rules, plans etc. that protect an employee’s rights:
examples: A written contract is often used today to provide both employers and employees the necessary employment protection.
Under employment protection laws, employees have the right to maternity leave.

meanings.definition: behaviour and communication between an employee and their employer, especially relating to employees' rights and their happiness in their jobs:
examples: The program is aimed at providing managers with the knowledge and skills they need to maintain good employment relations.

meanings.definition: an official arrangement in which a business pays someone to work for them:
examples: All employment relationships are an implicit contract, even if that contract is never written down.

meanings.definition: a company or government report that shows how many people have jobs, how much they earn, etc.:
examples: Wall Street firms and their economists base many of their business decisions on the Bureau of Labor Statistics Employment Report.

meanings.definition: the fact that someone is likely to be able to stay in a job for as long as they want to:
examples: We need to look for ways to promote flexibility without underminding employment security.

meanings.definition: rules that explain how employers must treat, pay, protect, etc. their employees:
examples: Company representatives ensure that work at the factory is performed according to the highest international employment standards.

meanings.definition: the combination of social security taxes and income tax that a company takes from an employee’s pay and must pay to the government:
examples: The IRS filed a tax lien of $24,297 against the firm for failure to pay employment taxes.

meanings.definition: a set of ideas that try to explain how jobs are created, levels of pay are decided, etc.:
examples: John Maynard Keynes offered new thinking on income and employment theory.

meanings.definition: in Britain, a special type of court that decides legal problems between employees and their employers:
examples: Claims must be submitted to an employment tribunal within three months of the alleged act of discrimination.

meanings.definition: relating to work or jobs:
examples: Many companies said they used medical records to make employment-related decisions.

meanings.definition:
plural of 
        
         emporium   old-fashioned
a large shop that sells many different types of goods, or a shop that sells a particular type of goods:
examples: an ice cream/antiques emporium

meanings.definition: a large store selling a large range of goods, or a store selling a particular type of goods:
examples: This chain of discount emporia sells everything from wardrobes to paper clips.
Welcome to the Chocolate Emporium - an online store selling every kind of chocolate imaginable.

meanings.definition: to give someone official authority or the freedom to do something:
examples: This amendment empowers the president to declare an emergency for a wide range of reasons.
The first step in empowering the poorest sections of society is making sure they vote.

meanings.definition: to encourage and support the ability to do something:
examples: We want to empower individuals to get the skills they need.

meanings.definition: To empower is also to give legal authority for something:
examples: The state constitution does not empower counties to create housing authorities.

meanings.definition: to give someone official or legal authority, or the freedom or confidence to do something:
examples: We empower our sales staff to make decisions without always having to consult their supervisor.
The Legislature is empowered to make law, subject to the Governor's right of veto.
This communications skills course aims to make people feel empowered.

meanings.definition: confident and in control of your life:
examples: It's important that girls feel empowered and in control of what happens to them.

meanings.definition: having the official authority or freedom to do something:
examples: The editor may not be empowered to negotiate a contract.

meanings.definition: Something that is empowering makes you more confident and makes you feel that you are in control of your life:
examples: For me, learning to drive was an empowering experience.

meanings.definition: the process of gaining freedom and power to do what you want or to control what happens to you:
examples: female/youth empowerment
political/economic empowerment
Part of the philosophy of the World Wide Web is the empowerment of the individual.

meanings.definition: the process of giving a group of people more freedom or rights:
examples: This approach to management emphasizes the empowerment of workers to make decisions.
The government's economic empowerment program aims to create jobs and raise living standards in the poorer communities.

meanings.definition: a female ruler of an empire, or the wife of a male ruler of an empire

past simple and past participle of 
        
         empty
to remove everything from inside something:
examples: I emptied the closet and put my belongings into the black overnight case.
Would you mind emptying (out) your pockets?
Empty the soup into a saucepan and simmer gently for ten minutes.
She quickly emptied her glass (= drank its contents) and ordered another drink.

meanings.definition: to become empty:
examples: The place emptied pretty quickly when the fight started.

meanings.definition: empty containers:
examples: Corporate customers receive a discount on ink cartridges if they agree to return their empties to the manufacturer.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not contain any things or people:
examples: His hands hung emptily at his sides, and he could think of nothing to say.
The scaffolding of the half-built mill stood emptily, like the skeleton of a forest.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not sincere or is without any real meaning:
examples: She uses emptily flattering phrases.
The claim to moral superiority rings more emptily than ever.

meanings.definition: in a way that is without purpose or interest:
examples: His ideas seemed emptily theoretical and insubstantial.
It seems a society that is decadent and emptily consumerist.

meanings.definition: empty space:
examples: He gazed out over the emptiness of the desert.

meanings.definition: the fact of not being sincere or having no real meaning:
examples: the emptiness of these political gestures

meanings.definition: a sad feeling of having no emotion or purpose:
examples: I was left with a horrible feeling of emptiness.

meanings.definition: empty space:
examples: She loves the emptiness of the desert.

meanings.definition: lack of meaning or purpose:
examples: He tried to ignore the feeling of emptiness .

meanings.definition: not containing any things or people:
examples: an empty house/street
Shall I take the empty bottles for recycling?
The train was empty (= there were no passengers) by the time it reached London.

meanings.definition: not sincere or without any real meaning:
examples: She dismessed his apology as empty rhetoric
Too many empty threats and your child will soon learn to ignore you.
They're just empty promises.

meanings.definition: without purpose or interest:
examples: He says his life has been completely empty since his wife died.
I felt empty, like a part of me had died.

meanings.definition: to remove everything from inside something:
examples: I emptied the closet and put my belongings into the black overnight case.
Would you mind emptying (out) your pockets?

meanings.definition: to become empty:
examples: The place emptied pretty quickly when the fight started.

meanings.definition: an empty bottle or other container, especially one that contained drink:
examples: Don't forget to recycle the empties.

meanings.definition: having nothing inside:
examples: He set the empty glass down.

meanings.definition: If a place is empty, no one is using it or is present:
examples: It was past midnight, and the streets were empty.

meanings.definition: Empty also means without any meaning or purpose:
examples: We need jobs, not empty promises.

meanings.definition: a container with nothing in it, esp. one whose contents have been used:
examples: Bring the empties to the recycling center.

meanings.definition: to take out everything from inside something, or to lose what is inside so that nothing is left:
examples: She emptied her husband’s mug in the sink.
Once the movie ended, the theater emptied quickly.
The Tombigbee River empties into Mobile Bay (= its water flows there).

meanings.definition: energy from food containing no nutrients (= substances that keep you healthy)
If a river empties into a larger area of water, the water from it flows into that larger area:
examples: The River Tees empties into the North Sea.

meanings.definition: the sad feelings that parents have when their children grow up and leave home:
examples: The last of her children had recently moved out and she was suffering from empty nest syndrome.

meanings.definition: someone whose children have grown up and no longer live at home
a person whose adult children have left home:
examples: Cruise companies tend to cater to empty nesters who finally have both the time and the money to travel the world.

meanings.definition: a set (= a group of numbers) that contains no elements, represented by the symbol {}
without bringing or taking anything:
examples: We can't go to the party empty-handed.

meanings.definition: not having anything to bring or to take away:
examples: The two would-be robbers fled empty-handed.

meanings.definition: silly, stupid, or not having good judgment

abbreviation for emergency medical service: a system, linked to the 911 phone number, of providing emergency medical care throughout the US

a large Australian bird with a long neck and grey or brown feathers. Emus cannot fly but have long legs and can run quickly:
examples: Emus grow to almost two metres and can run at nearly 50 kph.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for European Monetary Union: the process within the European Union of moving towards a single currency

abbreviation for European Monetary Union/ Economic and Monetary Union: the group of countries in Europe who use the same currency (the euro), or the process by which many countries started to use the euro:
examples: The study examines fiscal rules in the EMU.
Competitive conditions vary even within the EMU, as wages and inflation rates differ from country to country.
In the article he analyses how the EMU process has influenced political integration within the European Union.

meanings.definition: to copy something achieved by someone else and try to do it as well as they have:
examples: They hope to emulate the success of other software companies.
Fitzgerald is eager to emulate Martin's record of three successive world titles.

meanings.definition: to copy someone’s behavior or try to be like someone else because you admire or respect that person:
examples: Officials are looking to emulate successful ideas from other cities.
He just wants to emulate his dad.

meanings.definition:

         emulate
to copy something achieved by someone else and try to do it as well as they have:
examples: They hope to emulate the success of other software companies.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         emulate
to copy something achieved by someone else and try to do it as well as they have:
examples: They hope to emulate the success of other software companies.
Fitzgerald is eager to emulate Martin's record of three successive world titles.

meanings.definition: the process of copying something achieved by someone else and trying to do it as well as they have:
examples: Much of what the company did was commendable and worthy of emulation.
In emulation of the tradition of street portraiture, she set up a backdrop and began taking portrait photos.

meanings.definition: copying something achieved by someone else and trying to do it as well as they have:
examples: These short films were emulative of the work of other directors.
An emulative rivalry is at the heart of many male friendships.

meanings.definition: in a way that copies something achieved by someone else and tries to do it as well as they have:
examples: Upwardly mobile groups of people consume emulatively in order to be seen as similar to elite groups.
Try not to draw or paint emulatively, but develop your own style.

meanings.definition: a person, group, product, etc. that copies the behaviour of another person, etc.:
examples: The growth of iTunes and its emulators has forced changes in regulations governing the sale of music.

meanings.definition: a computer system that is designed to behave in the same way as a different system:
examples: You will need to install a Windows emulator to run Microsoft programs on a Linux machine.

meanings.definition: wanting to copy what someone else has done:
examples: He's not envious, but emulous of what you have achieved.
The brothers are often emulous and argumentative in ways that detract from their achievements.

meanings.definition: resulting from a wish to copy what someone else has done:
examples: They have an emulous need to keep up with their neighbours.
She finds it difficult to conceal her emulous hope for more success.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows that you want to copy or compete with what someone else has done:
examples: They were all doing well and were all emulously hoping to do even better.
They love their work and emulously apply themselves to it.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         emulsify
If two liquids emulsify or are emulsified, they combine and become a smooth mixture.
a substance that forms or keeps an emulsion and is often added to processed foods to prevent particular parts from separating
If two liquids emulsify or are emulsified, they combine and become a smooth mixture.

present participle of 
        
         emulsify
If two liquids emulsify or are emulsified, they combine and become a smooth mixture.
a mixture that results when one liquid is added to another and is mixed with it but does not dissolve into it:
examples: Mixing oil and vinegar together produces an emulsion.

meanings.definition: a water-based paint that is not shiny when dry:
examples: emulsion paint

meanings.definition: all together in a united group:
examples: The ruling committee resigned en bloc to make way for a new election.

meanings.definition: cooked or served on a skewer (= a long, thin metal pin):
examples: Food served en brochette is usually grilled.
Kebabs grilled en brochette were served with bowls of lentils and rice.
Starters included oysters en brochette, wrapped in bacon and grilled.

meanings.definition: baked in a pastry crust (= a hard outer layer):
examples: I hear the salmon en croute is fantastic.
For my last dinner party I made mushrooms en croûte with Hollandaise sauce.
We decided to cook and serve the salmon en croute.

meanings.definition: a short dash (= the symbol - ), used especially when typing on a computer or in printing to separate numbers:
examples: An en dash is as wide as an "n" in a particular typeface.
En dashes are used almost exclusively for date ranges.

meanings.definition: all together and at the same time, in large numbers:
examples: The shop's 85 workers have resigned en masse.
By early summer, hiking is less enjoyable because the mosquitoes are out en masse.
He ripped up the papers en masse without looking at any of them.

meanings.definition: wrapped in special paper or in foil (= thin, shiny, metal material), and cooked:
examples: They serve French classics such as salmon en papillote.
The rich white meat of this fish is often cooked en papillote with shrimp and crab.
I had the sea bass en papillote, which was absolutely delicious.
For my main course, I'll have the mushrooms and tofu en papillote, please.
I chose the cod en papillote with tomatoes and pesto.
The chef here does a beautiful sea bass en papillote.

meanings.definition: French for 'in passing': if you say something en passant, you mention it quickly while talking about something else:
examples: She mentioned, en passant, that she'd been in L.A. the previous week.

meanings.definition: on the way to or from somewhere:
examples: I stopped en route (to the party) and got some wine.
The bomb exploded while the plane was en route from Paris to Tokyo.

meanings.definition: on the way to or from somewhere:
examples: weather-related enroute delays

meanings.definition: on the way to or from somewhere:
examples: The ambulance is en route to the hospital.
En route from New York to Boston, the bus crashed into a stalled car.

meanings.definition: a short dash (= the symbol - ), used especially when typing on a computer or in printing to separate numbers:
examples: Use the en rule closed up in elements that form a range, for example, 2011-2015, Monday-Saturday, or 9.30-5.30.
En rules cause most difficulty for copy-editors.

meanings.definition: used to describe a bathroom that is directly connected to a bedroom, or a bedroom that is connected to a bathroom:
examples: All four bedrooms in their new house are en suite.

meanings.definition: An en-suite bathroom is directly connected to and entered through a bedroom:
examples: I want a hotel room with an en-suite bathroom.
All rooms have en-suite facilities.

meanings.definition: a bathroom directly connected to and entered through a bedroom:
examples: My room has an en-suite.

meanings.definition: used to form verbs that mean to put into or onto something:
examples: encase
encircle
endanger

meanings.definition: used to form verbs that mean to cause to be something:
examples: enable
endear
enlarge
enrich

meanings.definition: used to form verbs that mean to provide with something:
examples: empower

meanings.definition: used to form verbs that mean to increase the stated quality:
examples: Sweeten to taste with honey or brown sugar.
I've had to loosen my belt.

meanings.definition: to make someone able to do something, or to make something possible:
examples: Computerization should enable us to cut production costs by half.

meanings.definition: to allow or make it possible for someone to behave in a way that damages them:
examples: It is wrong to enable or support any addict to become re-addicted to any drug.
Parents must always ask themselves if they are enabling their child's drug use.

meanings.definition: to make someone or something able to do something by providing whatever is necessary to achieve that aim:
examples: Saving enough money now will enable you to retire comfortably.

meanings.definition: to make someone or something able to do something, or to make something possible:
examples: This software will enable us to track orders more efficiently.
Recent technology has enabled the development of cheaper digital radios.

meanings.definition: provided with a particular type of equipment or technology, or having the necessary or correct system, device, or arrangement to use it:
examples: WAP-enabled mobile phones
Their aim is to make sure that every home and business becomes internet-enabled in the next ten years.

meanings.definition: operated or made possible by the use of a particular thing:
examples: voice-enabled software

meanings.definition: used to describe a piece of equipment that is able to use the technology mentioned:
examples: GPS-enabled phones

meanings.definition: the process of making someone able to do something, or making something possible:
examples: It's about the enablement of man's creativity through machinery.

meanings.definition: the process of providing a particular type of equipment or technology, or the necessary or correct system, device, or arrangement to use it:
examples: We provide web enablement of labs and bioscience facilities.

meanings.definition: something or someone that makes it possible for a particular thing to happen or be done:
examples: Information technology is an enabler, but not the whole solution.

meanings.definition: someone who allows or makes it possible for another person to behave in a way that damages that person:
examples: He accepts his responsibility as the enabler of many of his wife's problems.

meanings.definition: making something possible or easier:
examples: The government has lowered corporate tax to create an enabling business environment.

meanings.definition: the section of a formal agreement, a law, etc., that gives someone legal authority to do something:
examples: There is an enabling clause in the contract that states that the company has the right to terminate the policy at any time.

meanings.definition: to put something into action, especially to make something law:
examples: A package of economic sanctions is to be enacted against the country.

meanings.definition: to perform a story or play:
examples: The stories are enacted using music, dance and mime.

meanings.definition: to make a law, or to make an idea into a law:
examples: For the second year, national lawmakers failed to enact environmental legislation.

meanings.definition: to make a law or a rule become official:
examples: The government is to enact a law aimed at improving safety on construction sites.

meanings.definition: the act of performing a story or play:
examples: The founding of the town was impressively presented in dramatic enactment and dance.
In a real-life enactment of every singer's worst nightmare, she sang a few phrases before stopping and announcing that she had lost her voice.

meanings.definition: the making of a law, or a particular act of making a law:
examples: Supporters were pleased with the enactment of the bill.

meanings.definition: a decorative glass-like substance that is melted onto clay, metal, or glass objects, and then left to cool and become hard, or an object covered with this substance
a type of paint that forms a shiny surface when dry
the hard, white, shiny substance that forms the covering of a tooth
to cover something with enamel
a substance made from glass that is used to decorate or protect clay, metal, and glass objects, or an object covered with this substance:
examples: The enamel on the sink was chipped.

meanings.definition: Enamel is also a type of paint that forms a shiny surface when dry:
examples: I used a blue enamel for the trim.

meanings.definition: Enamel is also the hard, white, shiny substance that forms the covering of a tooth.

past simple and past participle of 
        
         enamel

present participle of 
        
         enamel
to cause someone to like or love something or someone:
examples: The tail fins and rocket details of 1950s cars were an impression of the technology that enamored that decade.
Persephone was the Greek goddess who enamored Hades, the king of the underworld.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to be liked by someone:
examples: I know this piece is not going enamor me to supporters of feminism.
In her childhood, giggling had been a form of self-protection, enamoring her to adults.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to be liked by someone:
examples: I know this piece is not going enamour me to supporters of feminism.

meanings.definition: liking something a lot:
examples: I have to say I'm not exactly enamoured with/of this part of the country.

meanings.definition: having a gender identity that is not simply male or female:
examples: The book's protagonist is enby.
My enby child lives four hours away, but they often visit at weekends.

meanings.definition: involving people who are enby:
examples: The festival features gay, lesbian, bi, trans, enby, and otherwise queer-focused films.

meanings.definition: a person who has a gender identity that is not simply male or female:
examples: Transmasculine enbies have a lot to offer traditional male groups.
Speaking as an enby, I find it uplifting to see a video game that treats enbies as real and worthy of respect.

examples: Many people are living in encampments around the city with no electricity or running water.

meanings.definition: to express or show the most important facts about something:
examples: It was very difficult to encapsulate the story of the revolution in a single one-hour documentary.
She encapsulates the stereotyped image that the British have of Americans.

meanings.definition: to cover or surround something or someone completely:
examples: The nuclear waste is encased in concrete before being sent for storage in disused mines.

meanings.definition: to cover or enclose something completely:
examples: The medal was encased in clear plastic.

meanings.definition: used to form nouns that refer to an action or series of actions:
examples: violence (= violent actions)
a performance (= act of performing)

meanings.definition: used to form nouns that describe a state or quality:
examples: her long absence (= period during which she was absent)

meanings.definition: a wall surrounding a castle, cathedral, or fortified city (= one that is protected by walls):
examples: By midnight more than 75,000 soldiers were within the enceinte.

meanings.definition: relating to or affecting the brain, in humans and in animals that have a spinal cord (= a set of nerves inside the row of bones in the back that connect the brain with other nerves in the body):
examples: Modern imaging methods are frequently used to diagnose encephalic lesions.
the encephalic region

meanings.definition: a serious illness caused by an infection that makes the brain swell
any of several medical conditions that involve swelling of the brain and spinal cord (= the set of nerves inside the spine):
examples: Encephalomyelitis can be caused by a variety of conditions that lead to irritation of the brain and spinal cord.
Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis presents as an acute-onset neurological dysfunction following a triggering event such as an infection.

meanings.definition: the brain in humans, and in animals that have a spinal column (= line of bones down the centre of the back):
examples: There were no apparent macroscopic changes in the encephalon.
These chemicals are found within the pituitary and other parts of the central nervous system and encephalon.

meanings.definition: inflammation affecting the surface of the brain that may be caused by infection or poisonous substances
to attract or please someone very much:
examples: The audience was clearly enchanted by her performance.

meanings.definition: to have a magical effect on someone or something
to charm or please someone a lot:
examples: He was enchanted by stories of the Old West.

meanings.definition: (in stories) to put someone completely under your control by using magic
affected by magic or seeming to be affected by magic:
examples: They met in Paris one enchanted afternoon in early autumn.

meanings.definition: changed by magic, or seeming to be changed by magic:
examples: The princess lives in an enchanted castle.

meanings.definition: a person who uses magic on someone or something:
examples: He is like a serpent enchanter.
Suddenly, as if by the touch of a enchanter's wand, he became just like his father.

meanings.definition: very pleasant:
examples: It's described in the guide book as "an enchanting medieval city".

meanings.definition: very pleasant or charming:
examples: Belgium is an enchanting country.

meanings.definition: in a way that is very pleasant or attractive:
examples: She had never been there before, and everything seemed enchantingly new to her.
She was enchantingly pretty, with dark shining curls and beautiful skin.

meanings.definition: a feeling of great pleasure and attraction, especially because something is very beautiful:
examples: The audience looked on in utter fascination and enchantment.
This is a place of enchantment and beauty.

meanings.definition: a very attractive and pleasing quality:
examples: How can I describe the many enchantments of this island?

meanings.definition: something that is thought to have magical power over someone:
examples: spells and enchantments

meanings.definition: the state of being under the influence of magic:
examples: Nothing could break through his enchantment.

meanings.definition: a woman with magical powers
an extremely attractive and interesting woman
a type of food originally from Mexico consisting of a tortilla that is filled with meat and covered with a very spicy sauce
a food consisting of a tortilla (= type of flat, round bread) wrapped around meat, beans, or cheese, and covered with a sauce that is usually spicy
a benign tumour (= one that is not likely to cause death) that occurs in bones, especially in the hands and feet:
examples: Typically enchondromas cause no symptoms.

meanings.definition: to surround something, forming a circle around it:
examples: The house is encircled by a high fence.
Villaverde is one of the high-rise districts that encircle Madrid.

meanings.definition: to surround or form a circle around something:
examples: A parking lot encircles the mall.

meanings.definition: a part of a country that is surrounded by another country, or a group of people who are different from the people living in the surrounding area:
examples: Campione d'Italia is an Italian enclave in Switzerland.

meanings.definition: an area that is different from the larger area or country surrounding it, or a group of people who are different from the people living in the surrounding area:
examples: Yorkville was an enclave of German immigrants.

meanings.definition: to surround something:
examples: The park that encloses the monument has recently been enlarged.

meanings.definition: to send something in the same envelope or parcel as something else:
examples: Please enclose a curriculum vitae with your application.

meanings.definition: to surround:
examples: The garden is enclosed by four walls.

meanings.definition: to send something in the same envelope or package as something else:
examples: Please enclose a stamped, self-addressed envelope.

meanings.definition: to include something inside a letter or parcel:
examples: Apply in writing, enclosing a current CV, to the address below.
Please find enclosed an application form and information about the company.

meanings.definition: surrounded by walls, objects, or structures:
examples: He doesn't like enclosed spaces.

meanings.definition: sent to someone in an envelope with a letter:
examples: The enclosed card is for Julia.

meanings.definition: (of a place) surrounded by a wall and often covered:
examples: It’s the largest fully-enclosed shopping center in the world.

meanings.definition: the act of putting fences around land:

meanings.definition: something that is put in the same envelope or parcel as something else
an area surrounded by a fence or other structure in order to be kept separate from other areas:
examples: The dogs are in a fenced enclosure in the backyard.

meanings.definition: something extra that is sent in a letter or package with the main message:
examples: You will find two enclosures with this letter – a check and a photograph.

meanings.definition: a document, etc. that is included inside a letter:
examples: Please identify enclosures such as disks or checks in any correspondence.

meanings.definition: to change something into a system for sending messages secretly, or to represent complicated information in a simple or short way:
examples: Many satellite broadcasts are encoded so that they can only be received by people who have paid to see them.
Some music CDs are encoded with information about the performers and their music.

meanings.definition: to use a word or phrase in a foreign language in the correct way:
examples: Grammatical information helps learners to encode sentences.

meanings.definition: to put information into a form in which it can be stored, and which can only be read using special technology or knowledge:
examples: HTML is the programming language used to encode documents to that they can be displayed on any computer which has access the Web.
Each box of medicine has a label encoded with a unique ID number linked to a database.

to include different types of things:
examples: The festival is to encompass everything from music, theatre, and ballet to literature, cinema, and the visual arts.

meanings.definition: to include several different things:
examples: The plan encompasses repaving the street and planting 40 new trees.

meanings.definition: an extra song or piece of music that is performed at the end of a show because the audience shouts for it:
examples: We were shouting for an encore.
They did a few old hits as/for an encore.

meanings.definition: shouted by the audience at the end of a performance to get the performer to sing or play more:
examples: There were a few shouts of "Encore!" but she walked off stage.

meanings.definition: the performance of an additional song or piece of music after a show has formally ended, or the word people sometimes call out while clapping to request this performance:
examples: The audience demanded encore after encore.

meanings.definition: a new type of job that someone starts doing after already working for many years, especially when they have achieved success or made money and want to do something good for society:
examples: Non-profit organizations make an excellent encore career for senior executives.

meanings.definition: a meeting, especially one that happens by chance:
examples: I had an alarming encounter with a wild pig.
This meeting will be the first encounter between the party leaders since the election.

meanings.definition: an occasion when people have sex, usually with someone they have not met before
an occasion when two teams play against each other:
examples: In their last encounter with Italy, England won 3–2.

meanings.definition: to meet someone unexpectedly:
examples: On their way home they encountered a woman selling flowers.

meanings.definition: to experience something, especially something unpleasant:
examples: When did you first encounter these difficulties?
The army is reported to be encountering considerable resistance.

meanings.definition: to meet someone unexpectedly, or to experience, esp. something unpleasant:
examples: In the kitchen I encountered a woman I had never seen before.
He was shocked by the hostility he encountered.

meanings.definition: to experience a situation, especially something that is unexpected or unpleasant:
examples: We encountered a problem with the fuel pump during safety tests.
This is the first time I have encountered racism at work.

meanings.definition: a meeting with someone, especially one that is unexpected or unpleasant:
examples: Customer service representatives are trained to handle encounters with angry customers.

meanings.definition: to make someone more likely to do something, or to make something more likely to happen:
examples: We were encouraged to learn foreign languages at school.
The council is encouraging the development of the property for both employment and recreation.

meanings.definition: to talk or behave in a way that gives someone confidence to do something:
examples: They've always encouraged me in everything I've wanted to do.

meanings.definition: to help someone to feel confident and able to do something, or to give advice to someone to do something:
examples: Our parents always encouraged us to ask questions.

meanings.definition: If something encourages an activity, it supports it or makes it more likely:
examples: The city needs to encourage job creation.

meanings.definition: having more confidence or hope about something:
examples: She felt encouraged by their promise of support.

meanings.definition: words or behaviour that give someone confidence to do something:
examples: Children need lots of encouragement from their parents.
I could never have achieved this without the encouragement of my husband and family.

meanings.definition: words or behaviour that make something more likely to happen:
examples: We give positive encouragement to applications from older candidates.

meanings.definition: making you feel more confidence or hope:
examples: There was a lot of positive feedback, which was very encouraging.

meanings.definition: in a way that is encouraging (= making you feel more confidence or hope):
examples: My mother smiled encouragingly at me as I went up on stage.
The level of activity has continued to be encouragingly high.

meanings.definition: to take control or possession of something in a gradual way and often without being noticed:
examples: Farmers encroached on forest land to grow crops.
These devices are encroaching on people’s privacy.

meanings.definition: to gradually take away someone else's rights, or to take control of someone's time, work, etc.:
examples: What the company is proposing encroaches on the rights of individuals.
I resent it that my job is starting to encroach on my family life.

meanings.definition: to gradually cover more and more of an area of land:
examples: They have promised that the development will not encroach on public land.

meanings.definition: the act of gradually taking away someone else's rights, or taking control of someone's time, work, etc.:
examples: The new censorship laws are serious encroachments on freedom of expression.

meanings.definition: in some sports, an instance of a player moving too close to the ball or an opponent before the play begins:
examples: The referee called a penalty for encroachment on the defence, allowing the offence to move up five yards.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         incrustation
covered with something hard or decorative:
examples: She arrived home with her knees encrusted with mud.
The manuscript is bound in gold and silver and encrusted with jewels.

meanings.definition: covered with a hard layer or something, or with something decorative:
examples: All our belongings were encrusted with mud.

meanings.definition: to change electronic information or signals into a secret code (= system of letters, numbers, or symbols) that people cannot understand or use on normal equipment:
examples: Your financial information is fully encrypted and cannot be accessed.

meanings.definition: to put information into a special form so that most people cannot read it:
examples: Protected websites will tell you that the transfer is encrypted, and your browser will usually display a symbol confirming this.

meanings.definition: to protect private information by putting it into a form that can only be read by people who have the permission to do so:
examples: The software encrypts data that is sent over the internet.
The email is encrypted, so you need to enter a password to read it.

examples: The records were stored using protective encryption.
The company's encryption software allows secure credit card transactions over the internet.

meanings.definition: to weigh someone or something down, or to make it difficult for someone to do something:
examples: Today, thankfully, women tennis players are not encumbered with/by long, heavy skirts and high-necked blouses.

meanings.definition: prevented from making quick progress by having to carry heavy objects or deal with important duties and responsibilities:
examples: She was encumbered by concern over her husband’s health.

meanings.definition: if a property is encumbered, there is a mortgage or other charge on it:
examples: Transfer of encumbered property can have negative tax implications.

meanings.definition: if a person or an organization is encumbered, there is something that makes it difficult for them to do things:
examples: The firm is encumbered by debt, and may need to sell off assets.
Online stores are not encumbered with the overheads of high-street stores.

meanings.definition:
present participle of

to weigh someone or something down, or to make it difficult for someone to do something:
examples: Today, thankfully, women tennis players are not encumbered with/by long, heavy skirts and high-necked blouses.

meanings.definition: something that makes it difficult for you to do something:
examples: When you're walking 30 miles a day, the fewer encumbrances the better.
He has no patience for the irritations and encumbrances of celebrity.
I felt that I was a nuisance, an incumbrance.

meanings.definition: a mortgage (= an agreement to borrow money from a bank, etc. to buy a property) or other charge to pay on a property, or the fact that a property has a mortgage or other charge to pay on it:
examples: They were buying land without encumbrances for between $100 and $500 an acre.
To make a reasonable risk evaluation it is important to know what other encumbrances there are on the property title.
I confirm that no charge, hire-purchase agreement or other incumbrance affects the property.

meanings.definition: a mortgage or other charge on a property, or the fact of a property having a mortgage, etc.:
examples: An encumbrance is a legal claim on a property that affects the owner's ability to transfer the ownership of the property.

meanings.definition: something that makes it difficult to do things:
examples: He had paid off his loans and was free of the encumbrance of debt.

meanings.definition: used to form nouns showing a state or quality:
examples: her long presidency (= time during which she was president)
a difficult pregnancy (= time during which a woman is pregnant)

meanings.definition: a letter from the Pope to Roman Catholic bishops, often about the Church's official opinion on a subject:
examples: Several popes wrote encyclicals on the rosary.

meanings.definition:
a UK spelling of 
        
         encyclopedia

a mainly UK spelling of 
        
         encyclopedically

a mainly UK spelling of 
        
         encyclopedist

a book or set of books containing many articles arranged in alphabetical order that deal either with the whole of human knowledge or with a particular part of it, or a similar set of articles on the internet:
examples: The Cambridge Encyclopedia of Language
The library was full of dictionaries, encyclopaedias, poetry, and plays.

meanings.definition: a large collection of information about one or many subjects, often arranged alphabetically in articles in a book or set of books, or available through a computer
containing a lot of information
covering a large range of knowledge, often in great detail:
examples: her encyclopedic knowledge of France

meanings.definition: covering a large range of knowledge, often in great detail:
examples: He has boundless energy and an encyclopedic memory.

meanings.definition: in a way that contains a lot of information, or that is organized like an encyclopedia:
examples: Authors and historic events are listed encyclopedically.
She wrote long novels that were encyclopaedically packed with information.

meanings.definition: in a way that includes a large range of knowledge:
examples: He seemed to be encyclopedically well informed about everything from dinosaurs to modern technology.
They were encyclopaedically well educated.

meanings.definition: a person who creates or writes for an encyclopedia (= a book, website, or set of books containing many articles arranged in alphabetical order about different subjects):
examples: He was an encyclopedist, known for his work on medical texts.
She has an international reputation as a scientist and encyclopaedist.

meanings.definition: the part of a place or thing that is furthest away from the centre:
examples: This cable should have a plug at one end and a socket at the other.
We damaged the end of the piano when we moved it.
Get to the end of the queue and wait your turn like everyone else.
Our house is the third from the end on the left.
Is it safe to stand the computer on (its) end?

meanings.definition: the final part of something such as a period of time, activity, or story:
examples: I always like to leave my desk clear at the end of the day.
The end of the play was much more exciting than I'd expected.
This latest injury must surely mean that her tennis career is now at an end (= finished).
The statement said there would be no end to the violence until the terrorists' demands were met.

meanings.definition: polite word for death:
examples: We were all by her bedside when the end finally came.
He met his end (= died) in a shoot-out with the police.

meanings.definition: either of the two halves of the field in some sports:
examples: The teams change ends at half-time so that neither side has an unfair advantage.

meanings.definition: in sports including curling, bowls, and archery, a part of a game, especially one in which each team or player throws or shoots towards one end of the playing area:
examples: It was a close contest that came down to the last stone in the last end.
The Canadians took singles on each of the next three ends.

meanings.definition: a small part of something that is left after most of it has been used:
examples: She makes quilts out of fabric bolt ends.
The floor was covered in cigarette ends.

meanings.definition: an aim, intention, or purpose:
examples: Do you have a particular end in mind?

meanings.definition: the parts of a task or process connected with one particular type of activity or person:
examples: Rick's more involved with the financial end of things.

meanings.definition: to finish or stop, or to make something finish or stop:
examples: When is your meeting due to end?
Her resignation ends months of speculation about her future.
Their marriage ended in 1991.
The game ended in a draw.
I'd like to end with a song from my first album.
She ended her speech on an optimistic note.

meanings.definition: the last or farthest part of something or of a period of time, beyond which it does not exist:
examples: She tied one end of the rope to a tree.
The punctuation at the end of this sentence is a period.
Did you stay to the end of the movie?
Steve can swim to the far end of the lake and back.

meanings.definition: a specific part or division of an activity:
examples: She takes care of the financial end of the business and I handle the marketing end.

meanings.definition: something that your actions or efforts are intended to achieve; an aim:
examples: To accomplish that end, you will have to work hard and be lucky, too.

meanings.definition: (in football) one of two players who begin play farthest from the ball:
examples: a defensive end

meanings.definition: to finish or stop, or to make something finish or stop:
examples: Our arguments always end in tears.
She ended her speech on an optimistic note.

meanings.definition: the time or place that something finishes:
examples: The construction will be completed by the end of the year.
Sales are looking good according to the end-of-month report.
We spent a long time looking for a good supplier, but we found one in the end.
There are encouraging signs that the recession has come to an end.
The difficult period we've been through now seems to be at an end.
There is no end to the possible markets for this product.
The meeting room is at the end of the corridor on the right.

meanings.definition: used when stating whether goods or services are expensive or cheap, or of high or low quality:
examples: This basic laptop is aimed at the low end of the market.

meanings.definition: an aim or purpose:
examples: We aim to halve production costs, and to this end we are investing in automating the process.
We see good design not just as a means of increasing profits, but as an end in itself.

meanings.definition: the parts of a task or process connected with one particular type of activity, or with a particular person:
examples: Rick's more involved with the financial end of things.
Everything's ready here, but how are thing's your end?
We kept our end of the bargain, but they failed to meet their deadline.

meanings.definition: to finish or stop, or to make something finish or stop:
examples: What time is your meeting due to end?
Her resignation ends months of speculation about her future.
Our contract with those suppliers ended in April.
The negotiations ended in failure after three days.
I'd like to end my presentation with a little story...

meanings.definition: a person who buys and uses a product or service:
examples: We have kept our prices the same, so our increased production costs have not been passed on to the end consumer.
Customer surveys allow us to learn more about the end consumer.

meanings.definition: to kill yourself:
examples: And if this doesn't work, I'm just going to end it all.

meanings.definition: in American football, a line that marks the back of one of the end zones (= the areas at the end of the field where a player with the ball can score a goal):
examples: The wide receiver's feet were across the end line when he caught the ball, meaning that he was out of bounds, so the catch was not counted.
In American football, the goal posts are located on the end line, but in Canadian football they are located on the goal line.

meanings.definition: in ball sports such as basketball, one of the two lines that mark each end of the playing area:
examples: The ball slipped past his outstretched fingers and across the end line.

meanings.definition: the end of the working or business day:
examples: With luck we will have the project up by end of day tomorrow.

meanings.definition: something you say to tell someone that you have made a final decision and you do not want to talk about it any more:
examples: You're not going out tonight - end of!

meanings.definition: something you say when you think that the opinion you have just expressed about something is correct and that there is no other way of thinking about it:
examples: This woman is innocent - end of story.

meanings.definition: any organ in the body that is ultimately (= finally, after other things have happened) affected by serious disease:
examples: The assessment and treatment of both risk factors and end organs are essential in the management of cardiovascular diseases.
Without proper treatments, diabetes results in a series of complications that can affect multiple end organs.

meanings.definition: one of several specialized structures that form the end of a pathway of nerve fibres:
examples: Eventually, the eroding nucleus will contact enough end organs of the nervous system, and radiating pains will begin.
Stimulation is the action of various agents on muscles, nerves, or a sensory end organ by which activity is evoked.

meanings.definition: relating to any organ in the body that is ultimately (= finally, after other things have happened) affected by serious disease or medical condition:
examples: This leads to progressive vascular and end-organ damage.
The challenge lies in identifying those at the highest risk of end-organ dysfunction before it occurs.
There was no obvious evidence of end organ damage.

meanings.definition: something that is produced by an activity, especially by an industrial process:
examples: Every stage of production from obtaining raw materials to recycling end products is monitored for its environmental effects.

meanings.definition: the thing that is produced by an industrial process or an activity:
examples: Greed and selfishness are the end products of a system that always puts the individual first.

meanings.definition: something that is the result of or is created by an activity or process:
examples: People only see the end product and not all the hard work that goes into producing it.
The report was the end product of more than a year's study of the district's management and organizational structure.

meanings.definition: a result of a series of events or a long process:
examples: The end result of these changes will be more bureaucracy and fewer resources.

meanings.definition: what finally happens from a series of events:
examples: I followed the recipe, but the end result was disappointing.

meanings.definition: from the very beginning of a process to the very end:
examples: We offer our clients end-to-end solutions covering all aspects from design, to manufacture to packaging.
He admitted to not providing wounded troops with the end-to-end care they deserve.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a system of communication where only the people communicating can read the messages:
examples: Will end-to-end encryption eliminate the chance that stolen cardholder data can be used successfully for fraudulent transactions?
This section focuses on end-to-end data privacy, where no intermediate nodes are able to understand the data that passes through them.

meanings.definition: including all the stages of a process:
examples: He wants the company to provide an end-to-end service, from early clinical trials all the way through to high-volume manufacturing.

meanings.definition: including everything that is necessary for all the parts of a computer network to be connected and work together:
examples: an end-to-end system/solution/technology

meanings.definition: to finally be in a particular place or situation:
examples: They're travelling across Europe by train and are planning to end up in Moscow.
Much of this meat will probably end up as dog food.
She'll end up penniless if she continues to spend like that.
After working her way around the world, she ended up teaching English as a foreign language.

meanings.definition: to reach a particular place or achieve a situation after other activities:
examples: After two weeks of traveling around Europe, we ended up in Paris.
The deals were popular at the time, but many ended up losing money.

meanings.definition: the person or organization that uses something rather than an organization that trades in it:
examples: The software can be modified to suit the particular needs of the end user.

meanings.definition: the person or organization that uses a product or service:
examples: The management of distributors and dealers were reviewed in an attempt to minimize disruption to our end-users.
The survey has specifically targeted end users of computer software.

meanings.definition: (in American football) the area at the end of the field where a player with the ball can score a goal
(in football) the area at the end of the field where a player with the ball can score a goal
a solution to a problem that avoids the problem rather than dealing with it directly:
examples: We're not officially allowed to use outside contractors, so we'll need to do an end-around to bypass that rule.

meanings.definition: End-of-life issues relate to someone's death and the time just before it, when it is known that they are likely to die soon from an illness or condition:
examples: end-of-life care
More of the baby boomer generation are now facing end-of-life decisions.

meanings.definition: An end-of-season sports event happens at the end of a season (= the part of a year in which a sport is played):
examples: The team failed to make it to the end-of-season playoffs.

meanings.definition: relating to the end of a period of time when particular clothes, products, etc. are sold in shops:
examples: Prices are reduced by up to 75 percent in our end-of-season sale.
The store sells end-of-season stock at heavily discounted prices.

meanings.definition: an occasion when clothes or other goods relating to a particular season are sold at a lower price than usual:
examples: Get 50% off camping equipment in our end-of-season sale.

meanings.definition: An end-of-terrace house is at the end of a row of similar houses that are joined together.
relating to the end of the financial year, or to the end of December:
examples: end-of-year accounts/results/sales

meanings.definition: a way of avoiding a rule that was put in place to stop you from doing something:
examples: The teachers made an end-run around the regulations by using two different textbooks.
Officials in California tried to do an end run around the federal governement.

meanings.definition: in American football, an occasion when a wide receiver runs across the field behind the line of scrimmage and is handed the ball so that they can run forwards with it:
examples: They tried to fool the defence with an end run.

meanings.definition: used to refer to the final stage of a disease, just before death:
examples: end-stage liver disease

meanings.definition: to put someone or something at risk or in danger of being harmed, damaged, or destroyed:
examples: He would never do anything to endanger the lives of his children.
We must be careful not to do anything that might endanger the economic recovery.

meanings.definition: to put someone or something in a situation in which it is likely to be harmed, damaged, or destroyed:
examples: Revealing that information might endanger our national security.

meanings.definition: in danger of being harmed, lost, unsuccessful, etc.:
examples: Social workers who look after abused or endangered children often have stressful days at work.
the endangered contracts of failing competitors

meanings.definition: animals or plants that may soon not exist because there are very few now alive:
examples: Monarch butterflies are now an endangered species idue to declining numbers.
Fencing is put up to protect the eggs of endangered sea turtles from humans.
The zoo specializes in breeding endangered animals.
Environmentalists claim the project would destroy marshland that is home to many endangered birds.
This area provides habitat for several rare or endangered fish species.

meanings.definition: a type of animal or plant that might stop existing because there are only a few of that type alive

present participle of 
        
         endanger
to put someone or something at risk or in danger of being harmed, damaged, or destroyed:
examples: He would never do anything to endanger the lives of his children.
We must be careful not to do anything that might endanger the economic recovery.

meanings.definition: an operation to remove fat from inside an artery (= a tube carrying blood from the heart) that is blocked:
examples: None of the patients had severe enough disease in the ascending aorta to warrant an aortic endarterectomy.
The authors reported no complications in 10 of the patients undergoing endarterectomy.

meanings.definition: the cerebrum (= the front part of the brain) and the structures connected to it:
examples: At the core of the left and right halves of the endbrain are the internal regulatory systems.
The forms taken by the end-brain determine the intelligence capacity of the higher vertebrates, including reptiles, birds, and mammals.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to be liked by someone:
examples: She is unlikely to endear herself to her colleagues with such an aggressive approach.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to be liked by another person:
examples: His fiery temper did not endear him to his coworkers.

meanings.definition: making someone like you:
examples: She laughs at herself a lot, which is always endearing.

meanings.definition: easily able to make people like you:
examples: Pickwick is endearing, as so many fools are.

meanings.definition: in a way that makes someone like you:
examples: He was endearingly funny.
The presenter is tall, with an endearingly crooked smile.

meanings.definition: a word or phrase that you use to show that you love someone:
examples: terms of endearment such as "darling" or "sweetheart"
Between kisses, he was murmuring endearments.

an effort or attempt to do something:
examples: Writing is a very different endeavor than teaching.

meanings.definition: to try to do something:
examples: I endeavored to explain the legal consequences of his action.

meanings.definition: to try to do something:
examples: Engineers are endeavouring to locate the source of the problem.

meanings.definition: an attempt to do something:
examples: In spite of our best endeavours, it has proven impossible to contact her.
Crossing the North Pole on foot was an amazing feat of human endeavour.
Thanks to all of you who support me in my artistic endeavours.

examples: When is your meeting due to end?
Her resignation ends months of speculation about her future.
