meanings.definition: especially of a disease or a condition, regularly found and very common among a particular group or in a particular area:
examples: Malaria is endemic in many of the hotter regions of the world.
The disease is endemic among British sheep/to many British flocks.
There is endemic racism/poverty/violence in many of the country's cities.

meanings.definition: (esp. of a disease or social condition) found particularly in a specific area or group:
examples: Some of these problems are endemic to big US cities.

meanings.definition: in a way that is endemic (= regularly found and very common among a particular group or in a particular area):
examples: She suggests the country's government is endemically corrupt.

meanings.definition: (of a chemical process, especially one in the body) involving energy being absorbed:
examples: endergonic and exergonic reactions

meanings.definition: the last stage in a game of chess when only a few of the pieces are left on the board
the last stage of a process, especially one involving discussion:
examples: A diplomatic endgame is under way to find a peaceful solution.

meanings.definition: the last part of a story:
examples: People want love stories with happy endings.

meanings.definition: a part added to the end of a word:
examples: To make the plural of "dog", you add the plural ending -s.

meanings.definition: the last part of a process, esp. the way in which something stops existing:
examples: The movie’s ending is so romantic!

meanings.definition: An ending is a part added to a word that changes its meaning:
examples: To make “dog” plural, you add the ending “-s.”

meanings.definition: a plant with thick, pale leaves that taste bitter and that are eaten cooked as a vegetable or in salads:
examples: Arrange 4-5 spears of endive across each plate.
Grill the endives for 3 to 4 minutes on each side.
Spoon the cheese mixture into a piping bag and pipe it into the endive leaves.

meanings.definition: a plant with curly green leaves that are eaten uncooked in salads:
examples: Radicchio and endive are popular salad leaves that are available all through winter.
He makes a salad of endive and walnuts with a warm dressing.
There was a beautiful display on the market stall of green frizzy endives and purple oak leaf lettuces.

meanings.definition: a plant with long, narrow leaves that curl at the edges and that is eaten in salads
never finishing, or seeming never to finish:
examples: We used to have endless arguments about politics.
He seems to think that I have an endless supply of money.
The possibilities are endless.

meanings.definition: If something is endless, it never finishes or seems never to finish because it continues for so long:
examples: When I was a child, the summers seemed endless.

meanings.definition: never finishing, or never seeming to finish:
examples: There have been endless meetings about this problem.
We've had orders from Brazil, China, India, Spain ... the list is endless.

meanings.definition: in a way that is endless (= never finishing, or seeming never to finish):
examples: I find myself endlessly repeating the same phrases.
The clear, blue-green waters of Lake Michigan appear to go on endlessly.

meanings.definition: relating to the endocardium (= the thin layer of tissue that covers the inside spaces of the heart), or on the inside of the heart :
examples: The endocardial thickening was not uniform throughout the left ventricular cavity.
The patient has temporary pacing wires inserted transvenously as endocardial wires.

meanings.definition: inflammation of the lining of the heart:
examples: bacterial/infective endocarditis

meanings.definition: a thin layer of tissue that covers the inside spaces of the heart:
examples: This may lead to an infection of the endocardium or heart valves.
The most important pathological alteration of the endocardium is thickening.

meanings.definition: a model made to show the shape of a brain by pouring a substance into the inside of an empty skull (= the bones of the head):
examples: The general form of the brain can be outlined from the structure of the endocast.
Endocasts are particularly useful for comparing brain sizes.

meanings.definition: relating to or formed by the process of cartilage (= strong tissue found in the joints) being replaced by bone:
examples: The process of endochondral ossification is responsible for both the formation and linear growth of most of the skeleton.
These have been found to induce endochondral bone formation in adult non-human primates.

meanings.definition: a model made to show the shape of a brain by pouring a substance into the inside of an empty skull (= the bones of the head):
examples: Information is limited to endocranial casts of fossil skulls that show only the size and shape of the brain.
Careful preparation of the skull has made it possible to describe not only the superficial features of the skull, but also to prepare an endocranial cast.

meanings.definition: relating to hormones (= chemicals made by living cells that influence the body's development, growth, sex, etc.) or to any of the organs in the body that make them and put them into the blood:
examples: Many processes in the body are controlled by the endocrinal system.
Age-associated endocrinal changes are actually similar in cattle and in humans.

meanings.definition: relating to any of the organs of the body that make hormones (= chemicals that make the body grow and develop) and put them into the blood, or to the hormones that they make
of or relating to any of the organs of the body that make hormones (= chemicals which make the body grow and develop) and put them into the blood, or the hormones that they make
a chemical that can affect the systems in the body that produce and control hormones:
examples: There is concern that endocrine disruptors in the environment could affect humans.

meanings.definition: any of the organs of the body, such as the pituitary gland or the ovaries, that produce and release hormones into the blood to be carried around the body
relating to the endocrine glands (= organs in the body that make hormones) or to endocrinology (= the area of science and medicine concerned with the endocrine glands):
examples: Data suggest this did not have an effect on the endocrinologic response.
This can even reverse the immunologic and endocrinologic defects caused by long-term heroin addiction.

meanings.definition: relating to the endocrine glands (= organs in the body that make hormones) or to endocrinology (= the area of science and medicine concerned with the endocrine glands):
examples: This was confirmed by endocrinological testing.

meanings.definition: a doctor or scientist who specializes in endocrinology
the area of science and medicine that is concerned with the endocrine glands and hormones
a layer of cells in a plant's root that is the inside part of the cortex (= the part under the exodermis and outer layer):
examples: The only way for the water to cross the endodermis is through the cytoplasm of these cells.

meanings.definition: A nuclear reaction that is endoergic absorbs energy:
examples: Molecules that are the result of endoergic reactions may break down.
All photonuclear reactions are endoergic.

meanings.definition: the fact or custom of having marriage only between members of the same group:
examples: Village endogamy is still common in the region.

meanings.definition: found or coming from within something, for example a system or a person's body or mind:
examples: Endogenous insulin levels decrease over time in people with type 2 diabetes.

meanings.definition: used in economics to describe something that is inside a particular system, rather than outside that system:
examples: There are those who see the origins of the crisis as endogenous to the region.

meanings.definition: the liquid found inside the inner ear (= a part inside the ear) that helps control balance:
examples: When a person moves their head or body, the endolymph moves.

meanings.definition: relating to the endometrium (= the lining of the uterus):

meanings.definition: a condition in which cells from the lining of the uterus grow outside the uterus:

meanings.definition: the inside surface of the uterus (= the organ in which a baby develops)
a person with a round body shape and with a lot of fat
having a round body shape with a lot of fat:

meanings.definition: inside, into, or through the nose, especially used to describe medical operations that enter the body through the nose:
examples: All patients underwent a standardized procedure, with an endonasal approach to the lacrimal sac.

examples: The school has received an endowment of $50,000 to buy new books for the library.

meanings.definition: something that you have from birth, often a quality:

meanings.definition: the end of something or something that you are trying to achieve:
examples: I don't feel like I'm at an endpoint or even at a midpoint in my career.
We’ve reached an acceptable endpoint in this litigation.

meanings.definition: a point at which a line segment ends
a point at which a line segment ends
a result or event that must happen in order for an activity or project to be considered as having been successfully achieved:
examples: They changed the endpoint because they want to be able to analyze the data more quickly.

meanings.definition: the fact that something difficult, unpleasant, or painful is possible to deal with :
examples: The workload was barely endurable, but the experience was priceless.
Many patients with osteoarthritis need aspirin or another pain reliever to make life endurable.

meanings.definition: in a way that is endurable (= possible to accept and deal with), even though it may be difficult, unpleasant, or painful:
examples: They were able to perform their duties effectively and endurably.
The water was hot, but endurably so, once you got used to it.

meanings.definition: the ability to keep doing something difficult, unpleasant, or painful for a long time:
examples: Running a marathon is a test of human endurance.
The pain was bad beyond endurance.

meanings.definition: used to describe sports or activities that demand the ability to make a lot of physical effort over a long period of time, or people or animals who do these:
examples: Studies of elite sprinters reveal their leg muscles have more fast-twitch fibres, while marathon runners and other endurance athletes have more slow-twitch.
For endurance runners, performance is mainly a question of how efficiently the body can take in and burn oxygen.
In endurance sports, you can actually improve as you get older.

meanings.definition: the ability to continue doing something for a long time:
examples: He began visiting the gym to build up his strength and endurance.

meanings.definition: someone who rides a horse in races over long distances:
examples: They are endurance riders and Arabian horse enthusiasts.

meanings.definition: someone who rides a bicycle in races over long distances:
examples: Great sprinters, unlike stage racers or endurance riders, reach their best in their 20s.

meanings.definition: the sport or activity of taking part in horse races over long distances:
examples: In endurance riding, competitors usually race horses from 50 to 100 miles.
Nicky was the British endurance riding champion and had three horses.

meanings.definition: the sport or activity of taking part in bicycle rides over long distances:
examples: Her training programme includes four-hour bike rides on weekends plus 40 minutes of endurance riding twice a week.

meanings.definition: to suffer something difficult, unpleasant, or painful:
examples: We had to endure a nine-hour delay at the airport.
She's already had to endure three painful operations on her leg.

meanings.definition: to continue to exist for a long time:
examples: The political system established in 1400 endured until about 1650.

meanings.definition: with the end, rather than the side, facing or touching:

meanings.definition: a treatment for cleaning the bowels by filling them with a liquid through the anus
a person who hates or opposes another person and tries to harm them or stop them from doing something:
examples: He's made a few enemies in this company.

political enemies

meanings.definition: a country, or the armed forces of a country, that is at war with another country:

an attack by enemy aircraft
enemy forces/territory

meanings.definition: a person who hates or opposes another person and tries to harm that person:

meanings.definition: The enemy is a country or the armed forces or people of a country that is at war with your own country:
examples: He was charged with espionage and aiding the enemy.

meanings.definition: having or involving a lot of energy:
examples: an energetic young woman
I tried aerobics but it was too energetic for me.

meanings.definition: relating to or having the physical property of energy, or involving energy being exchanged or released:
examples: Cosmic rays are energetic particles that speed through space.
It is believed that these particles form during supernova explosions and similar energetic events.

meanings.definition: very active physically and mentally:
examples: The president was an energetic campaigner.

meanings.definition: with a lot of energy:
examples: Many community groups have energetically opposed the idea.
For some people the morning is a time of energetically tackling things which have to be done.

meanings.definition: the type and amount of energy used and produced in a particular process, or the scientific study of this:
examples: If you're looking at it in total energetics of food production, it's an expensive way to produce protein.

meanings.definition: the total of all your power and ability to be mentally and physically active:
examples: I'm going to channel all my energies into getting a better job.
He turned his energies to building up his business.
I would like to see the president focus his energies on reducing poverty.

meanings.definition: to make someone feel energetic or eager:
examples: I felt very energized after my holiday.

meanings.definition: to make something more active:

meanings.definition: the power and ability to be physically and mentally active:
examples: Since I started eating more healthily I've got so much more energy.
I was going to go out this evening, but I just haven't got the energy.
I didn't even have the energy to get out of bed.
Her writing is full of passion and energy (= enthusiasm).

meanings.definition: the power from something such as electricity or oil that can do work, such as providing light and heat:
examples: The energy generated by the windmill drives all the drainage pumps.

Fifty percent of people said they support nuclear energy as an alternative to fossil fuels.

meanings.definition: the mood or feeling that a person or place creates, which gives you an impression of their character:
examples: From the moment I met him I loved his energy.
If I encounter people with bad energy, I don't let it affect me.

meanings.definition: the power and ability to be physically and mentally active:
examples: They spent a lot of time and energy on the grant proposal.

meanings.definition: Your energies are the total amount of your physical and mental strength to do something:
examples: All my energies were directed toward establishing an academic career.

meanings.definition: power to do work that produces light, heat, or motion, or the fuel or electricity used for power:
examples: Certain materials acquired the ability to carry an electric charge with no loss of energy.
The cost of energy rose last month.

meanings.definition: the power from something such as electricity or oil, which can do work, such as providing light and heat:
examples: 80% of the energy used to wash garments is needed to heat the water.
We aim to manage and conserve energy and water efficiently within all our premises.
These power stations work 24 hours a day, providing energy to the nation.
energy use/costs
energy supply/production
wind/wave/solar energy

meanings.definition: an examination of a building to find out how much energy is being used in it and if changes could be made in order to use less:
examples: After a two-day energy audit of his factory, his $2.5 million business was declared "energy inefficient."
A home energy audit is the first step to assess how much energy your home consumes.

meanings.definition: a type of food that is shaped into a bar, made, for example, with oats and nuts, mainly designed for people who need energy quickly, for example sportspeople:

meanings.definition: a document showing you how much money you owe for electricity, gas, etc. that you have used:

meanings.definition: a company that supplies electricity, gas, etc. to homes and businesses:

meanings.definition: the use of as little power from something such as electricity or oil as possible, and the stopping of practices that waste energy:

meanings.definition: financial products such as options (= the right to buy or sell something in the future) whose value is based on an energy product, for example, gas or electricity:

meanings.definition: a cold drink that contains a lot of sugar and caffeine and that is said to give you energy

meanings.definition: a company that supplies electricity, gas, etc. to homes and businesses:

meanings.definition: the fact that a place is able to produce or obtain enough energy (= electricity, fuel, etc.) for the needs of the people who live there:
examples: The new president put a greater focus on energy security rather than environmental protection.

meanings.definition: ways of producing energy to provide the heat, light, etc. that businesses and consumers need:

meanings.definition: something such as oil, coal, or the sun, which can be used to provide power for light, heat, machines, etc.:
examples: We are committed to the development of clean and renewable energy sources.

meanings.definition: buying and selling energy such as oil, hoping to make a profit on rising or falling prices:
examples: There are calls to curb energy speculation because of the impact on consumers of oil price increases.

meanings.definition: an international standard for consumer products and buildings that are energy efficient (= do not waste energy):

meanings.definition: shares in companies that produce or trade in energy:

meanings.definition: a payment from the government that keeps the price of energy lower than the market rate for consumers, or higher than the market rate for producers:

meanings.definition: energy provider  :

meanings.definition: a group of things that are used together to produce energy:

meanings.definition: a way of allowing a person or organization to pay less tax because they have changed to a system that uses less energy, or to renewable energy (= power from the sun, wind, etc.):
examples: The Committee approved $20 billion in energy tax credits as part of a plan to help revive the US economy.

meanings.definition: an organization that helps consumers and businesses to use less energy:

meanings.definition: the process of using energy, or the amount of energy that is used:

meanings.definition: an organization responsible for making sure that companies that supply energy obey particular standards and do not act illegally:

meanings.definition: using little electricity, gas, etc.:

meanings.definition: using a lot of electricity, gas, etc.:

meanings.definition: relating to products, systems, etc. that use as little electricity, gas, etc. as possible:

meanings.definition: to make people obey a law, or to make a particular situation happen or be accepted:
examples: It isn't always easy for the police to enforce speed limits.
The new teacher had failed to enforce any sort of discipline.

meanings.definition: to cause a law or rule to be obeyed:
examples: We need to enforce the traffic laws.

meanings.definition: to make sure that people obey something such as a law or rule:

meanings.definition: to force somebody to do something, or to make sure that something happens:
examples: Ministers are preparing to enforce a minimum price for beer.

meanings.definition: the fact that a law or rule is enforceable (= possible to make people obey, or possible to make happen or be accepted):

meanings.definition: (of a law or rule) possible to make people obey, or possible to make happen or be accepted:

meanings.definition: an enforceable law, rule, contract, etc. is one that people can be made to obey:

meanings.definition: to employ someone:
examples: I have engaged a secretary to deal with all my paperwork.
We're engaging the services of a professional administrator.

meanings.definition: to interest someone in something and keep them thinking about it:
examples: The debate about food safety has engaged the whole nation.
If a book doesn't engage my interest in the first few pages, I don't usually continue reading it.

meanings.definition: to become involved, or have contact, with someone or something:
examples: She's an intelligent child but in class she doesn't really engage.
Just stay out of his way as much as possible, and don't engage with him.

meanings.definition: to make one part of a machine fit into and move together with another part of a machine:
examples: When the large gear wheel engages (with the smaller one), the mill stone will start to go round.

meanings.definition: to attack or begin to fight someone:
examples: Enemy planes engaged the troops as they advanced into the mountains.

meanings.definition: to teach someone, especially a class of children, or to keep someone busy
especially of a writer, musician, artist, etc. interested in and taking part in politics
to cause someone to become interested or involved in an activity, or to attract someone’s interest:
examples: He wrote about things that engaged him.

meanings.definition: to fit one part of a machine into another so they move together, or cause something to fit into and move together:
examples: The gears won’t engage.

meanings.definition: to attack or begin to fight an enemy in a military operation:
examples: The marines engaged the enemy.

meanings.definition: to arrange to employ someone; hire:
examples: She decided to engage a personal assistant.

meanings.definition: to employ someone:
examples: They have engaged accountancy firm Ernst & Young to approach financial institutions for funding on their behalf.

meanings.definition: to take part in something:

meanings.definition: to take part in or do something:
examples: Most students engage in extracurricular activities after school and on weekends.

meanings.definition: to start a conversation with someone:

meanings.definition: having formally agreed to marry:

meanings.definition: involved in something:

meanings.definition: busy doing something:
examples: I'd come to the meeting on Tuesday but I'm afraid I'm otherwise engaged (= doing something else).

examples: Every time I call her, she/the phone/the number is engaged.

meanings.definition: publicly promising that you intend to marry someone:

meanings.definition: busy doing something:
examples: The president is currently engaged but you can meet with his deputy.

meanings.definition: an agreement to marry someone:

meanings.definition: an arrangement to meet someone or do something at a particular time:

meanings.definition: the act of beginning to fight someone, or a period of time in a war

meanings.definition: the process of encouraging people to be interested in the work of an organization, etc.:

meanings.definition: happening over a long period and including a lot of difficulties:

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to or is similar to an epic (= a film, poem, or book that is long, contains a lot of action, and usually deals with a historical subject):

meanings.definition: in a way that happens over a long period and involves a lot of action and difficulty:

meanings.definition: extremely:

meanings.definition: a fold of skin across the inside corner of the eye in some people:

meanings.definition: a fold of skin across the inside corner of the eye in some people:

meanings.definition: relating to the epicardium (= the thin layer of tissue that surrounds the heart), or on the outside surface of the heart:

meanings.definition: always being pleasant:

meanings.definition: in a way that is always pleasant:

meanings.definition: in a way that does not change suddenly:

meanings.definition: the same in amount, number, or size:

meanings.definition: the same in importance and deserving the same treatment:

meanings.definition: skilled or brave enough for a difficult duty or piece of work:

meanings.definition: to be the same in value or amount as something else:
examples: 16 ounces equals one pound.

meanings.definition: to achieve the same standard or level as someone else, or the same standard or level as you did before:
examples: We raised over $500 for charity last year and we're hoping to equal that this year.

meanings.definition: to result in something:
examples: He disputed the idea that more money equals better education.

meanings.definition: the same in amount, number, or size:
examples: One quart is equal to four cups.
Divide the class into equal groups.

meanings.definition: the same in importance and (of people) deserving the same treatment:
examples: equal rights
We want a society that promotes equal opportunity for all of its citizens.

meanings.definition: someone or something that is the same in amount, size, or importance as another person or thing:
examples: In this country, we’re all equals with the same rights.
As an all-around athlete he has no equal (= no one else is as good).

meanings.definition: to be the same in amount, number, size, or importance as another:
examples: We hope to equal the amount of money we raised last year.

meanings.definition: the same in price, number, size, etc.:

meanings.definition: to be the same in price, number, size, etc:

meanings.definition: if one thing equals another thing, it results in that thing:

meanings.definition: someone or something who is as important, successful, etc. as someone or something else:

meanings.definition: in the US, a law that makes it illegal to refuse to lend someone money because of their race, religion, age, etc.

in the US, a government organization that is responsible for making sure that employers do not treat employees or people applying for jobs unfairly because of their race, religion, age, etc.
marriage between two people of the same gender that is legally the same as, and of equal importance to, marriage between two people of different genders:
examples: He argued that equal marriage legislation would create a more tolerant society.

meanings.definition: the idea that men and women, people of different races, religions, etc. should all be treated fairly and have the same opportunities, especially relating to employment:

examples: The Civil Service is an equal opportunities employer.

meanings.definition: the principle of treating all people the same, and not being influenced by a person's sex, race, religion, etc.:

meanings.definition: the idea that different groups, for example men and women, should be paid the same amount of money for doing the same or similar jobs, rather than one group being paid more than another:

the symbol =, used to show that two things are the same in value, size, meaning, etc.
the symbol = used between two written things to show that they are the same, esp. between the parts of a mathematical equation

in music, a tuning system (= a system to help a musical instrument to produce the correct sounds when played) in which the octave (= the distance between two musical notes that are eight notes apart) is divided into twelve intervals of equal size:
examples: the standard Western twelve-tone equal temperament system
Equal temperament has been the accepted method of tuning keyboards for over two centuries.

meanings.definition: giving all shares in a group equal importance, with the same importance given to shares in small companies as to shares in large companies:
examples: The table shows a calculation of a five-stock index, comparing a market weight versus an equal weight calculation.

meanings.definition: the right of different groups of people to have a similar social position and receive the same treatment:
examples: equality between the sexes
racial equality
the government department responsible for equalities

meanings.definition: the right of different groups of people to receive the same treatment:
examples: racial equality

meanings.definition: a situation in which men and women, people of different races, religions, etc. are all treated fairly and have the same opportunities:
examples: She works as an adviser on equality and diversity at the Institute of Personnel and Development.
We want to see equality and justice in the workplace.
The 2005 law was intended to promote equality for all Californians, regardless of sexual orientation.
gender/racial/social equality
equality of rights/treatment/access
The Iowa Constitution has lived up to its promises of equality for everyone.
The principle of equality between foreign and domestic investors needs to be adhered to more closely.
equality policies/laws/legislation

meanings.definition: in the UK, an independent organization that is responsible for making sure that employers do not treat employees or people applying for jobs unfairly because of their sex, race, religion, age, etc. The Equality and Human Rights Commission replaced the Equality Opportunities Commission in October 2007

the idea that all people should have equal rights and treatment and be welcomed and included, so that they do not experience any disadvantage because of belonging to a particular group, and that each person should be given the same opportunities as others according to their needs:
examples: Here is some information on improving equality, diversity and inclusion in your workplace.
Lack of budget and lack of support are two common barriers to equality, diversity and inclusion.

meanings.definition: the process of making things or people equal:
examples: There were no plans for tax equalization.
equalization of pressure inside and outside the aircraft

meanings.definition: in the US and Canada, a process in which each local tax authority tries to make sure that the amount of tax to pay on a property is calculated at the same percentage of its value as other properties:
examples: The county's equalization director confirmed that property values had come to a standstill, rising only 1.6% over a 12-month period.

meanings.definition: the process of making laws or treatment the same for all people or companies in a group or place:
examples: There are new rules which allow for the gradual equalization of pensions between men and women.

meanings.definition: to make things or people equal:
examples: They are putting pressure on the government to equalize state pension ages between men and women.

meanings.definition: to get the point in a game or competition that makes your score the same as that of the other team or player:
examples: Spain managed to equalize in the last minute of the game.

meanings.definition: to make laws or treatment the same for all people or companies in a group or place:
examples: The latest proposals would implement appropriate measures to equalize the conditions of global trade.
equalize taxes/rates/payments

meanings.definition: to get the point in a game or competition that makes your score the same as that of the other team or player:

meanings.definition: something that makes things or people equal:
examples: They see education as a great equalizer.

meanings.definition: the point in a game or competition that gives both teams or players the same score:
examples: He scored an equalizer during the closing minutes of the game.

meanings.definition: electronic equipment that adjusts (= makes slight changes to) the frequency of recorded sound to make it sound better:
examples: Stereos typically have adjustable equalizers that boost or cut bass or treble frequencies.

to make things or people equal:

         equal

         equal
fairly and in the same way:
examples: In an ideal world, would everyone get treated equally?

meanings.definition: in equal amounts:
examples: We put all our tip money in a jar and at the end of the day we divide it equally.
The inheritance money was shared equally among the three sisters.
Power is currently equally split between the two parties.

meanings.definition: to the same degree:
examples: You looked equally nice in both dresses.

meanings.definition: used for adding an idea that is as important as what you have just said:
examples: Not all businesses are legitimate. Equally, not all customers are honest.

meanings.definition: a calm mental state, especially after a shock or disappointment or in a difficult situation:
examples: He received the news of his mother's death with remarkable equanimity.
Three years after the tragedy she has only just begun to regain her equanimity.

meanings.definition: the state of being calm and in control of your emotions, esp. in a difficult situation:
examples: In spite of her financial troubles, she faced the future with equanimity.

meanings.definition: to consider one thing to be the same as or equal to another thing:
examples: He complained that there was a tendency to equate right-wing politics with self-interest.

meanings.definition: to consider as the same, or to connect in your mind:
examples: People sometimes equate money with happiness.

meanings.definition: to consider that one thing is the same as or similar to something else:
examples: Fast cars are often equated with power and sex appeal.
Most customers equate the value of a product solely with its price tag.

meanings.definition: to consider one thing to be the same as or equal to another thing:
examples: Do you equate success with hard work?
Culturally, slenderness is equated with wealth and youth.

meanings.definition: to be the same in amount, number, or size:
examples: The price of such goods in those days equates to about $50 at current prices.

meanings.definition: to be equal to a particular price, number, or amount:
examples: The £800m drop in profits equated to a 3% loss of market share for the group.

to consider one thing to be the same as or equal to another thing:
examples: He complained that there was a tendency to equate right-wing politics with self-interest.

to consider one thing to be the same as or equal to another thing:
examples: He complained that there was a tendency to equate right-wing politics with self-interest.

meanings.definition: a mathematical statement in which you show that two amounts are equal using mathematical symbols:
examples: In the equation 3x - 3 = 15, x = 6.
The students were learning to solve simple equations, such as 6 + x = 18.

meanings.definition: a statement containing chemical symbols, used to show the changes that happen during a particular chemical reaction
a difficult problem that can only be understood if all the different influences are considered:
examples: Managing the economy is a complex equation of controlling inflation and reducing unemployment.

meanings.definition: the act of considering one thing to be the same as or equal to another, or the fact that they are the same or equal:
examples: The equation between higher education and higher earnings still holds true.
These drugs have broken the equation between AIDS and death.
There is a tendency in movies to make an equation between violence and excitement.

meanings.definition: a mathematical statement that two amounts, or two symbols or groups of symbols representing an amount, are equal:
examples: In the equation 3x - 3 = 15, x equals 6.

meanings.definition: a mathematical statement consisting of numbers, letters, and symbols that shows that one amount is equal to another:
examples: Profit can be calculated using the simple equation P = R - C (Profit = Revenue minus Cost).
linear/algebraic/differential equations

meanings.definition: a situation, especially when it is considered to be complicated and made up of many different parts:
examples: In today's market it's more important than ever to get the price/performance equation right.
Another important factor in the equation is the exchange rate.
When you're starting your own business, difficulties and frustrations are part of the equation.
The WTO cannot afford to ignore the trade side of the equation.
Project planners failed to factor government bureaucracy into the equation.

meanings.definition: relating to, using, or involving equations (= mathematical statements in which you show that two amounts are equal using mathematical symbols):
examples: This kind of formulation makes equational reasoning more straightforward.
The ordinary rules of equational deduction are valid in this example.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to, uses, or involves equations (= statements in which you show that two amounts are equal using mathematical symbols):
examples: This relationship can be expressed equationally.
An algebraic system is equationally defined if its structure is defined by a set of finite operations.

meanings.definition: an imaginary line drawn around the middle of the earth an equal distance from the North Pole and the South Pole:
examples: Indonesia is on the equator.
The town lies exactly on the Equator, near Lake Victoria.
Exposure to UV rays from the sun varies according to how far away from the equator you live.

meanings.definition: an imaginary line around the earth or another planet at an equal distance from the North Pole and the South Pole
near the equator, or typical of places near the equator:
examples: equatorial Africa
The equatorial climate of the Amazonian rain forests is hot and wet.

meanings.definition: near the earth's or another planet's equator, or typical of areas at and near the equator:
examples: the equatorial Pacific

meanings.definition: a country in West Africa
belonging to or relating to Equatorial Guinea
a person from Equatorial Guinea
an officer who works for a particular member of a royal family to help in their official duties:
examples: an equerry to the Queen

meanings.definition: connected with the riding of horses:
examples: They plan to hold the Olympics' equestrian events in another part of the city.

meanings.definition: a person who rides horses, especially as a job or very skilfully
connected with the riding of horses
An equestrian statue is a statue of a person on a horse.
the sport or activity of riding horses:
examples: Equestrianism is one of the country's fastest-growing leisure activities.
She is one of the greatest champions in the world of equestrianism.

meanings.definition: equal or equally
Places or points that are equidistant have equal distances between them. :
examples: Along the avenue, all the trees were of the same height and were equidistant.
He checked the other two meters, positioned at equidistant points around the edge of the building.
Australia is roughly equidistant from Africa and South America.
Milton Keynes is equidistant between Birmingham and London.

meanings.definition: equally distant
at an equal distance from two or more other places:
examples: Australia is roughly equidistant from Africa and South America.
Springfield is equidistant from the two coasts.
Milton Keynes is equidistant between Birmingham and London.

meanings.definition: in such a way that the distances between things are equal:
examples: The five lights were positioned equidistantly below each other.
The spots on the fabric are equidistantly spaced.

meanings.definition: used to describe a shape whose sides are all the same length:
examples: an equilateral triangle

meanings.definition: a triangle that has all sides the same length
a force that is able to balance a system of forces
a force that is able to balance a system of forces
to achieve equilibrium (= a state of balance) or to bring something into equilibrium:
examples: In a global labour market, pay levels will equilibrate.
The medium was equilibrated with 5% CO2.

meanings.definition: a person who entertains people by balancing in difficult positions, especially high above the ground, or by balancing objects in difficult positions:
examples: He was the director of a troupe of acrobats and equilibrists.
They were walking back and forth along the edge of the building like equilibrists.

meanings.definition: a state of balance:
examples: The disease destroys much of the inner ear, disturbing the animal's equilibrium.
the country's economic equilibrium

meanings.definition: a calm mental state:
examples: Yoga is said to restore one's inner equilibrium.

meanings.definition: the state in which the reactants (= substances involved in a chemical reaction) and products (= substances produced in a chemical reaction) do not change because the rate of forward reaction (= when products are produced from reactants) is equal to the rate of reverse reaction (= when the original reactants return from the products)
a state of balance:
examples: He devised a mathematical method to prove the existence of equilibrium among prices, production, and consumer demand.

meanings.definition: Equilibrium is also the state of balance maintained by the various organisms that live in a particular environment.
Equilibrium also means a state of balance between opposing forces.
Equilibrium is also a state of mental calm.
a situation in which an economy is balanced and not experiencing large changes, for example when the number of goods that people want to buy is similar to the number of goods being offered:
examples: Raising the prices we charge the consumer would enable us to raise wages until we reach an equilibrium between supply and demand.
Saudi Arabia has promised to make every effort to ensure equilibrium in the oil industry and to stabilize prices.

meanings.definition: the rate of exchange for a currency at which the supply of that currency and the demand for it are equal:
examples: He attempts to estimate an equilibrium exchange rate for sterling against the euro.

meanings.definition: the price at which the supply of goods and services is similar to the demand for them:
examples: As more of a commodity is supplied, its price will fall until it reaches its equilibrium price.

meanings.definition: the quantity of goods or services that is supplied or demanded at the equilibrium price:
examples: When competition exists the equilibrium quantity will be higher.

meanings.definition: a date when day and night are of exactly equal length:
examples: The date of the equilux will vary depending on where on Earth you are, whereas the equinox is a fixed instant in time.

meanings.definition: connected with horses, or appearing similar to a horse:
examples: equine flu
The portraits showed an aristocratic family with long equine faces.

meanings.definition: a disease of horses that causes swelling of the brain and spinal cord, and that can be passed to humans by mosquitoes (= small flying insects):
examples: The boy died last week from complications of Eastern equine encephalitis, a mosquito-borne disease.
Veterinarians identified 12 horses with symptoms of equine encephalitis.

meanings.definition: either of the two occasions in the year when the centre of the sun is directly above the Equator, and day and night are approximately equal in length:
examples: the vernal (= spring) equinox
the autumn equinox

meanings.definition: either of the two times during the year when the sun crosses the equator and day and night are of equal length, about March 21st and September 23rd
to provide a person or a place with objects that are necessary for a particular purpose:
examples: It's going to cost $4 million to equip the hospital.
All the police officers were equipped with shields to defend themselves against the rioters.

meanings.definition: to give someone or something the skills or knowledge needed to do a particular thing:
examples: The goal of the course is to equip people with the skills necessary for a job in this technological age.
A degree in the history of art is very nice but it doesn't exactly equip you for many jobs.

meanings.definition: to provide someone or something with objects that are needed for a particular activity or purpose:
examples: All of our classrooms are equipped with computers.

meanings.definition: to prepare someone or something with whatever is needed to deal with a particular situation:
examples: The convention center is equipped to handle 20,000 people daily.
I am not really equipped to discuss international affairs.

meanings.definition: to give someone or something the tools and equipment they need to do a job:
examples: A company spokesman said it would not be equipping the new $2.5 billion plant until business conditions improve.
Only about 15% of buses in Chicago are equipped with diesel particulate filters to reduce soot emissions into the air.
Many so-called 'smart' cars now come equipped with wireless technology.
All our appliances are fully equipped with the latest safety features.
Nearly every phone on the market is equipped to send and receive texts.
The latest range of planes is equipped for in-flight refueling.

meanings.definition: to give someone the skills and knowledge they need in order to do something:
examples: Small businesses are not necessarily equipped to provide the stimulus and career progression many seek.
The EU and NATO now seem better equipped to deal with any new threats that may lie ahead.
An 'efficient' balance sheet in the short term does not necessarily equip firms for success in the long term.

meanings.definition: to give someone the skills they will need in the future:
examples: The overall goal is that young people should grow up equipped for adult life.
The ability to communicate confidently better equips graduates for the demands of professional life.

meanings.definition: to provide a person, place, vehicle, etc. with objects that are necessary for a particular purpose:
examples: The helicopter is equipped with video cameras that record both infrared and standard images.
We should equip all our troops with the best possible gear.

meanings.definition: to give someone or something the skills or information needed to do a particular thing:
examples: We are equipping recruits with the skills they need to do this job.
We are not sure that the UK parliament is equipped with the necessary knowledge to address these issues.

meanings.definition: the set of necessary tools, clothing, etc. for a particular purpose:
examples: office/camping/kitchen equipment
electrical equipment

meanings.definition: the act of equipping a person or place
the set of tools, clothing, etc., needed for a particular activity or purpose:
examples: computer/electrical/farm equipment

meanings.definition: the machinery, tools, etc. that you need to do a job:
examples: What are the estimated start-up costs for real estate, construction, and equipment?
Industrial machinery and equipment orders have risen by 2.7%.
People want to know exactly what they're getting when they buy a piece of equipment.
install/use/supply equipment
buy/purchase/hire equipment
electrical/electronic/high-tech equipment
computer/office/audio-visual equipment
state-of-the-art/special/specialized equipment
equipment maker/manufacturer/supplier

meanings.definition: a financial arrangement in which an organization lends equipment to a company for a specific period of time in return for regular payments:
examples: I fell into arrears on my office equipment lease and my rent for the office.

meanings.definition: a system in which equipment is lent to a company for a particular period of time in return for regular payments:
examples: Equipment leasing can be successfully included in micro-finance.

meanings.definition: a situation in which things are perfectly balanced:
examples: There is in the artist's landscapes a delicate equipoise between the natural and the man-made.
If the evidence for and against the defendant's guilt is in equipoise, then the burden of proof is on the prosecution.

meanings.definition: equal in importance, power, or effect:
examples: If A is equipollent to B, and B is equipollent to C, is A equipollent to C?
The systems can be considered to be equipollent if they have the same force.

meanings.definition: having the necessary tools, clothes, equipment, etc.:
examples: Their schools are very poorly equipped.
We were well equipped for the trip.

meanings.definition: having the skills, knowledge, or qualities needed to do something:
examples: Many consider him the leader best equipped to be president.
Not being a specialist in the subject, I don't feel very well-equipped to answer such questions.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         equip
equally probable, or equally likely to happen:
examples: Each of these actions has several possible results, all of which are equiprobable.
There are two equiprobable possibilities here.

meanings.definition: treating everyone fairly and in the same way:
examples: an equitable tax system

meanings.definition: treating everyone equally; fair:
examples: She charged that women are being denied equitable pay.

meanings.definition: fair to all the people or organizations involved in a situation:
examples: New legislation should ensure fair competition and equitable treatment for all the market players.
an equitable distribution of wealth/resources/profits

meanings.definition: a mortgage that does not satisfy all the conditions of a legal mortgage, but means the lender must use a court of law to get possession of the property if the loan is not paid back
in a way that treats everyone fairly and in the same way:
examples: If the law is to be effective it must be applied equitably.
All of the patients should be treated equitably.

meanings.definition: shares in companies, especially ordinary shares, or the activity of trading these shares:
examples: Shares rose as investors moved out of bonds and into equities.
Most people invest in equities through unit or investment trusts.

meanings.definition: the value of a company, divided into many equal parts owned by the shareholders, or one of the equal parts into which the value of a company is divided:
examples: He sold his equity in the company last year.
The rights give holders the opportunity to purchase additional equity interests in the company at a big discount.

meanings.definition: the value of a property after you have paid any mortgage or other charges relating to it
the situation in which everyone is treated fairly according to their needs and no group of people is given special treatment:
examples: a society based on equity and social justice

meanings.definition: in English-speaking countries, a system of justice that allows a fair judgment of a case where the laws that already exist are not satisfactory
the money value of a property or business after debts have been subtracted:
examples: How much equity do you have in your home?

meanings.definition: An equity is also one of the equal parts, or shares, into which the value of a company is divided.
equal treatment; fairness
the capital that a company gets from selling its shares rather than borrowing money:
examples: Many internet firms have financed themselves with equity.

The company is planning to raise equity of £1.1 billion to fund growth plans.
an equity holder/investor/strategist

meanings.definition: the value of a property for the owner after it has been sold and any loan paid back:
examples: The equity in your home can be a cheap source of cash.
An owner with a house worth $100,000 and an $80,000 mortgage has $20,000 in equity.
According to research, retired homeowners have nearly £700 billion of equity in their homes.

meanings.definition: a system of English law that developed from the 17th to the 19th centuries that can still be used to judge a case fairly in a court of law if the rules of common law are not suitable
a method of accounting that takes into account a percentage of profits from shares that a company owns in another company:
examples: The group's equity accounting, which includes its share of profits from companies it does not control, showed that net profits jumped to $105.1 million.

meanings.definition: the capital that a company gets from selling shares rather than borrowing money:
examples: Companies in the US enjoy greater flexibility in raising new equity capital.

meanings.definition: the finance that a company gets from selling shares rather than borrowing money:
examples: Equity finance is an efficient way for SMEs to finance high-risk investments because it allows investors to share more fully in the rewards of a successful venture.

meanings.definition: a mutual fund (= investment company) that invests money in equities:
examples: Management charges range typically from 1% to 1.75% p.a. on actively managed equity funds.

meanings.definition: investment in a company's ordinary shares:

a share in a company, rather than another form of investment such as a bond:
examples: The transaction can be settled in cash or by issuing equity instruments.

meanings.definition: money that is invested in a company in the form of shares:
examples: In order to develop the country's infrastructure we need a lot of capital, both loans and equity investment.
an equity investment company/firm/trust

meanings.definition: in the UK, a financial arrangement in which you can invest money in the stock market and do not have to pay tax on any profits you make:
examples: A popular way of holding shares is in an equity ISA.

meanings.definition: a financial arrangement in which a lender to a business will also receive part of any profits:

meanings.definition: the buying and selling of shares:
examples: You can trade over the phone on the UK equity markets.

the legal right to own a property after having paid a mortgage on it, even if some payments have been late:
examples: Where the payments on a mortgage have not been met and the instrument has not been foreclosed, the mortgagor still has what is known as an equity of redemption.

meanings.definition: the principle that people should pay an equal amount of tax according to their income and ability to pay
a financial arrangement that allows a person who owns a house to obtain money based on the value of their house, while continuing to live in it:
examples: Under the scheme, equity release is available to anyone over 60.
Is equity release really the best way to realize the benefit of property price rises?

meanings.definition: a financial arrangement in which someone who owns a property sells all or part of it to a financial organization in exchange for cash, but has the right to continue living there:
examples: an equity release scheme/plan

meanings.definition: a share that gives the person who owns it the right to receive part of a company's profits and to vote at shareholder meetings:
examples: The net proceeds from the issue of equity shares should be credited directly to shareholders' funds.

meanings.definition: the part of a company that a person or organization owns, represented by the number of shares they have:

a small/large/significant equity stake

→ 
        
         equity kicker  :
examples: The publishing group, struggling with a £450m debt, is offering equity sweeteners to lenders in return for their support.

meanings.definition: the amount earned on shares, calculated as a percentage of the money invested:

meanings.definition: used to describe something that is connected to the value of shares in a company:

meanings.definition: the fact of having the same amount, value, purpose, qualities, etc.:
examples: There's a general equivalence between the two concepts.
I don’t see any moral equivalence between the two sides.

meanings.definition: the fact of having the same amount, value, purpose, qualities, etc.:
examples: I don’t believe there is a moral equivalency between the two situations.
The survey indicates that there is an equivalency of satisfaction between in-person and telephone appointments.
Comparing these two organizations is a false equivalency.

meanings.definition: having the same amount, value, purpose, qualities, etc.:
examples: She's doing the equivalent job in the new company but for more money.
Is $50 equivalent to about £30?

meanings.definition: something that has the same amount, value, purpose, qualities, etc. as something else:
examples: There is no English equivalent for "bon appetit" so we have adopted the French expression.
Ten thousand people a year die of the disease - that's the equivalent of the population of this town.

meanings.definition: equal to or having the same effect as something else:
examples: A mile is equivalent to about 1.6 kilometers.

meanings.definition: the same in amount, price, size, etc.:
examples: The total consumer electronics market is equivalent to approximately $100 for every person on Earth.
Under the new scheme, companies would agree to pay the pension contributions of their employees, and in return workers would sacrifice an equivalent amount from their salary.

meanings.definition: something that is the same amount, price, size, etc. as something else or has the same purpose as something else:
examples: The FSA has spoken to its New York equivalent, the SEC, regarding the takeover.
The price of a barrel of crude oil in the early 1980s went as high as $40 (the equivalent of $80 today).

meanings.definition: If something is the equivalent of something else, it has the same amount, value, purpose, qualities, etc. as it:
examples: These athletes are the modern equivalent of the ancient gladiators.
He runs the equivalent of three marathons a week.

meanings.definition: having the same amount, value, purpose, qualities, etc. as something else:
examples: At that time, five dollars was equivalent to about three pounds sterling.
The territory of modern Iraq is roughly equivalent to that of ancient Mesopotamia.

meanings.definition: in a way that has the same amount, value, purpose, qualities, etc. as something else:
examples: The two groups of students performed equivalently in the test.
An equivalently sized flat in the capital city would cost twice as much.

meanings.definition: not clear and seeming to have two opposing meanings, or confusing and able to be understood in two different ways:
examples: His words to the press were deliberately equivocal - he didn't deny the reports but neither did he confirm them.

meanings.definition: (of statements) unclear and seeming to have two opposing meanings, or (of actions or ways of behaving) confusing and able to be understood in two different ways:
examples: She gave an equivocal response.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not clear and seems to have two opposing meanings, or that is confusing and able to be understood in two different ways:
examples: The new biography was received equivocally.
Asked how many patients had fully recovered he equivocally stated, "None."

meanings.definition: to speak in a way that is intentionally not clear and confusing to other people, especially to hide the truth:
examples: She accused the minister of equivocating, claiming that he had deliberately avoided telling the public how bad the problem really was.

meanings.definition:

examples: She accused the minister of equivocating, claiming that he had deliberately avoided telling the public how bad the problem really was.

to speak in a way that is intentionally not clear and confusing to other people, especially to hide the truth:
examples: She accused the minister of equivocating, claiming that he had deliberately avoided telling the public how bad the problem really was.

meanings.definition: a way of speaking that is intentionally not clear and is confusing to other people, especially to hide the truth, or something said in this way:
examples: He answered openly and honestly without hesitation or equivocation.
Her equivocations were not evasions.

meanings.definition: the sound that people often make when they pause in the middle of what they are saying or pause before they speak, often because they are deciding what to say:
examples: "What time shall we meet this evening?" "Er, eight-ish?"
"Is he handsome?" "Er, well - he's got a nice friendly sort of face, though he's not exactly handsome."

added to some verbs to form nouns that refer to people or things that do that particular activity:

a dishwasher (= a machine or person that washes dishes)
an actor (= a person who acts)

meanings.definition: added to the names of particular subjects to form nouns that refer to people who have knowledge about or are studying that subject:
examples: a philosopher (= a person who knows about/studies philosophy)
an astronomer (= a person who knows about/studies astronomy)

meanings.definition: added to the names of particular places to form nouns referring to people who come from those places:
examples: a Londoner (= a person who comes from London)
a northerner (= a person who comes from the north)

meanings.definition: added to nouns or adjectives to form nouns referring to people who are connected or involved with that particular thing:
examples: a pensioner (= a person who receives a pension)

meanings.definition: added to nouns to form nouns or adjectives referring to people or things that have those particular characteristics:
examples: a double-decker (= a bus with two decks)
a big-spender (= someone who spends a lot of money)

meanings.definition: abbreviation for emergency room (= the place in a hospital for people who need immediate medical care):
examples: You should go to the ER if you have chest pains.

meanings.definition: a period of time of which particular events or stages of development are typical:
examples: the Jefferson era
His memoir offers us a fascinating glimpse of a bygone era.

meanings.definition: a period of time in which the history of the earth is measured, into which an eon can be divided and which itself can be divided into epochs:
examples: The Phanerozoic eon is divided into the Paleozoic, Mesozoic, and Cenozoic eras.

meanings.definition: a period of time known for particular events or developments:
examples: She was one of the more remarkable women of her era.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a verb that can be transitive (= used with an object) or intransitive (= used without an object), with the object of the transitive verb used as the subject of the intransitive verb. For example, close is an ergative verb (I closed the door| The door closed):

meanings.definition: When a tooth erupts, it appears through the gum (= the flesh surrounding the teeth) for the first time:
examples: Before a new tooth erupts, it can cause a red, swollen area on the baby's gums.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         erupt
When a volcano erupts, it explodes and flames and rocks come out of it:
examples: Since the volcano last erupted, many houses have been built in a dangerous position on its slopes.

meanings.definition: to start suddenly and violently:
examples: At the end of a hot summer, violence erupted in the inner cities.

meanings.definition: to suddenly express your feelings in a noisy way:
examples: The crowd erupted in applause and cheering.

meanings.definition: If spots erupt on your skin, they suddenly appear:
examples: Two days after he'd been exposed to the substance, a painful rash erupted on his neck.

meanings.definition: When a tooth erupts, it appears through the gum (= the flesh surrounding the teeth) for the first time:
examples: Before a new tooth erupts, it can cause a red, swollen area on the baby's gums.

meanings.definition: an occasion when a volcano explodes, and flames and rocks come out of it, or the act of doing this:
examples: a volcanic eruption
Around the year 600, the eruption of a nearby volcano buried Ceren's buildings.

meanings.definition: the act of starting suddenly and violently:
examples: There was a violent eruption of anti-government feeling.
The curfew was aimed at preventing any eruption of violence in the capital.

meanings.definition: the act of suddenly expressing your feelings in a noisy way:
examples: He became increasingly prone to eruptions of bad temper.
His comment triggered an eruption of laughter.

meanings.definition: an occasion when spots suddenly appear on your face:
examples: an eruption of spots
Skin eruptions are common to many of us during times of stress.

meanings.definition: an occasion when a tooth appears through the gum (= the flesh surrounding the teeth) for the first time:
examples: She was taking painkillers to help with the painful eruption of a wisdom tooth.

meanings.definition: according to Orthodox Jewish custom, an area of a town whose edges are marked by a wire, or the wire itself, within which certain activities are allowed on holy days that would not normally be allowed in public on those days:
examples: The eruv is a sanctioned strategy for symbolically extending private space into the public domain of streets and sidewalks.
Outside an eruv, actions such as carrying water or prayer books or pushing a pushchair are prohibited in public on most holy days.

meanings.definition: a national park (= a large area of land protected by the government because of its natural beauty or because it has a special history) in the northwestern part of Wales:
examples: Planning ahead for your visit to Eryri National Park is essential.
The Welsh name for Snowdonia is Eryri.

meanings.definition: redness of the skin:
examples: The most commonly reported side effect was mild erythema.

meanings.definition: a circular or ring-shaped area of red, damaged skin that appears after a bite from a tick (= an insect) and is one of the first signs of Lyme disease (= a disease caused by bacteria that are spread by ticks):
examples: The most common sign is a reddish rash called erythema migrans.
The bite is followed by a rash called erythema chronicum migrans.

meanings.definition: a cell in bone marrow (= soft tissue in the centre of a bone) that becomes a red blood cell (= a cell that carries oxygen around the body):
examples: This interferes with the ability of erythroblasts to incorporate iron.
It is an inherited disorder that prevents developing red blood cells, erythroblasts, from making enough haemoglobin.

meanings.definition: a blood disease in a foetus (= a baby before it is born) or a new baby that is usually caused by a difference between the blood types of the baby and the mother:
examples: Sonogram revealed a 27-week-old foetus with erythroblastosis fetalis.

meanings.definition: any of the cells that carry oxygen around the body
relating to red blood cells (= cells that carry oxygen around the body) or to the cells from which these develop:
examples: There was no marked change in the number of erythroid cells in the bone marrow.
The bone marrow shows an absence of erythroid precursors.

meanings.definition: a kind of small spring plant that has white, yellow, pink, or purple flowers with curved petals:
examples: Plant spring-flowering bulbs such as erythronium to provide interest early in the year.
Erythroniums should be kept in just-damp compost until planting out.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for emotional support animal: an animal that helps someone who has a mental health condition or emotional problem, for example by helping them to feel calmer and less worried:
examples: Is it possible to fly with an ESA?
We believe that ESAs should have the same legal rights as trained assistance animals.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         escape
to become or make something become greater or more serious:
examples: His financial problems escalated after he became unemployed.
The row could escalate into full-blown conflict.
The decision to escalate UN involvement has been made in the hopes of a swift end to the hostilities.
The escalating rate of inflation will almost certainly bring escalating prices.

meanings.definition: to involve someone more important or higher in rank in a situation or problem:
examples: You might need to escalate the issue to the next highest level management team.
The customer is threatening to escalate his complaint.

meanings.definition: to make or become greater or more serious:
examples: Sending in more troops would escalate the war.
Our costs escalated considerably over the next few years.

meanings.definition: to become more important or serious, or to make something do this:
examples: Mediation can be used to settle disputes at an early stage and stop problems escalating.
If the customer remains dissatisfied with the response, they may then escalate the complaint.

meanings.definition: to rise or to make something rise:
examples: As prices escalated, fewer people could afford a mortgage on a house.
It was suggested that the UV coating on the windows would escalate the cost of the original plan.

meanings.definition: to become something greater or more serious:
examples: The row could escalate into full-blown conflict.
A few inmates began shouting, and this soon escalated into a brawl.

meanings.definition: a situation in which something becomes greater or more serious:
examples: It's difficult to explain the recent escalation in violent crime.
The country was not prepared for the rapid escalation of the war.

meanings.definition: the process of becoming greater or more serious, or a particular situation when this happens:
examples: the escalation of costs
military escalation

an increase in the amount, level, or seriousness of something:
examples: Many cities have seen an escalation in violence from street gangs.
There has been an escalation in tension at the border, with both sides sending in troops.

meanings.definition: a set of stairs moved up or down by electric power on which people can stand and be taken from one level of a building to another, especially in shops, railway stations, and airports:
examples: I'll meet you by the up escalator on the second floor.
He ran after her on the down escalator before catching up with her on the platform.

meanings.definition: a set of stairs that moves by electric power and on which people can stand to be taken up and down from one level to another, usually within a building
a statement in a contract that allows a figure, such as prices, wages, rent, interest rates, etc., to go up or down under particular conditions:
examples: The buyer put an escalation clause in her contract that ensured she would match any higher offer.

meanings.definition: a thin piece of meat without bones:
examples: veal/turkey escalopes

meanings.definition: an act involving some danger, risk, or excitement, because it is different from usual or expected behaviour:
examples: Her latest escapade was to camp outside a department store on the night before the sale.

meanings.definition: an act or situation that is exciting because it shows behavior that is not controlled as it usually is:
examples: Their escapades sound as if they could be ripped from the pages of “Tom Sawyer” and “Huckleberry Finn.”

meanings.definition: to get free from something such as a prison or cage, or from someone who will not allow you to leave:
examples: Two prisoners have escaped.
A lion has escaped from its cage.
She was kidnapped but escaped her captors.

meanings.definition: to get away from a situation, place, or person that you do not like or that limits your freedom:
examples: She would escape from reality by losing herself in books.
He longed to escape the small town where he grew up.

meanings.definition: to avoid something bad happening to you:
examples: None of the people responsible should be allowed to escape punishment.
She was lucky to escape serious injury.
He narrowly (= only just) escaped a fine.
He escaped being made redundant because the company reassigned him.
The southeast region escaped relatively lightly (= did not suffer much) in the storms.
The sector has remained fairly buoyant during the recession, but it has not escaped entirely.

meanings.definition: to avoid being noticed by someone:
examples: Nothing important escapes her notice.
The potential of this substance has not escaped the attention of the pharmaceutical industry.
Nothing she does escapes media scrutiny.
The historic nature of the vote escaped no one (= everyone was aware of it).

meanings.definition: to press the key on a computer keyboard that allows you to leave a particular screen and return to the previous one or to interrupt a process:
examples: Escape from this window and return to the main menu.

meanings.definition: in coding (= writing instructions for a computer), to tell a computer that a particular character (= letter, number, etc.) or string (= series of characters) should be understood in a different way to normal, by putting a particular symbol before it:
examples: Where an attribute value is a string, you must use double backslashes ( \\ ) to escape characters, such as \\n for a newline or \\uxxxx for a Unicode character.
There are two special characters you need to escape this string: the single quote (') and the back slash (\).

meanings.definition: the act of successfully getting out of a place or a dangerous or bad situation:
examples: He made his escape on the back of a motorcycle.
She looked around for a possible escape route.
They had a narrow escape (= only just avoided injury or death) when their car crashed.

meanings.definition: a loss that happens by accident:
examples: an escape of radioactivity

meanings.definition: something that helps you to forget about your usual life or problems:
examples: Romantic novels provide an escape from reality.

meanings.definition: a holiday that takes you away from your ordinary life, or a place where you go on holidays like this:
examples: The Bahamas are ideal for a tranquil, romantic holiday escape.
Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket are the favourite escape for many New Yorkers.

meanings.definition: the key on a computer keyboard that allows you to leave a particular screen and return to the previous one or to interrupt a process:
examples: Press Esc to return to the main menu.

meanings.definition: to become free or get free from, or to avoid something:
examples: to escape from prison/a burning house
The book’s faults have not escaped the notice of (= not been avoided being noticed by) critics.

meanings.definition: the act or possibility of becoming free or getting away from a place where you are kept esp. by force, or of avoiding a dangerous situation:
examples: The blast knocked me down – it was a narrow escape (= I was almost hurt badly).

meanings.definition: An escape is also an unintentional loss:
examples: an escape of radioactive fuel

meanings.definition: the key on a computer keyboard which allows you to leave a particular screen and return to the previous one or to interrupt a process:
examples: Press Escape to return to the main menu.
To exit the program, use Esc.

meanings.definition: a person who entertains people by escaping from chains, boxes, etc.

a symbol that is used in coding (= writing instructions for a computer) before a character (= letter, number, etc.) or string (= series of characters), to tell the computer that the character or string should be understood in a different way to normal:
examples: Backslash should be avoided outside of quoted strings because it is the escape character for MySQL.
The character ASCII code 1 is used as an escape character to introduce special code sequences.

meanings.definition: a statement in a contract that allows you to break all or part of the contract under particular conditions
to get free from something such as a prison or cage, or from someone who will not allow you to leave:
examples: No prisoner has ever succeeded in escaping from this dungeon.
A lion has escaped from its cage.
One of the hostages managed to escape from his captors.

meanings.definition: to get away from a situation that you do not enjoy or that limits your freedom:
examples: She would escape from reality by losing herself in books.

I sometimes need to escape from my family for a while and be alone.

meanings.definition: the part of a submarine through which people can leave when it is underwater
a way of getting out of a difficult or unwanted situation:
examples: The psychiatrist offered him an escape hatch from his feelings of guilt.

a game where people are locked into a room and have to find a way to escape by finding clues (= signs or information that help you to find the answer to a problem or mystery) in it, and solving puzzles, or a special room where this is done:
examples: An escape room is a great thing to try with a bunch of friends or workmates.

meanings.definition: a particular way that you can use to get out of a place:

meanings.definition: a method of getting out of a difficult situation:
examples: I was doing a job that I didn't enjoy and was looking for an escape route.

meanings.definition: a series of symbols used in coding (= writing instructions for a computer) before a character (= letter, number, etc.) or string (= series of characters), to tell the computer that the character or string should be understood in a different way to normal:
examples: A single backslash serves as the marker for an escape sequence.
You can use escape sequences to specify actions such as carriage returns and tab movement.

meanings.definition: to avoid being noticed by someone:
examples: Nothing important escapes her notice.
We did our best to escape the attention of the press.

meanings.definition: the speed at which an object such as a spacecraft must travel in order to escape from the gravity (= the force that makes things fall to the ground) of the Earth or of another planet, moon, etc.:
examples: Escape velocity depends on the size and density of the planet or celestial body concerned.
The planets in our solar system have different masses and so their escape velocities are also different.

meanings.definition: having got free:
examples: an escaped prisoner

meanings.definition: a person who has escaped from a place:
examples: The escapees were recaptured after three days on the run.

examples: Whatever land is not actually owned by the public authority may be transferred to it by escheat.

meanings.definition: property or money for which no owner can be found and for that reason becomes the property of the state:

meanings.definition: to become the property of the state by escheat:

meanings.definition: to avoid something intentionally, or to give something up:
