meanings.definition: to go with a person or vehicle, especially to make certain that he, she, or it leaves or arrives safely:
examples: Several little boats escorted the sailing ship into the harbour.
Security guards escorted the intruders from the building.
The police escorted her to the airport, and made sure that she left the country.
Whenever he leaves his cell, he will be escorted by a guard.

meanings.definition: to go with someone and show them a place:
examples: People on the tour will be escorted by an expert on archaeology.

meanings.definition: to go to a social event with someone, especially a person of a different gender:
examples: Who will be escorting her to the ball?
Would you allow me to escort you?

meanings.definition: a person who goes with another person as a partner to a social event:
examples: "But I can't go to the dance without an escort," she protested.

meanings.definition: someone who is paid to go out to social events with another person, and sometimes to have sex:
examples: He hired an escort to go to the dinner with him.

meanings.definition: a person or vehicle that goes somewhere with someone to protect or guard them:
examples: The members of the jury left the court with a police escort.

meanings.definition: the state of having someone with you who gives you protection or guards you:
examples: The prisoners were transported under military escort.

meanings.definition: to go with someone or something as a companion or guard:
examples: He escorted her to her car in the parking lot because it was after dark.

meanings.definition: a companion or guard for someone or something:

meanings.definition: a business that supplies people who work as escorts

meanings.definition: a frame or wire for a tree to grow along in a flat shape against something such as a wall or fence:

meanings.definition: flat and smooth, or on the same level:

meanings.definition: continuous or regular:
examples: You should try to work at an even rate instead of taking it easy one day and working flat out the next.

meanings.definition: equal or equally balanced:

meanings.definition: equally likely to happen as to not happen:

examples: an even bet

meanings.definition: forming a whole number that can be divided exactly by two:
examples: 6 is an even number and 7 is an odd number.

meanings.definition: to make two things equal:
examples: The new help for female-owned businesses should help to even things a little.

meanings.definition: equal or equally balanced:
examples: The class has a pretty even mix of boys and girls.
I bought the tickets, so if you pay for dinner we’ll be even (= you will not owe me any money).

meanings.definition: continuous or regular:
examples: We walked at an even pace.

meanings.definition: flat and smooth, or on the same level:
examples: The snow was even with the kitchen doorstep.

meanings.definition: (of numbers) able to be exactly divided by two:
examples: The result should be an even number.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize a comparison or the unexpected or extreme characteristic of something:
examples: Even smart people can make mistakes.
She never cried – not even when she was badly hurt.
Even with a good education, you need some common sense to get ahead.
The new service is one of the most useful and popular on the Web. Even better, it's free to use.

meanings.definition: used when you want to be more exact or detailed about something you have just said:
examples: I’d like to get a place in the Rocky Mountains, maybe Colorado or Montana – Idaho even.

meanings.definition: to make equal:
examples: Tonight’s win evens their record at 6-6.

Taking me to the movies isn’t going to even things out.

meanings.definition: happening in a smooth, gradual, and regular way instead of changing a lot or changing suddenly:
examples: Share prices are continuing to rise at an even rate.

meanings.definition: fair and equal:
examples: Both parties considered the exchange an even trade, with each property valued at $1.7 million.

meanings.definition: to become equal, or to make something equal:
examples: The league is divided into two skill levels in order to even out the competition.

meanings.definition: to become regular or equal, or to make something do this:
examples: Adding money to your portfolio a little at a time will even out a lot of unpredictable fluctuations.

meanings.definition: at the same time as:
examples: I tried to reason with him, but even as I started to explain what had happened he stood up to leave.

They were forced to spend more on advertising even as the cost of raw materials soared.
Even as the party stands on the brink of power, bickering between senior members threatens to damage it.

meanings.definition: used to say that even an expert sometimes makes mistakes:
examples: The famous aphorism about human fallibility is that even Homer nods.

meanings.definition: used to say that if something is the case or not, the result is the same:

meanings.definition: a situation in which the chance of something happening is considered to be the same as the chance of it not happening, so that if you bet (= risk) money on it and are successful, you will receive the same amount of money that you risked:
examples: If I were betting I'd take even money on United.

meanings.definition: having an equal chance of winning or losing a competition, or used to refer to someone or something that has this chance:
examples: He has an even-money chance of winning the race.

meanings.definition: despite something:
examples: I've thought about it so much, but even now I can't believe how lucky I was to survive the accident.

meanings.definition: despite what has just been said:

meanings.definition: to make something equal:
examples: Lori was doing her best to even up the contest.

meanings.definition: although:

meanings.definition: happening at a later time or as a result at the end:

meanings.definition: facts, information, documents, etc. that give reason to believe that something is true:
examples: The police have found no evidence of a terrorist link with the murder.

meanings.definition: to provide evidence (= facts, information, etc. that give reasons for believing) that something is true or present:

meanings.definition: objects, documents, official statements, etc. that are used to prove something is true or not true, especially for legal or insurance purposes:

growing/mounting/increasing evidence

meanings.definition: supported by a large amount of scientific research:

meanings.definition: extremely good:

meanings.definition: extremely good:

meanings.definition: not including; but not:

meanings.definition: Except also means with this difference or in this case only:
examples: The twins look exactly alike except (that) one is slightly taller.

meanings.definition: to not include something or someone:

meanings.definition: used to mean 'not including' or 'but not':
examples: Our offices are open Monday through Friday except on national holidays.
All money transfers, except for those between members of the same branch, will now be charged a transaction fee.

meanings.definition: to not include someone or something:
examples: Materials used in farming are excepted from sales and use tax.
Virtually all new restaurants in the region are smoke free, excepting those connected to a bar.

meanings.definition: not including; but not:
examples: Except for the fact that I lost my jacket, the party was a great success.

meanings.definition: used to give a reason why something is not possible or true:

meanings.definition: not included:

meanings.definition: a risk that is not included in an insurance policy:

meanings.definition: not including:
examples: All the people who were on the aircraft have now been identified, excepting one.

meanings.definition: someone or something that is not included in a rule, group, or list or that does not behave in the expected way:
examples: Men are usually quite good at map-reading but Tim is the exception.

meanings.definition: something that is not included, or the action of not including something:
examples: We don’t usually accept late applications, but since you were so sick I’ll make an exception (= do something different from what is usual).
Teen movies usually aren’t very good, but this one is an exception to the rule.
Every apple in the box, without exception, was rotten.

meanings.definition: someone or something that is not included in a rule, group, or list, or that does not behave in the expected way:
examples: Most of these states have moderate property taxes; Arizona's very high business property taxes are an exception.
The condition covering cotton textiles was agreed as an exception to the general trade rules.
Carriage is free on all orders with the exception of urgent deliveries.
Businesses exist to make a profit, and banks are no exception.

meanings.definition: a problem or special condition that stops a computer program from processing information in the normal way:
examples: The system identifies the point in the program where the exception occurred.

meanings.definition: a risk that is not included in an insurance policy:
examples: Medical insurance has more exceptions than most types of insurance.

meanings.definition: a condition in a property agreement that limits an owner's rights

meanings.definition: not like most others of the same type; unusual:

meanings.definition: unusual; not what happens regularly or is expected:

meanings.definition: much greater or better than usual:

meanings.definition: amounts of money shown in a company's accounts that relate to unusual events that do not happen regularly:

meanings.definition: a loss shown in a company's accounts that relates to an unusual event that does not happen regularly:

meanings.definition: the idea that a person, country or political system can be allowed to be different from, and perhaps better than, others:

meanings.definition: in a way that is much greater than usual, especially in skill, intelligence, quality, etc.:

meanings.definition: an amount that is more than acceptable, expected, or reasonable:
examples: An excess of enthusiasm is not always a good thing.
They both eat to excess (= too much).
There will be an increase in tax for those earning in excess of (= more than) twice the national average wage.

meanings.definition: a part of the cost of an accident, injury, etc. that you agree to pay yourself when you buy insurance:
examples: She has an excess of £200 on her home insurance policy.

meanings.definition: extra:
examples: Cut off any excess pastry and put it to one side.

meanings.definition: an amount that is more than acceptable, expected, or reasonable:
examples: They both eat to excess (= a lot more than they need).
The company’s losses are in excess of (= more than) $5 million.

meanings.definition: more than is necessary; too much:
examples: excess baggage

meanings.definition: an amount that is more than is needed, expected, or acceptable:
examples: If you retire having saved more than £1.4m you will face a one-off 33% tax charge on the excess.
Any excess over these expenses represents profit attributable to shareholders.
There is still, in many industries, an excess of productive capacity.

meanings.definition: a part of the cost of an accident, injury, etc. that you agree to pay yourself when you buy insurance:
examples: Cover would cost £239 a year with a £75 excess, or £215 a year with a £250 excess.
The policy carries a £40 excess on most claims.

meanings.definition: more than is needed, expected, or acceptable:
examples: Rents may be lower than ownership costs, meaning renters can invest the excess cash.
The machine can generate electricity using excess heat that would otherwise be wasted.

meanings.definition: bags that weigh more than the allowed amount for a single passenger, or the money you are charged to take them onto an aircraft:
examples: We had to pay excess baggage.
He arrived with 88 pounds of excess baggage.

meanings.definition: bags that weigh more than the allowed amount for each passenger, or the money you are charged so they can be taken onto a plane:
examples: He was charged $40 for excess baggage.

meanings.definition: the ability to hold or deal with a larger number of people or things than is needed at the present time:
examples: The airline has shifted some of its excess capacity from Asian to North Atlantic routes.

meanings.definition: the ability to produce more of something than is needed at the present time:
examples: The company has just opened a new factory and hopes to fill all its excess capacity with a new marketing push.

meanings.definition: deaths during a particular period above the usual, expected number of deaths under normal conditions, which can show the effect of something like a disease or harmful event:
examples: Not all excess deaths during the pandemic were directly caused by the virus.
A team at Harvard estimated nearly 4,700 excess deaths in Hurricane Maria's aftermath.

meanings.definition: a situation in which customers want more of a product or service than is available:
examples: When there is excess demand for housing, house prices rise quickly.

meanings.definition: an amount of money a passenger has to pay if they do not have the correct ticket:
examples: If you have a season ticket but are riding out of your zone, you will be charged an excess fare.

meanings.definition: the number of deaths during a particular period above the usual, expected number under normal conditions, which can show the effect of something like a disease or harmful event:
examples: We should develop methods to rapidly assess total excess mortality after natural disasters.
They analysed excess mortality from the Coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic.

meanings.definition: a situation in which there is more of a product or service available than customers want to buy:
examples: They forecast that the world will have an excess supply of 365 million barrels of oil in the three months to June.

meanings.definition: actions beyond the limit of what is acceptable:
examples: These villages are unspoiled by tourists and the excesses of modern life.

meanings.definition: too much:

meanings.definition: too much or too many:

meanings.definition: in a way that is too much:
examples: She was polite but not excessively so.

meanings.definition: to take something back to a shop where it was bought and get something else instead:
examples: If you don't like the gift, you can exchange it.

meanings.definition: to change something for something else of a similar value or type:

meanings.definition: a place or organization where shares, currencies, commodities, etc. are bought and sold:

meanings.definition: the process of changing one currency for another:

meanings.definition: to change one currency into another:

meanings.definition: an economy in which goods are exchanged for money or other goods:

meanings.definition: the risk of losing money on an investment or sale because of changes in exchange rates:

meanings.definition: someone who makes sure that things are done according to a dead person's will (= their legally recorded wishes about what should happen to their money, property, etc.):
examples: As executor, I tried to close my late mother's bank accounts.

meanings.definition: A law, agreement, etc. that is executory has been agreed, but does not yet have an effect and will begin in future:

meanings.definition: relating to the arrangements for making decisions and managing businesses:

meanings.definition: a typical or good example of something:

meanings.definition: an amount of money that someone who commits an offence has to pay, which is intended to be large enough to prevent them or others from committing similar offences in the future:

The warranty period is due to expire at the end of November.
Under current law, the state's earned-income tax credit would expire after this year.

meanings.definition: if an option (= the right to buy or sell particular shares) expires, it can no longer be exercised (= used):
examples: The investment options expire on February 5.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         expire
If something that lasts for a fixed length of time expires, it comes to an end or stops being in use:
examples: My passport expires next month.
The contract between the two companies will expire at the end of the year.

meanings.definition: to die:
examples: He ceased to breathe, gently expiring without any struggle at the age of 90.
In 1936 the last Tasmanian tiger breathed its final breath and expired in a zoo in Hobart.

meanings.definition: to breathe out or to breathe air out:
examples: The patient inhales as much air as possible and then expires with maximum effort.
The device measures the amount of carbon dioxide expired by the patient's lungs.

present participle of

meanings.definition: to breathe out or to breathe air out:

examples: the expiry of a lease/visa
What is the expiry date of your credit card? (= What is the last date on which it can be used?)

meanings.definition: death:
examples: Date of his expiry was March 3, 1931.

meanings.definition: the end of an agreement or a document after a fixed length of time:
examples: The restrictions must apply for not more than two years beyond the expiry of any relevant employment contract.
patent/contract/lease expiry

meanings.definition: the end of the period of time during which an option (= the right to buy or sell particular shares) can be exercised (= used):
examples: Friday sees the expiry of the March options series.
a futures/options expiry

meanings.definition: the date at which a document, agreement, etc. has no legal force or can no longer be used:
examples: You need to enter the credit card number and expiry date.
Their concession to operate the franchise currently has an expiry date of 2052.
The car's tax disc had passed its expiry date.

meanings.definition: the date printed on the container of an item for sale, especially food or medicine, after which the item can no longer be sold and should not be used:
examples: Food product labels must specify weights, ingredients, nutritional content, and expiry date.
Never take any medication that is past its expiry date.

meanings.definition: the last day on which an option (= the right to buy or sell particular shares) can be used:
examples: American warrants allow you to buy or sell the underlying security at any time up to the expiry date.
By the option expiry date of 21 December the FTSE 100 index stood at 5,100.

meanings.definition: to make something clear or easy to understand by describing or giving information about it:
examples: If there's anything you don't understand, I'll be happy to explain.
The teacher explained the rules to the children.
Our guide explained where the cathedral was.
He explained how the machine worked.
Please could you explain why you're so late.
She explained that she was going to stay with her sister.
"Someone must have hit the wrong button," an official explained.
Molly asked the teacher if she could explain herself a little more clearly (= say more clearly what she meant).
No one has been able to explain (= give the reason for) the accident.

meanings.definition: to make something clear or easy to understand by describing or giving information about it:
examples: If there’s anything you don’t understand, I’ll be happy to explain.
The teacher explained the procedure to the students.
Bill explained how the program works.

meanings.definition: To explain is also to give a reason for doing something:
examples: He couldn’t explain why he did it.

meanings.definition: to avoid blame for something that has happened by making it seem not important or not your fault:
examples: I don't know how you're going to explain away that dent you made in Dad's car.

meanings.definition: to try to escape being blamed for something bad, usually by making it seem unimportant:
examples: He tried to explain the error away by saying it was a simple typing mistake.

meanings.definition: the details or other information that someone gives to make something clear or easy to understand:
examples: She gave a detailed explanation of the administration’s health-care proposal.

meanings.definition: An explanation is also a reason or an excuse for doing something:
examples: He had no explanation for his absence the day before.

meanings.definition: giving an explanation about something:
examples: Some of the proposals include explanative notes after the main text.
Explanative sketches focus on certain details and features of the design.

meanings.definition: in a way that explains something:
examples: We have tried to present the results explanatively.
"I've just arrived," she added explanatively.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to or provides an explanation:
examples: Simple models can be explanatorily powerful.
Their analysis is explanatorily incomplete, and requires much more detail.
He held up his glass and said explanatorily, "Pink champagne."

meanings.definition: giving an explanation about something:
examples: There are explanatory notes with the diagram.
The kit comes complete with an explanatory instruction leaflet.

meanings.definition: helping to make something clear or understandable:
examples: an explanatory note

meanings.definition: a variable (= a number, amount, or situation that can change) that is changed so that its effect on another variable can be measured:
examples: The relevant explanatory variables are listed in Table 5.1.
We extend our analysis to include income as an explanatory variable.

meanings.definition: a word that is considered offensive:
examples: She dropped the book on her foot and let out a row/string of expletives.

meanings.definition: a rude or offensive word used to express anger, pain, annoyance, etc.
used when an offensive word has been removed from a report of what someone has said:
examples: He ran at the officers, calling them (expletive deleted) and threatening them.
What don't you (expletive deleted) idiots understand about keeping your noses out of our affairs?
He basically called my car a [expletive delelted] and that made me mad.
Oh boy, what were you (expletive deleted) thinking?
I'm going to throw this [expletive deleted] TV out of the window!

meanings.definition: able to be explained:
examples: Under the circumstances, what happened was quite explicable .

meanings.definition: in a way that can be explained:
examples: He explicably delayed the decision as long as he could.
She was explicably amazed going through all these details.

meanings.definition: to explain something in detail, especially a piece of writing or an idea:
examples: This is a book which clearly explicates Marx's later writings.

examples: His explication of each side's strategies and tactics is gripping.
There's too much explication in the play and not enough action.

meanings.definition: giving an explanation about something:
examples: The book is a combination of line drawings alternating with explicative text.
The model's purpose is explicative.

meanings.definition: in way that provides or relates to an explanation:
examples: I thought it would be helpful to talk more fully and explicatively about my work.
Mathematical models may sometimes be explicatively effective.

meanings.definition: giving an explanation about something:
examples: The text includes a short introduction and some explicatory footnotes.
The exhibits were accompanied by long explicatory leaflets.

meanings.definition: clear and exact:
examples: I gave her very explicit directions how to get here.
She was very explicit about (= said very clearly and exactly) what she thought was wrong with the plans.
I wasn't aware that I would be paying - you certainly didn't make it explicit (= state it clearly).

meanings.definition: showing or talking about sex or violence in a very detailed way:
examples: Warning: the movie contains sexually explicit material.

meanings.definition: communicated directly in a clear and exact way:
examples: I gave them explicit directions on how to get here.

meanings.definition: Explicit also means showing full details, without anything hidden or suggested.
knowledge that can be expressed in words, numbers, and symbols and stored in books, computers, etc.:
examples: Explicit knowledge can be articulated and easily communicated between individuals and organizations.

meanings.definition: in a way that is clear and exact:
examples: I told you quite explicitly to be home by midnight.
It should be explicitly stated exactly what the grant covers.

meanings.definition: the quality of being clear and exact:
examples: The story was told with the explicitness of a textbook.
The skilled negotiator knows that explicitness aids common understanding.

meanings.definition: the act of showing or talking about sex or violence in a very detailed way:
examples: The discussion was about the explicitness of sex on the screen.
Their letters had an emotional intensity and a sensual explicitness.

meanings.definition: to break up into pieces violently, or to cause something to do this:
examples: A bomb exploded at one of the capital's busiest railway stations this morning.
He was driving so fast that his car tyre exploded.

meanings.definition: to react suddenly with a strong expression of emotion:
examples: "What on earth do you think you're doing?" she exploded (= said angrily).
The children exploded into giggles (= suddenly started laughing uncontrollably).

meanings.definition: to increase very quickly:
examples: The population has exploded in the last ten years.

meanings.definition: to show something to be wrong:
examples: This book finally explodes some of the myths about the origin of the universe.

meanings.definition: to burst violently and usually with a loud noise, or to cause this to happen:
examples: A bomb exploded nearby.
Black holes are left behind by exploding stars called supernovas.
fig. Yoga has exploded in popularity as a way to achieve physical and mental health.

meanings.definition: to show sudden violent emotion, esp. anger:
examples: He exploded in anger when told his luggage had been lost.

meanings.definition: to increase very quickly:
examples: The population is exploding in that part of the world.

meanings.definition: to prove to be false or wrong:
examples: She hopes that this book will explode myths about poverty and intelligence.

meanings.definition: to suddenly change into something powerful or exciting:
examples: London's parks have exploded into colour (= become very colourful, because many flowers have opened) in the last week.

meanings.definition: to use something in a way that helps you:
examples: We need to make sure that we exploit our resources as fully as possible.

meanings.definition: to use someone or something unfairly for your own advantage:
examples: Laws exist to stop companies exploiting their employees.

meanings.definition: something unusual, brave, or funny that someone has done:
examples: She was telling me about her exploits while travelling around Africa.

meanings.definition: a brave, interesting, or unusual act:
examples: daredevil exploits
He is not content to limit himself to his exploits on the basketball court.

meanings.definition: to use something for your own benefit:
examples: The two companies joined forces to exploit the potential of the Internet.

meanings.definition: to use someone unfairly for your own advantage:
examples: Factories here are coming under criticism for exploiting workers.

meanings.definition: to use or develop something for profit or progress in business:
examples: We need to make sure that we exploit our resources as fully as possible.
exploit opportunities/potential
This collection of valuable sound recordings has never been commercially exploited.

meanings.definition: to treat someone unfairly in order to make money or get an advantage:
examples: Laws exist to stop companies exploiting their employees.
These unfortunate people have been ruthlessly exploited.

meanings.definition: to use something, often unfairly, for your own advantage:
examples: These are responsible employers who are not seeking to exploit loopholes in the legislation.
People exploit the system by lodging multiple appeals.

meanings.definition: able to be used in a way that helps people:
examples: The coal mine is no longer commercially exploitable.

meanings.definition: able to be used unfairly, for someone's own advantage:
examples: The lack of jobs in this area means that the workforce is easily exploitable.

meanings.definition: the use of something in order to get an advantage from it:
examples: Britain's exploitation of its natural gas reserves began after the Second World War.
Their goal is to protect the Antarctic and its resources from future commercial exploitation.

meanings.definition: the act of using someone or something unfairly for your own advantage:
examples: Marx wrote about the exploitation of the workers.
We want to put a stop to the exploitation of children by adults.
The exploitation of fear is an effective means of manipulation.
These people are the victims of reality TV exploitation.

meanings.definition: the act of using someone unfairly for your own advantage:
examples: She favors legislation to curb the exploitation of child labor.

meanings.definition: Exploitation of colonies leaves them at a disadvantage and makes the colonizing nations more wealthy and powerful.

examples: The awards recognize the best new products or processes suitable for commercial exploitation.

meanings.definition: unfair treatment of other people for your own advantage:
examples: Working at very low wages is only one form of exploitation many immigrant workers face.

meanings.definition: using someone or something unfairly, in a way that helps you or makes money for you but may cause harm to them or to other people:
examples: The housekeeper works long hours for her exploitative employers.
The merchandising looks greedy and exploitative.

meanings.definition: in a way that uses someone or something unfairly, with a result that is bad for other people but good for you:
examples: These companies exploitatively and cheaply buy crops from poor farmers.

meanings.definition: in a way that is designed to discover more about something or to discover new things:

meanings.definition: done in order to discover more about something:

meanings.definition: intended to learn more about something:

meanings.definition: to search a place and discover things about it:
examples: The best way to explore the countryside is on foot.
Robots, rather than astronauts, explore space now.
The children have gone exploring in the woods.

meanings.definition: to think about, talk about, or study something, or to experience it, in order to find out more about it:

The movie explores the themes of love and loss.

meanings.definition: to try to discover; learn about:

meanings.definition: the fact of something such as a bomb exploding:
examples: The fire was thought to have been caused by a gas explosion.
The explosion (= the intentional exploding) of nuclear devices in the Bikini Atoll was stopped in 1958.

meanings.definition: a sudden strong expression of emotion:
examples: There was an explosion of applause from the audience at the end of the performance.

meanings.definition: a large increase in the number of something that happens very quickly:
examples: The government has had to take measures to halt the population explosion.

meanings.definition: the act of proving that something is wrong:
examples: the explosion of the conspiracy theories surrounding the death of the star

meanings.definition: a violent burst, often with a loud noise:
examples: The fire was caused by a gas explosion.
The explosion of the space shuttle shocked the nation.

meanings.definition: a quick and big increase:
examples: Auto dealers report an explosion of interest in family-style vans.

meanings.definition: exploding or able to explode easily:
examples: Certain gases are highly explosive.
An explosive device (= a bomb) was found at one of the capital's busiest stations this morning.

meanings.definition: very loud and sudden, like an explosion:
examples: There was an explosive clap of thunder overhead.

meanings.definition: An explosive situation or emotion is one in which strong feelings are loudly or violently expressed:
examples: The situation in some of America's cities has become explosive.
Capital punishment is an explosive issue.
She has an explosive temper.

meanings.definition: An explosive increase is very large and quick:
examples: The last few years have seen an explosive increase in the number of homeless people on our streets.

meanings.definition: used to describe a sports player, runner, etc. who is able to suddenly increase their speed or power while playing or running, or to describe this speed or power:
examples: He was one of the Premier League's most explosive players.
Trainers work on drills designed to promote explosive speed and physical agility.

meanings.definition: a substance or piece of equipment that can cause explosions
exploding or able to explode easily:
examples: an explosive device
Certain gases are highly explosive.
fig. It was a politically explosive issue.

meanings.definition: Explosive also means difficult to control and likely to be violent:
examples: She has an explosive temper.

meanings.definition: very quick and big:
examples: There has been an explosive increase in the number households owning a computer.

meanings.definition: a substance that can be made to burst violently:
examples: Explosives are sometimes used to blast away rock in construction.
Dynamite is a powerful explosive.

meanings.definition: a large, fast fall in air pressure that leads to the forming of a bomb cyclone (= a severe storm that develops very fast):
examples: Four regions where explosive cyclogenesis frequently occurs are the Northwest Pacific, the North Atlantic, the Southwest Pacific, and the South Atlantic.

meanings.definition: the job of examining an explosive device and preventing it from exploding or causing it to explode safely:
examples: The men are specialists in explosive ordnance disposal.
An explosive ordnance disposal team arrived to check the area.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to, causes, or is caused by something exploding:
examples: The substance is toxic and explosively flammable.

meanings.definition: in a way that is very sudden and powerful, like an explosion:
examples: During our conversation he sometimes giggles explosively.
As a player he was talented and explosively energetic.

meanings.definition: in a way that grows or spreads extremely quickly:
examples: India and China were enjoying explosively growing economies.
These weeds cause problems because of their ability to spread explosively.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to or causes strong feelings, especially anger, being loudly or violently expressed:
examples: He has an explosively combative temperament.

meanings.definition: the condition of being able to explode easily, or of exploding with a lot of force:
examples: Everyone was aware of the explosiveness of the gas.
The explosiveness of a volcanic eruption dictates whether lavas are produced.

meanings.definition: the quality of being very loud and sudden, like an explosion:
examples: the explosiveness of the impact

meanings.definition: the loud or violent expression of strong feelings, or a tendency to express feelings like this:
examples: The explosiveness of his denial was absolute.
Kids reach the point of explosiveness faster than adults.

meanings.definition: the ability to suddenly increase your speed or power while playing a sport, running, etc.:
examples: The drills are designed to test speed, strength, agility, and explosiveness.
After major knee surgery, he lost his explosiveness.

an

abbreviation for
        
         exposition
a person who supports an idea or belief or performs an activity:
examples: Adam Smith was an exponent of free trade.
Jacqueline du Pré was a leading exponent of the cello.

meanings.definition: a number or sign that shows how many times another number is to be multiplied by itself:
examples: In 64 and yn, 4 and n are the exponents.

meanings.definition: someone who supports an idea, plan, or position:
examples: He was the leading exponent of the behavioral approach to psychology.

meanings.definition: a number or sign that shows how many times another number is to be multiplied by itself
a person who supports an idea or belief:
examples: Adam Smith was an exponent of free trade.

meanings.definition: a person who performs an activity:

meanings.definition: a number or sign which shows how many times another number is to be multiplied by itself:
examples: In 6³ and y², 3 and 2 are the exponents.

meanings.definition: An exponential rate of increase becomes quicker and quicker as the thing that increases becomes larger:
examples: We are looking for exponential growth in our investment.
There has been an exponential increase in the world population this century.

meanings.definition: containing an exponent (= a number or sign that shows how many times another number is to be multiplied by itself):
examples: 64 is an exponential expression.

meanings.definition: becoming quicker and quicker:
examples: We are looking for exponential growth in our investment.
There has been an exponential increase in sales since the new advertising campaign began.

meanings.definition: in a way that becomes quicker and quicker as something that increases becomes larger:
examples: Malthus wrote about the risks involved in the world's population increasing exponentially.

meanings.definition: to send goods to another country for sale:
examples: French cheeses are exported to many different countries.
Our clothes sell so well in this country that we have no need to export.

meanings.definition: to put something from one country into use in other countries:
examples: American culture has been exported all over the world.

meanings.definition: If you export information from a computer, you copy a large amount of it to a different part of the computer's memory or to another device.
a product that you sell in another country, or the business of sending goods to another country in order to sell them there:

India grows tea for export.
We are planning to develop our export market.
Most of the country's export trade is with Russia.

meanings.definition: to send goods to another country for sale or use:
examples: Chile exports a large amount of copper to Japan.

meanings.definition: something sold and taken out of a country and into another:
examples: Coffee is one of Brazil’s main exports.

meanings.definition: Export is also the business of sending goods to another country in order to sell them there.
to send goods to another country for sale:

The exchange rate is making it difficult for farms and factories to export.
Oil companies had contracts with an exporting countries that fixed prices and volumes.

meanings.definition: to put something from one country into use in other countries:
examples: He believes the state's educational model can be exported to other states.
American culture has been exported all over the world.

meanings.definition: to copy a large amount of information on a computer either to a different part of the computer's storage space or to another form of storage such as a CD, so that it can be used for a different purpose:
examples: If they had all the right tools on the same platform they would not need to export data.
The only way to do this is to export the data into a spreadsheet.
This article tells you how to import and export files from UNIX to other systems.

meanings.definition: a product that you sell in another country:
examples: Coffee is one of Brazil's main exports.
oil/arms/beef exports
We plan to increase our exports over the next five years.
ban/halt/control exports
a decline/growth in exports

meanings.definition: the activity or business of sending goods to another country in order to sell them there:
examples: The ruling banned the export of live cattle.
Most of their crops are grown for export.
an export company/business

meanings.definition: limits on selling goods or a particular type of product outside the country:
examples: The government has removed export controls on most computers and telecommunications equipment.
Existing export controls are restricted to export of intellectual property by paper or computer discs.
Obstacles to domestic trade are also being removed and export controls relaxed.

meanings.definition: a loan given to a person or company who has exported goods while they wait for payment from the buyer:
examples: In effect, importers of capital equipment under an export credit system are provided, as buyers, with fixed-term funds at subsidized interest rates.

meanings.definition: a type of insurance, often given by a government organization, that protects an export company from loss if a foreign buyer does not pay for goods

→ 
        
         the ECGD
a document that states that permission has been given to export something legally:
examples: Many countries require the submission of export documents issued by the Department of Public Health before importation of manufactured products is permitted.

meanings.definition: a tax on goods being sent out of a country:
examples: Last week the government approved an increase in oil export duties.

meanings.definition: an arrangement by which a bank or other organization pays an export company for exported goods and then collects payment from the foreign buyer:
examples: Export factoring eliminates the uncertainty of when you’ll get paid by your international customers.

meanings.definition: insurance that protects a company if a foreign buyer does not pay for exported goods:
examples: Manufacturers are demanding cheaper export insurance from the government.

meanings.definition: a list of things sent for sale in another country, together with their value, so that officials in the country to which they are sent will know what the package contains
an official document that gives you permission to send something out of the country for sale:
examples: The government will not issue an export licence if there is a clear risk that the proposed export might be used for internal repression.
Any company that wants to export natural gas must apply for an export permit.

meanings.definition: a country or group of countries to which goods and services from another country are sold:
examples: The EU is Minnesota's single largest export market.
Russia is the biggest export market for U.S. chicken.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         export licence
a bank, often owned by the government, that provides loans and other financial services to export companies, especially the US Export-Import Bank:
examples: The US Export-Import Bank provided nearly two-thirds of its long-term loan guarantees over the last two years to a single corporate entity.

meanings.definition: mainly involving or caused by selling goods in other countries:
examples: Many small companies drive Italy's export-led economy.
export-led growth/recovery/boom

meanings.definition: able to be sent to another country for sale:
examples: Their economy produces few exportable goods.

meanings.definition: (of something from a particular country) able to be used in other countries:
examples: The value of the new television technology to the company is that it is highly exportable.

meanings.definition: (of information from a computer) able to be copied to a different part of the computer's memory or to another computer device:
examples: The formats should be exportable to any format.

meanings.definition: the act of sending something to another country for sale:
examples: These crates have been packed for exportation.
Since 1827, Mexico has prohibited the exportation of archaeological items.

meanings.definition: the spreading of something such as an idea from one country into another country:
examples: An empire is based upon the exportation of ideology.
America's global exportation of its popular culture

meanings.definition: the activity of sending goods to another country in order to sell them there:
examples: The main business of the port is the exportation of grain and agricultural produce.
These crates have been packed for exportation.

meanings.definition: to put something from one country into use in other countries:
examples: American culture has been exported all over the world.

meanings.definition: If you export information from a computer, you copy a large amount of it to a different part of the computer's memory or to another device.

to remove what is covering something so that it can be seen:
examples: The plaster on the walls has been removed to expose the original bricks underneath.
He damaged his leg so badly in the accident that the bone was exposed.

meanings.definition: to allow light to shine on photographic film, as part of producing an image or in a way that destroys an image:
examples: Depending on how bright the sky is and what kind of effect you want to achieve, you might expose the film anywhere from one minute to 10 minutes.
This photograph was under-exposed (= too little light was allowed to reach the film).
Many of the show's paintings give the impression of over-exposed photographs (= in which too much light was allowed to reach the film).
Police forced tourists who had photographed the incident to expose their film.

meanings.definition: to put someone at risk from something harmful or unpleasant:
examples: It is feared that people living near the power station may have been exposed to radiation.
His comments in the interview could expose him to charges of perjury.
There had been an outbreak of the virus and healthcare workers had been exposed.

meanings.definition: to make public something bad or dishonest:
examples: The review exposed widespread corruption in the police force.
The newspaper story exposed him as (= showed that he was) a liar.

meanings.definition: a public report of the facts about a situation, especially one that is shocking or has been kept secret:
examples: Today's newspaper contains a searing exposé of police corruption.

meanings.definition: to make something covered or hidden able to be seen:
examples: The plaster was removed to expose the original brick wall.

meanings.definition: to publicly show that someone or something is bad or dishonest:
examples: He was exposed as a fraud and a liar.

meanings.definition: to create a situation or a condition that makes someone likely to be harmed:
examples: His behavior on the Senate floor exposed him to ridicule.
Be sure your child wears sunscreen whenever she’s exposed to the sun.

meanings.definition: to create conditions that allow someone to have the opportunity to learn or experience new things:
examples: Kate was exposed to new ideas when she went to college.

meanings.definition: a public report about a situation that is shocking or that has been kept secret
to create conditions that allow someone the opportunity to do, learn, or experience something:
examples: Some expose themselves to the equity market only indirectly, through insurance and pension plans.

meanings.definition: to put something where it can be easily seen:
examples: Make sure the new models are exposed in the window.

meanings.definition: a public report of the facts about a situation, especially one that is shocking or has been kept secret:
examples: Today's newspaper contains a searing exposé of insider trading.

meanings.definition: having no protection from bad weather:
examples: The house is in a very exposed position.
The site has easy access but is very exposed and should be perhaps left for a calm day.

meanings.definition: able to be easily harmed, influenced, or attacked:
examples: Small companies are more exposed to an economic downturn.
The publishing of my personal information left me feeling very uncomfortable and exposed.

meanings.definition: uncovered so that it can be seen:
examples: The building is very attractive with exposed brickwork, beamed ceilings, and oak panelling.
Mosquitoes feast on every inch of exposed flesh.

meanings.definition: Exposed film has had light shone on it as part of producing an image or in a way that destroys an image:
examples: He was carrying rolls of exposed film that contained secret information.

meanings.definition: not covered; able to be seen:
examples: He left some exposed wires that should be covered up.

meanings.definition: if a person or organization is exposed, they risk losing money:
examples: The bank was heavily exposed due to the high number of high-risk mortgages it held.

meanings.definition: a clear and full explanation of an idea or theory:
examples: It purports to be an exposition of Catholic social teaching.

meanings.definition: a show in which industrial goods, works of art, etc. are shown to the public:
examples: the San Francisco exposition

meanings.definition: a statement that explains something clearly
Exposition in a written work is the passages which explain where events take place, what happened before the story begins, and the background of the characters.
a big public event in which the goods of many different companies or organizations are shown:
examples: the San Francisco exposition

meanings.definition: a show in which industrial goods, works of art, etc. are shown to the public:
examples: a machinery and equipment exposition

meanings.definition: a person who explains or describes something, especially complicated ideas:
examples: He regarded himself primarily as an expositor and defender of Platonic philosophy.

meanings.definition: explaining or describing something:
examples: expository writing

meanings.definition: explaining or describing an event or situation:
examples: expository writing

meanings.definition: to express disagreement or complaint:
examples: Walter expostulated with the waiter about the size of the bill.

meanings.definition:

examples: Walter expostulated with the waiter about the size of the bill.

meanings.definition: the act of expressing disagreement or complaint:
examples: I disregarded her expostulation at my rudeness.
He heard some expostulations from the back of the room.

meanings.definition: the fact of experiencing something or being affected by it because of being in a particular situation or place:
examples: You should always limit your exposure to the sun.
Even a brief exposure to radiation is very dangerous.

meanings.definition: the fact of something bad that someone has done being made public:
examples: The exposure of the politician's love affair forced him to resign.
More than anything he fears exposure.

meanings.definition: the fact of an event or information being often discussed in newspapers and on the television, etc.:
examples: His last movie got so much exposure in the press.

meanings.definition: a serious medical condition that is caused by being outside in very cold weather:
examples: All the members of the expedition to the South Pole died of exposure.

meanings.definition: a single photograph on a piece of film, or the amount of time a piece of film is open to the light when making a photograph:
examples: There are 24 exposures on this film.

meanings.definition: the direction in which something faces:
examples: Our dining room has a northern exposure (= faces north), so it's rather cold.

meanings.definition: a risk of financial loss, especially on the stock market:
examples: The fund has hedged its exposure to gas prices.
The simplest way to reduce the volatility of your portfolio is to diversify your exposure across a variety of asset classes.

meanings.definition: a situation or condition that makes someone likely to be harmed, esp. because the person has not been protected from something dangerous:
examples: A federal court jury found the workers had been harmed by prolonged exposure to asbestos fibers.
Avoid prolonged exposure to sunlight.

meanings.definition: Exposure is also a serious medical condition that is caused by being outside without protection from the weather.
the conditions that make available an opportunity to learn or experience new things:
examples: Additional exposure to the Japanese language was provided at meals.
Students deserve exposure to creative teachers.

meanings.definition: the attention given to someone or something by television, newspapers, magazines, etc.:
examples: More races means more exposure for the team.
He gained wide exposure in both the print and sound media.

meanings.definition: the act of stating facts publicly that show that someone is dishonest or dangerous:
examples: Party officials have succeeded in keeping a lid on exposure of the senator’s misdeeds.

meanings.definition: the condition of facing in (a stated direction):
examples: Our dining room has a southern exposure, so we get plenty of sun.

meanings.definition: one of the positions in a strip of film that can produce a photograph:
examples: Get a roll of film with 36 exposures.

meanings.definition: the risk of losing money, for example through a loan or investment, or the amount of money that might be lost:
examples: The bank had relatively little exposure to subprime mortgages, which are issued to people with weak credit histories.
If they do walk away from the deal their total exposure is around £40 million.

meanings.definition: the state of possibly being affected by something such as a substance or influence:
examples: The city's youths need more exposure to positive role models.

meanings.definition: the amount of public attention that someone or something, especially an advertisement or product, receives:
examples: The overall winner is guaranteed lots of media exposure.
The product is being advertised to bloggers with the hope of getting more exposure.

meanings.definition: the act of investing in something:
examples: Her clients wanted more exposure to the energy and real estate sectors.

meanings.definition: a document that is not in its final form, but is intended for people to read and discuss so that changes can be made:
examples: Interested parties are encouraged to review the exposure draft and submit their comments.

meanings.definition: to give a detailed explanation of something:
examples: He's always expounding on what's wrong with the world.

meanings.definition: to show a feeling, opinion, or fact:
examples: Her eyes expressed deep sadness.

meanings.definition: to send something somewhere very quickly:
examples: Your order will be expressed to you within 24 hours.

meanings.definition: moving or being sent fast:
examples: Please send this letter by express delivery.
She took the overnight express train to Luxor.
The dry cleaners offer a normal or an express service.

meanings.definition: clearly and intentionally stated:
examples: It is my express wish that after my death, my books be given to my old college library.
The lawyer argued that the accused had gone to the victim's house with the express purpose of killing her.

meanings.definition: using a service that does something faster than usual:
examples: Please can you send this parcel express?

meanings.definition: a train or bus that takes less time to do a journey than other trains or buses:
examples: The quickest way to get here is to take the uptown express.
the Orient Express

meanings.definition: a service that does something faster than usual:
examples: This parcel needs to be sent by express.

meanings.definition: to show a feeling or idea by what you say or do or by how you look:
examples: She’s expressed interest in doing some camping.
Several victims expressed disappointment at the small amount of money they were offered.
He wrote to express his sympathy after the death of her mother.
The program tries to get students to express themselves verbally.

meanings.definition: (esp. of transportation or a service) fast, or direct:
examples: The express train makes very few stops.

meanings.definition: clearly and intentionally stated:
examples: It was her express wish that art collection be given to the university’s museum.

meanings.definition: a train or bus that does not stop at many places on its route and therefore is faster in getting people to where they want to go:
examples: Change here to get the express.

meanings.definition: to state an opinion or fact, or say how you feel about something:
examples: International observers had expressed growing doubts that the balloting would be fair.
express appreciation/gratitude/satisfaction
He said that a Chinese technology company had expressed interest in acquiring an American manufacturer of disk drives.
Some board members expressed concern about the proposal.

meanings.definition: to send a package or letter somewhere by a method that is faster than usual:
examples: She says she expressed the documents yesterday.

meanings.definition: to show an amount or quantity in a particular way:
examples: Expense ratios are a mutual fund's cost of doing business and are expressed as a percentage of your assets in the plan.
The rates of duty listed below are expressed in pounds sterling.

meanings.definition: sent using a service that sends packages and letters faster than is possible with the usual method:
examples: Did she send it by express mail?
I have an express package for you.

meanings.definition: existing for the purpose of doing something quickly:
examples: If you have bags to check, you can do it curbside or at the express check-in.

meanings.definition: able to travel at a high speed and not stopping often :
examples: express buses

meanings.definition: clearly stated and agreed, often as a part of a contract:
examples: All payments were made with the express approval of both governments.
He will be the main witness at hearings, called for the express purpose of spotlighting his views on climate change.

meanings.definition: using a service that sends packages and letters faster than is possible with the usual method:
examples: Send the letter express, next-day delivery.

meanings.definition: a fast train or bus that does not stop often:
examples: The express skips stops to make the trip faster.

meanings.definition: a service that sends packages and letters faster than is possible with the usual method:
examples: The package should arrive by express today.

meanings.definition: a statement in a legal agreement that says that something must be done or exist in order for something else to happen:
examples: His offer includes the express condition that he be paid $2 million if the company agrees to his bid and the transaction later collapses.

meanings.definition: a contract in which the details of an agreement are clearly stated:
examples: The court will weigh up the facts of the situation rather than looking only at the express contract terms.

meanings.definition: a place in a store where people who have few items can pay for them more quickly:
examples: She complained that the person ahead of her in the supermarket express lane had a cart full of items.

meanings.definition: a clear statement in a legal agreement of a particular right or duty:
examples: Under the express terms of the contract we will not be responsible for any personal injury incurred while you are using our facilities.

meanings.definition: a trust (= legal arrangement in which a person or organization controls another's assets) whose conditions are stated by the person making it, rather than being agreed by a legal process in a court:
examples: An express trust is created by a settlor (the person setting up the trust) giving explicit instructions as to how his or her property is to be held.

meanings.definition: the fast transport of goods, letters, packages, etc. from one place to another using an express service, or the charge for such a service:
examples: He asked for it to be sent at once by expressage.

meanings.definition: the act of saying what you think or showing how you feel using words or actions:

It's better to give expression to (= show) your anger, rather than hiding it.
His sadness at the death of his wife found expression (= was shown) in his music.
She plays the violin with great expression (= feeling).

meanings.definition: the look on someone's face, showing what they feel or think:
examples: I could tell from her expression that something serious had happened.
Mark always has such a miserable expression on his face.

meanings.definition: a word or group of words used in a particular situation or by particular people:
examples: He uses a lot of unusual expressions.
"A can of worms" is an expression that means "a difficult situation".

meanings.definition: in mathematics, a symbol or group of symbols that represent an amount:
examples: 4xy2 is an expression.

meanings.definition: a word or group of words having a particular meaning or used in a particular way:
examples: That was an expression he hadn’t heard before, and wondered what it meant.

meanings.definition: An expression is also a mathematical statement that includes numbers, symbols, or both.
the act of showing a feeling or idea, or a feeling or idea that is shown:
examples: She had such a sad expression on her face that I wondered what was wrong.
Freedom of expression is a cherished right in democracies.

meanings.definition: a statement by a company or investor of their intention to compete for an opportunity to do a job or become involved in a business:
examples: The Forestry Commission invites expressions of interest in forestry maintenance operations, as follows.
Two early front runners for acquiring the bank submitted an expression of interest.

meanings.definition: a style of art, music, or writing, beginning in the 1900s, that tries to express feelings and emotions rather than trying to accurately represent how things appear:
examples: Bohrod dismissed abstract expressionism and other major postwar art movements.
Van Gogh was one of the pioneers of Expressionism, and he used colour primarily for its emotive appeal.

meanings.definition: using or relating to expressionism (= a style of art, music, or writing, beginning in the 1900s, that tries to express people's feelings and emotions):
examples: Munch's "The Scream" is a famous expressionist painting.
Rather than being linked by a linear plot, expressionist drama is structured around a theme.

meanings.definition: someone who uses expressionism (= a style of art, music, or writing, beginning in the 1900s, that tries to express people's feelings and emotions):
examples: As an expressionist, Van Gogh's moods were frequently portrayed in his art.
The Vampyre (1979) reflected the German silent film expressionists of the 1920s.

meanings.definition: using, relating to, or similar to expressionism (= a style of art, music, or writing, beginning in the 1900s, that tries to express people's feelings and emotions):
examples: The director has created a sinister atmosphere by means of expressionistic lighting.
Germany was the centre of this expressionistic style of cinema.
The new style of dance that he developed was increasingly expressionistic.

meanings.definition: in a way that uses, relates to, or is similar to expressionism (= a style of art, music, or writing, beginning in the 1900s, that tries to express people's feelings and emotions):
examples: The stage is lit expressionistically, with a palette that combines bright neons with dark shadows.
The landscape is portrayed expressionistically and filmed with dramatic shadows and silhouettes.

meanings.definition: not showing what someone thinks or feels:
examples: She was looking out of the window at them with an expressionless face.
He has such an expressionless voice.

meanings.definition: showing no emotion:
examples: His face was expressionless as the verdict was announced.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not show what someone thinks or feels:
examples: The workers sat expressionlessly as he explained how the new system would work.
He looked at me expressionlessly for a moment, before turning and walking away.

meanings.definition: showing what someone thinks or feels:
examples: an expressive face
expressive hands

meanings.definition: showing your feelings in your voice, behavior, or appearance:
examples: His singing was beautiful and expressive.

meanings.definition: in a way that is expressive (= showing what someone thinks or feels):
examples: She danced the part of Giselle very expressively.
The old woman shrugged expressively.

meanings.definition: the state of showing what someone thinks or feels:
examples: The expressiveness of his eyes is remarkable.
Her voice is remarkable for its purity and emotional expressiveness.

meanings.definition: the quality, for example in a musical performance, of showing what someone feels and thinks:
examples: There were a few problems, but these were outweighed by the expressivity of the singing.

meanings.definition: in a way that is clear:
examples: I expressly told you to be home by midnight.

meanings.definition: for a particular purpose:
examples: The farmer put up the fence expressly to stop people walking across his field.

meanings.definition: in a clear way; in a way that shows intention or choice:
examples: He wrote the play expressly for her.

meanings.definition: to illegally take property or money that belongs to someone else:
examples: The banker has been in jail since mid-May pending trial on charges of expropriating deposits.

Look at this exquisite painting.

a vase of exquisite workmanship

meanings.definition: used to describe feelings such as pleasure or pain that are extremely strong, or qualities that are extremely good; great:
examples: exquisite joy
The pain was quite exquisite.
A good comedian needs to have an exquisite sense of timing.

meanings.definition: especially beautiful or admirable:
examples: exquisite Chinese embroideries
the most exquisite French cuisine

meanings.definition: in a very beautiful and delicate way:
examples: Their house is exquisitely furnished.
Exquisitely dressed couples stroll the streets.

meanings.definition: in a way that is very extreme:
examples: an exquisitely painful disease
Is there a more exquisitely melancholy sound than that of children crying?

meanings.definition: the quality of being very beautiful and delicate:
examples: She commented on the exquisiteness of the workmanship.
I admired the exquisiteness of the orchid's bloom.

meanings.definition: the quality of being extremely sharp or exact:
examples: the exquisiteness of the pain
He amended translations of classical texts with analytical exquisiteness.

used to refer to something very old that is still existing:
examples: We have some extant parish records from the 16th century.

meanings.definition: still existing:
examples: Phyllis Wheatley is the author of the earliest extant volume of poetry by an African American.

meanings.definition: a company that provides financial and business information, part of Thomson Financial:
examples: Extel specialises in providing financial data to fund managers around the world.

meanings.definition: done or said without any preparation or thought:
examples: The extemporal comedy of the clown has always been unscripted.
She gave an extemporal epitaph on the death of her uncle.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not involve any preparation or thought:
examples: This kind of folk song is sung extemporally at weddings.
He used to perform his poetry extemporally and then write it down on paper afterwards.

meanings.definition: the quality of being extemporaneous (= done or said without any preparation or thought):
examples: Extemporaneity brings life and excitement to the music.
Skilled interpreters need an amount of extemporaneity and a quick mind.

meanings.definition: done or said without any preparation or thought:
examples: an extemporaneous speech

meanings.definition: done or said without preparation:
examples: He made some extemporaneous remarks before the award ceremony.

meanings.definition: in an extemporaneous way (= done or said without any preparation or thought):
examples: She is used to speaking extemporaneously on highly scientific subjects.
He seemed confident, but when required to respond extemporaneously, he had difficulty.

meanings.definition: in an extempory way (= done or said without any preparation or thought):
examples: The observers recorded extemporarily what they witnessed at each place they visited.
I answered all the questions as well as I could extemporarily.

meanings.definition: done or said without any preparation or thought:
examples: She's an excellent public speaker who delivers concise, extemporary speeches.
You need to plan your presentation, but make it sound extemporary.
The surgeon did not perform any extemporary procedures during the operation.

meanings.definition: done or said without any preparation or thought:
examples: an extempore performance
At the audition, the actors were asked to perform extempore.

meanings.definition: a performance that an actor, musician, etc. has not prepared or planned, or the act of performing in this way:
examples: The familiar pieces are all at the beginning of the programme, followed by extemporisations.
Audiences still prefer to listen to well-known works of art, not to a performer's extemporization.

meanings.definition: to speak or perform without any preparation or thought:
examples: I'd lost my notes and had to extemporize.

meanings.definition: to add to something in order to make it bigger or longer:
examples: We have plans to extend our house (= to make it bigger).
The government has produced a series of leaflets designed to extend (= increase) public awareness of the dangers of AIDS.
We're planning to extend our publishing of children's books (= increase it).

meanings.definition: to make something last longer:
examples: The bar has recently extended its opening hours (= made them longer).
I need to extend my visa (= make it last longer).

meanings.definition: to stretch something out:
examples: We've extended a clothesline (= made it reach) between two trees in the garden.
He extended his hand as a greeting (= held out his hand for someone to shake it).

meanings.definition: to reach, stretch, or continue:
examples: The Sahara Desert extends for miles.
The path extends beyond the end of the road.
Rain is expected to extend to (= arrive in) all parts of the country by this evening.
The effects of this legislation will extend (= reach) further than the government intends.

meanings.definition: to offer or give something to someone:
examples: I should like to extend my thanks to you for your kindness.
The chairperson extended a warm welcome to the guest speaker.
The government is extending aid to people who have been affected by the earthquake.
The bank has agreed to extend us money/extend money to us (= lend us money) to buy our house.

meanings.definition: to include or affect someone or something:
examples: Parking restrictions do not extend to disabled people.
Her new-found tolerance does not extend to single mothers.
The invitation did not extend to family members.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to use all their ability:
examples: She feels that her job doesn't extend her enough.

meanings.definition: to reach, continue, or stretch:
examples: Farmland extends for miles in every direction.
The meeting extended into the late hours of the night.
He extended his hand to greet me.

meanings.definition: to add to something in order to make it longer; increase:
examples: The store has recently extended its hours.
I might have extended this essay to include more information.

meanings.definition: To extend something is also to increase its range so that it includes more:
examples: The proposed law would extend health insurance to all children.

meanings.definition: to offer or give:
examples: I would like to extend my thanks to everybody for making this evening a success.
We’d like to extend our condolences to the family.

meanings.definition: to increase the period of time during which something is effective, or to last for a particular period of time:
examples: At present they are only open four days a week but they plan to extend their hours.
extend an agreement/a contract/a deadline
Under the proposal the presidential term would be extended from five to six years.
It looks as if the final talks will extend into June.
Don't accept any loan that extends for more years than you plan to keep the car.

meanings.definition: to give or offer something to someone:
examples: The proposal would extend medical insurance coverage to 95% of the population, including every child.
By buying and packaging mortgages, Wall Street enabled the lenders to extend credit even as the dangers grew in the housing market.

meanings.definition: to increase the size or range of something:
examples: The company's premises have been extended.
The company's own-label range has been extended to include a dining line.
The two educators are responsible for extending college business programs beyond the classroom.

meanings.definition: Something that is extendable can be made longer:
examples: an extendable ladder
The lease on the office is extendable.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that can be made to last longer:
examples: The daily driving limit for long-distance bus drivers is nine hours, extendable to 10 on no more than two days a week.

meanings.definition: long or longer than usual:
examples: They're going on an extended holiday to Australia.
There was an extended news bulletin because of the plane crash.

meanings.definition: long or longer than usual:
examples: There will be extended election day coverage on the evening news.
They’re taking an extended vacation.

meanings.definition: the fact of an insurance agreement providing more protection against risks than is provided by the basic agreement:
examples: Even under its extended coverage the insurance company refuses to cover laptops away from home.

meanings.definition: money that is lent for a longer period of time than is usual or than was originally agreed:
examples: The airline asked for extended credit from three to six months.
Small businesses are less likely to get extended credit terms from their suppliers.

meanings.definition: in the US, money that a Federal Reserve Bank lends to a commercial bank for a longer period of time than is usual, usually for more than 30 days

a type of guarantee (= a promise to repair or replace a product) that increases the period of time during which the guarantee can be used:
examples: Only about 20% of the products covered by an extended warranty are ever brought in for repair, the agency says.

meanings.definition: in way that is long or takes a long time, or longer than usual:
examples: The link between these two factors has already been extendedly investigated.
He spoke extendedly with his lawyer before answering.

meanings.definition: a person or organization that lends money:
examples: Extenders of credit are not allowed to advertise on the student campus.

meanings.definition: a period of time during which something continues after the time that was originally agreed:
examples: He will vote against the budget extender because he wants to see a new budget as soon as possible.

a computer language that allows companies to collect financial information and share it electronically with others who need it, for example over the internet:
examples: The company announced its plans to provide complete company financials online in eXtensible Business Reporting Language (XBRL).

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         XML
the fact of reaching, stretching, or continuing; the act of adding to something in order to make it bigger or longer:
examples: The extension (= increasing) of police powers in the province has been heavily criticized.
The article is an extension of (= takes further) the ideas Professor Fox developed in an earlier book.
