I've applied for an extension to my visa (= asked for it to last longer).

meanings.definition: any of two or more phones in the same house that share the same number, or any of a number of phones connected to a switchboard in a large building such as an office:
examples: We have an extension in our bedroom.
When you call, ask for extension 3276.

meanings.definition: the last part of the name of a computer file, which comes after a (.) and shows what type of file it is
a long piece of hair that is added to a person's own hair in order to make the hair longer
a new part added to a house or other building:
examples: We're building an extension to our house.
We've paid off the amount we owed for building a two-storey extension on our home.

meanings.definition: an exercise in which you extend (= stretch out) your arm or leg, or the act of extending your arm or leg:
examples: Extensions are good for strengthening pelvic floor muscles.
Ask the instructor to show you how to do leg extensions.
The shoulder starts to lock up, preventing him from getting full arm extension.

meanings.definition: intended to support students' learning by making them try different or more difficult things in addition to their basic work:
examples: The book includes lesson plans and extension activities.

meanings.definition: offered by a university to people who are not studying for a degree there :
examples: She teaches an extension class on computer technology.
He took extension courses at the University of Minnesota for two years.

meanings.definition: any of two or more telephones in the same house that share the same number:
examples: We have an extension in our bedroom.

meanings.definition: An extension is also any of the telephones connected to a central system, esp. in a business.
an amount by which something is increased, or something added to something else:
examples: a contract extension
I applied for an extension to my visa.
We’re building an extension on our house to enlarge the kitchen.

meanings.definition: an increase in the period of time during which something is effective:
examples: When it failed to meet the deadline, the company was granted an extension.
a three-month/two-year, etc. extension
The company has negotiated an extension to the deadline for its £275 million cash-and-paper offer, originally expected tomorrow.

meanings.definition: the fact of giving or offering something to someone:
examples: This cheap, available money led to the extension of credit around the world.

meanings.definition: one of the phones in a large building that have their own numbers and are connected to a switchboard (= a piece of equipment used to direct all phone calls):
examples: Please give me a call back at extension 1247.
Can you put me through to Jan Robert's extension, please?

meanings.definition: an increase in the size or range of something:
examples: Most banks are recognizing that customers view Internet banking as an extension of existing services.
We are committed to the extension of this tax credit to cover all children born after April 2010.
The engineers have begun working on an extension of the canal.

meanings.definition: the last part of the name of a computer file, which comes after a dot (.), and shows what type of file it is:
examples: Be sure to leave the file extension unchanged.

meanings.definition: a new part that is added onto a building:
examples: The bank syndicate will finance a $460 million extension to the car factory.

meanings.definition: an extra wire used to take electricity to a piece of electrical equipment when it is an extra distance from the nearest socket
a wire that can be connected to the wire of an electrical device to make it longer
an extra wire used to take electricity to a piece of electrical equipment when it is an extra distance from the nearest socket
the attempt by a company to increase sales of a product by, for example, making changes to it or finding new uses for it:
examples: A sports clothing manufacturer used the extension strategy of advertising its sportswear as streetwear.

meanings.definition: covering a large area; having a great range:
examples: a school with extensive grounds
extensive repairs to the motorway
Her knowledge of music is extensive (= she knows a lot about music).
The wedding received extensive coverage in the newspapers (= it was written about a lot).

meanings.definition: covering a large area; having or being a large amount:
examples: Extensive roadway repairs are causing traffic problems.

meanings.definition: Extensive also means wide in range and including much detailed information:
examples: Her knowledge of music is extensive.
Foster did extensive research on electromagnetic fields.

meanings.definition: farming that uses traditional methods and uses less labour and investment than more modern methods in order to farm fairly large areas of land:
examples: Crop yields are inevitably lower in the areas that practise this type of extensive agriculture.

meanings.definition: the process of a customer trying to get all the information they need in order to be able to make a choice between different brands of a product that they want to buy:
examples: Extensive problem solving is likely to occur when the customer is purchasing a product that they have not bought before.

meanings.definition: in a way that covers a large area or has a great range:
examples: The house was extensively rebuilt after the fire.
The side effects of the new drug are being extensively researched.

meanings.definition: a muscle that moves an arm, leg, or other body part into a straight position from a bent one
a muscle that allows you to make part of your body straight
area or length; amount:
examples: From the top of the Empire State Building, you can see the full extent of Manhattan (= the area it covers).
We don't yet know the extent of his injuries (= how bad his injuries are).
Rosie's teacher was impressed by the extent of her knowledge (= how much she knew).
The River Nile is over 6,500 kilometres in extent (= length).

meanings.definition: the area, length, or size of something:
examples: Approaching the airport, you could see the full extent of the island.

meanings.definition: the degree or limit of something; how great or severe something is:
examples: To some extent it was my fault, though I didn’t mean any harm.
We didn’t know the extent of his injuries.
It makes sense to a certain extent to write down everything.

meanings.definition: to cause a wrong act to be judged less seriously by giving reasons for it:
examples: He was unable to say anything that might have extenuated his behaviour.

to cause a wrong act to be judged less seriously by giving reasons for it:
examples: He was unable to say anything that might have extenuated his behaviour.

meanings.definition: causing a wrong act to be judged less seriously by giving reasons for it:
examples: She was found guilty of theft, but because of extenuating circumstances was not sent to prison.
The lack of other options was an extenuating factor.

meanings.definition: acting to excuse something bad or causing something bad to be judged less seriously:
examples: There were extenuating circumstances.

meanings.definition: the fact of judging a wrong act less seriously by giving reasons for it:
examples: Her plea of ignorance of the law in extenuation of (= as an excuse for) her crime was not accepted.
No excuses or extenuations are needed.

meanings.definition: on or from the outside:
examples: In some of the villages the exterior walls of the houses are painted pink.
Exterior to the main house there is a small building that could be used as an office or studio.

meanings.definition: the outside part of something or someone:
examples: The Palace of Fontainebleau has a very grand exterior.
The exterior of the house needs painting.
There are shutters on the exterior of the windows.
Behind that cold exterior there's a passionate man.

meanings.definition: outer; on or from the outside:
examples: The exterior walls of the house are painted pink.

meanings.definition: the quality of being outside something or someone:
examples: This branch of philosophy emphasizes the distinction between exteriority and our inner life, what mystics would call our soul.
This belief may well be due to the exteriority of the country's architecture to mainstream discourse.

meanings.definition: to express or show something in a way that can be seen, heard, etc. by other people:
examples: Musicality is a gift of expression, the ability to exteriorize your feelings and share them with someone else.
We have each our own personality and we must have the courage to exteriorise it.

meanings.definition: to bring an internal (= inside) part of the body outside the body, for example in order to perform a medical operation on it:
examples: At birth, the bowel is difficult to repair or exteriorize.
The reproductive tract was exteriorised.

meanings.definition: on or from the outside:
examples: It was agreed that the new houses would be completed at least exteriorly.
The tower featured an exteriorly projecting niche, within which stood a small statue.

meanings.definition: to kill all the animals or people in a particular place or of a particular type:
examples: Once cockroaches get into a building, it's very difficult to exterminate them.
Millions of Jewish people were exterminated in concentration camps in the Second World War.

examples: International measures have been taken to prevent the extermination of the whale.

meanings.definition: a person whose job is to kill a particular type of animal that is not wanted in a place:
examples: He is employed full-time as a rabbit exterminator.
She and her husband work together as exterminators.

meanings.definition: a person whose job it is to kill unwanted insects or animals
a Latin word meaning "of, on, or from the outside", used in medical names and descriptions
of, on, for, or coming from the outside:
examples: the external walls of the house
Female kangaroos carry their young in pouches that are external to their bodies.
This cream is for external use only (= it must not be put inside the body).
In later years, his paintings began to show a number of external influences (= influences coming from other people).
Most news magazines have a section devoted to external affairs (= foreign news).
You shouldn't judge people by their external appearances (= what they appear to be like).

meanings.definition: existing, intended for, or happening outside a person, organization, place, country, etc.:
examples: This skin cream is for external use only.
She handles the company’s external relations.
His paintings show external influences (= influences coming from other people).

meanings.definition: coming from outside a company, organization, or country:
examples: an external applicant/candidate
A number of external developments help to explain why the country's economy under-performed compared to others.
External demand for the products of industrial countries may decline in the longer term.

meanings.definition: used to describe equipment that connects to the outside of a computer:
examples: Use an external hard drive to back up your entire system.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         balance of payments current account
the examination by a company of the things outside the company, such as the economy, the competition, and new opportunities, that might affect its success:
examples: In this article we present an external analysis of the clothing industry in this country.

meanings.definition: an official examination of the accounts of a company or organization by an expert from outside:
examples: He called for an external audit of the society's records.

meanings.definition: an examination of the activities of a company or organization in order to make certain it is obeying the law:
examples: The team completed its audit of the hazardous waste treatment facility this week.

meanings.definition: a bond that is sold to investors in several countries at the same time:
examples: The external bond market consists of the Eurobond market and the foreign bond market.

meanings.definition: the ability to sell products in foreign markets at competitive prices:
examples: The relative weakness of the pound sterling has increased the UK's external competitiveness.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         external equity
a customer of a product or service who is not an employee or part of the company that supplies it:
examples: Some 78% of the brewery's sales are to external customers, which means it is not relying on volume in its own pubs, and that sales through supermarkets are improving.

meanings.definition: the total amount of money that a country owes to other countries:
examples: The country's external debt is a staggering $38bn and its takes half the annual budget to service it.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a country pays more money to other countries than it receives from them, or the difference between the amount paid and the amount received:
examples: an external deficit of 10% of GDP

meanings.definition: the conditions and events outside a company that affects the way it operates:
examples: As the organization's external environment evolves, its goals must evolve to reflect this changing environment.

meanings.definition: the situation in which employees of a company receive pay that is fair, when it is compared to the pay of employees in other companies who do the same job:
examples: Among retail salespersons, internal equity was found to be more important to their job satisfaction than external equity.

meanings.definition: an exam arranged by people outside a student's own school, college, or university
someone from outside a student's own school, college, or university who judges an exam
the increase in a company's sales and profits that is a result of buying other companies or of forming a business relationship with them :
examples: External growth is the quickest way for a company to increase its value.

meanings.definition: the system by which a company looks outside its own organization to find a suitable person for a senior job, instead of giving the job to someone who is already working for the company at a lower level
an amount of money that a company owes to lenders or creditors (= people or organizations that have lent it money, or sold it goods), compared to money that is owed to shareholders:
examples: The company's restructuring has resulted in a reduction in its external liabilities.

meanings.definition: an amount of money that a country owes to another country:
examples: A significant part of the country's external debt is short-term external liabilities which, at the end of March, stood at $11.1 billion.

meanings.definition: anyone outside a particular company who is affected by its success or failure, for example, customers, companies that sell it supplies, or banks that lend it money:
examples: The CFO has always been in a delicate position, trying to balance internal and external stakeholders in the best interest of the corporation.

meanings.definition: trade in products and services with foreign countries:
examples: Total external trade amounted to US$323.9 billion, down 0.4% from the previous year.
external trade policy/relations

meanings.definition: a positive or negative effect for someone else as a result of something that you do:
examples: Economists sometimes underestimate the actual cost of doing business because they don't include externalities like environmental damage from pollution.
Transport creates some positive externalities because it stimulates economic growth and creates jobs.

meanings.definition: the quality of being outside something or someone:
examples: It is the object's externality that constitutes its very essence as an object that we can perceive.
How can we perceive the externality of objective reality in a representation that lacks this property?

meanings.definition: damage caused by a company's activities for which it does not pay, or something positive created by it for which it does not receive payment:
examples: Governments, through laws and regulations, attempt to transfer the costs of externalities such as pollution back to the responsible parties.

meanings.definition: the act of expressing feelings, especially bad feelings such as anger, or something that expresses these feelings:
examples: the externalization of negative feelings
The writer has said that his landscapes are externalizations of what is happening within his characters.

meanings.definition: to express feelings, especially bad feelings, such as anger:
examples: You have to learn to externalize your anger.

meanings.definition: fmlto express difficult thoughts or feelings openly

→ 
        
         outsource  :
examples: In order to cut costs, they decided to externalize certain categories of jobs.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to the outside of something, or that is on or comes from the outside:
examples: Externally the house is in need of repair.
Externally she appeared calm, but inside she was furious.

meanings.definition: the appearance of something or someone:
examples: It's easy to be misled by externals.

meanings.definition: as part of a period of study, a period of time during which a student works for a company or organization in order to get experience of a particular type of work:
examples: The course offers students the possibility of externships with local businesses.
Her externship in a pharmacy has definitely influenced her decision about her future career.

meanings.definition: a Latin word meaning "of, on, or from the outside", used in medical names and descriptions
a sense organ or part of the body, such as the eye or the ear, that reacts to information or changes from outside the body :
examples: Body-awareness is determined by exteroceptors: touch, taste, smell, sound, and sight.
After receiving an external stimulus, the exteroceptor converts it to a nerve impulse and sends it to the central nervous system.

meanings.definition: not now existing:
examples: There is concern that the giant panda will soon become extinct.
Many tribes became extinct when they came into contact with Western illnesses.
A lot of trades have become extinct because of the development of technology.

meanings.definition: An extinct volcano is one that is not now active (= will not explode again).
no longer existing:
examples: There is concern that the giant panda will soon become extinct.

meanings.definition: An extinct volcano (= mountain made from burned materials) is one that is no longer active.
a situation in which something no longer exists:
examples: The extinction of the dinosaurs occurred millions of years ago.
Many species of plants and animals are in danger of extinction (= being destroyed so that they no longer exist).
Several species of wildlife are threatened with extinction (= being destroyed so that they no longer exist).
Some people predict the extinction of family life as we know it today.

meanings.definition: to stop a fire or a light burning:
examples: It took the firefighters several hours to extinguish the flames.
to extinguish a cigarette

meanings.definition: to stop or get rid of an idea or feeling:
examples: Nothing could extinguish his love for her.

meanings.definition: to stop a fire or light from burning:
examples: It took the firefighters four hours to extinguish the flames.

meanings.definition: to take something away, for example a right to do something:
examples: A deed restriction extinguishes the right to use or develop a property for certain things.

meanings.definition: to decide that a debt does not have to be paid:
examples: With interest the debt doubled and was not finally extinguished until years later.
